People interested in hosting chargers for public use (like in societies or shops) 5. Magenta ChargeGrid Overview:
An Indian startup focused on affordable and user-friendly EV chargers.
Charger Type:
3.3 kW and 7.4 kW AC chargers Tethered Type-2 cable Cost:
‚Çπ35,000 for 7.4 kW unit Installation extra (~‚Çπ3,000‚Äì‚Çπ5,000) Installation:
You can order online and hire a local electrician Magenta also offers professional install support Smart Features:
Plug-and-play model May not have app support, but safe and reliable Warranty:
1 year standard Best For:
Budget-conscious users who want a made-in-India solution 6. Bolt.Earth Overview:
Bolt offers the most affordable smart socket for EV charging.
Charger Type:
3.3 kW socket (acts like a smart plug) You use your car‚Äôs portable charger with it Cost:
‚Çπ8,999 for Bolt Pro ‚Çπ11,000 for 4G variant Installation cost: ‚Çπ1,000‚Äì‚Çπ2,000 Installation:
Very easy ‚Äî wall-mounted socket installation by any electrician Smart Features:
Mobile app, energy tracking, usage history Can make your charger public to earn revenue Warranty:
1 year Cloud-based software updates Best For:
EV scooter owners, slow chargers, shared parking spaces, rental homes How to Integrate EV Charging with Your Home Solar Setup If you have rooftop solar, you‚Äôre sitting on a free fuel station. Here‚Äôs how to use it:
Can You Charge Your EV with Solar? Yes. EV chargers pull electricity from your home‚Äôs main panel. If your solar system is producing power at the same time, your car is being charged with clean solar energy.
Do You Need a Special Charger? No, standard AC chargers work fine. But some chargers like Statiq Nectar allow timed scheduling so you can charge during peak sunlight (10am to 4pm).
Can You Use a Battery Backup? If you have solar + battery storage (hybrid solar), you can charge even at night. Just make sure your inverter supports the extra load.
Cost Advantage: 1 full charge from grid: ‚Çπ120 to ‚Çπ200 1 full charge from solar: ‚Çπ0 (after system investment) Additional Tip: Install an energy management system (EMS) if you want to automate solar-only charging. It intelligently redirects solar surplus to your EV.
Maintenance Tips for Home EV Chargers Like any electrical equipment, chargers need some basic care:
Check cables monthly for wear or heat Clean dust and moisture from plug/port area Avoid loose sockets or adapters Test MCBs/RCDs once every few months Don‚Äôt charge in flood-prone areas during heavy rain Most branded chargers need zero annual servicing, but keep the warranty card handy in case you face issues.
Final Thoughts Installing an EV charger at home in India is now affordable, safe, and supported by good brands. Whether you‚Äôre driving a Tata Nexon EV or an Ather scooter, you‚Äôve got tailored options.
Want a brand you can trust? Go with Tata Power. Want a smart, app-based charger? Try Statiq. On a tight budget? Bolt.Earth is the best choice. And if you have solar at home ‚Äî even better. You can drive for free.
The future of mobility is electric, and it begins at home

India‚Äôs electric vehicle (EV) industry is picking up speed, and one name that keeps coming up when we talk about charging infrastructure is Tata Power. From powering homes for decades to now charging EVs across the country, Tata Power‚Äôs EZ Charge network is quietly building the backbone of India‚Äôs EV future. Whether you‚Äôre a daily commuter with a Nexon EV or planning an interstate trip in your MG ZS EV, there‚Äôs a good chance you‚Äôve plugged into one of their chargers.
In this blog, let‚Äôs break down everything you need to know about Tata Power EZ Charge: what they offer for homes and highways, how they compare to competitors like ChargeZone and Ather Grid, and where they‚Äôre headed next.
Tata Power EZ Charge: A Quick Snapshot Tata Power‚Äôs EZ Charge platform is their end-to-end EV charging solution, offering both home chargers and a widespread public charging network. As of 2025, they‚Äôve installed over 1.2 lakh home chargers and 5,500+ public chargers across 550+ cities and towns in India. That makes them one of the largest charging networks in the country.
They provide two major types of chargers:
AC Level 2 Chargers (usually 3.3 kW to 7.2 kW) for home and workplace use. DC Fast Chargers (ranging from 30 kW up to 150 kW or more) for public and highway locations. Their network supports Type-2 connectors, CCS2 fast chargers, and older Bharat DC standards to ensure compatibility across most EV brands in India.
Home Charging Made Easy Tata Power‚Äôs home charger setup is smooth, especially if you‚Äôre buying a Tata Motors EV. Often, the dealership coordinates everything for you:
A technician visits your house to inspect electrical load. If needed, they help you apply for load enhancement with the electricity board. Installation includes safety checks, proper earthing, and a wall-mounted charger. For Tata Nexon EV buyers, a basic 3.3 kW charger is usually bundled for free or at a subsidized rate. If you want a faster 7.2 kW charger, you might pay around ‚Çπ50,000 including installation. In cities like Delhi, government subsidies can bring this down significantly.
Their home chargers are Wi-Fi and Bluetooth enabled, with RFID and OCPP support. While most users simply plug in overnight, you can monitor usage through the EZ Charge mobile app in select cases.
Public Charging Network: Where Convenience Meets Scale Tata Power‚Äôs public electric vehicle charging stations are easy to find and simple to use. They‚Äôve placed chargers at:
Malls Petrol stations (HPCL, IOCL tie-ups) Office complexes Apartment societies Highways They also have a partnership with city transport agencies to support electric buses. Their chargers are monitored 24√ó7 via a centralized Network Operations Center in Mumbai to ensure high uptime.
Pricing:
AC charging usually costs ‚Çπ11‚Äì‚Çπ15 per kWh. DC fast charging can range from ‚Çπ18‚Äì‚Çπ24 per kWh. You can use the Tata Power EZ Charge app to:
Locate the nearest charger See availability Start and stop charging View real-time energy consumption Pay via UPI, cards, or digital wallets You can also use an RFID card if you don‚Äôt want to rely on your phone every time.
Future Plans: What‚Äôs Coming Next Tata Power isn‚Äôt just stopping at 5,000 or 10,000 chargers. Here‚Äôs what they‚Äôre planning next:
400,000 charging points by 2027 More high-speed DC chargers along highways and e-bus depots More solar-integrated EV stations (over 1,000 already run on green power) Special tariffs and EV-only meters for cheaper night-time home charging Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) to manage power loads at busy hubs Fleet charging infrastructure for commercial electric vehicles They‚Äôre also working on interoperability with other networks and exploring vehicle-to-grid (V2G) tech.
How Tata Power Stacks Up Against Competitors Let‚Äôs look at how Tata Power compares to some of the other big names in the Indian EV charging space.
1. ChargeZone Focus: Ultra-fast DC chargers on highways Network: Over 13,000 chargers (including partner stations) Tech: OCPI-based roaming with other CPOs like Statiq and Kazam User Base: Over 250,000 app users USP: Charging-as-a-service model + white-label stations Vs Tata Power: While Tata has scale and presence, ChargeZone is slightly ahead in roaming and ultra-high-speed DC stations.
2. Statiq Focus: Affordable smart charging with high app integration Network: 8,000+ chargers in 60+ cities Pricing: One of the lowest in the market (starting from ‚Çπ11/kWh) Tie-ups: Works with real estate developers, hotels, and tourism boards Vs Tata Power: Statiq is expanding fast with lower pricing, but Tata Power has deeper infrastructure control and brand trust.
3. Ather Grid Focus: Two-wheeler fast charging (mainly for Ather scooters) Network: 2,500+ charging points Speed: 1.5 km/min for Ather vehicles Pricing: ~‚Çπ1/min charging, app-based billing Vs Tata Power: Ather Grid is niche, serving mostly scooters. Tata Power caters to cars, fleets, and buses.
4. Jio-BP Pulse Focus: High-speed chargers at Reliance/Jio fuel stations Backed by: Reliance + BP USP: Highway and urban integration with fuel retail Vs Tata Power: Jio-BP has reach via its fuel stations, but Tata Power has more EV-first infrastructure and home charging reach.
5. Magenta ChargeGrid Focus: Solar-powered AC chargers USP: Subscription discounts, compact units for housing societies Vs Tata Power: Magenta is ideal for gated communities. Tata Power wins in scale, service, and EV ecosystem alignment.
Final Thoughts Tata Power EZ Charge has emerged as a trusted and powerful force in India‚Äôs EV transition. With the confidence of Tata Group, deep roots in power distribution, and smart moves across home and public charging, they‚Äôre setting the benchmark for how EV charging should work in a country as diverse and growing as India.
If you‚Äôre planning to switch to an EV in 2025, keep Tata Power EZ Charge on your radar. Whether you‚Äôre at home or on the highway, they‚Äôre already building the convenience you‚Äôll need tomorrow.

As India moves rapidly toward a greener mobility future, the electric vehicle (EV) charging ecosystem is becoming the bedrock of this transition. One of the most ambitious players entering this space is Jio-bp Pulse ‚Äî the EV charging business born from a powerful joint venture between Reliance Industries Limited and British Petroleum (BP). Though a relatively new entrant, Jio-bp Pulse has already made bold moves to shape the EV charging landscape in India through strategic placement, ultra-fast charging, renewable integration, and extensive collaborations.
In this detailed blog, we‚Äôll explore the full history of Jio-bp Pulse, how it has evolved since its inception, what it currently offers to both EV drivers and business partners, and its aggressive roadmap for the future. This is not just another EV brand‚Äîit‚Äôs a sign of how India‚Äôs largest corporate players are betting big on electric mobility.
How It All Began: The Genesis of Jio-bp Pulse Jio-bp Pulse was officially launched in 2021 as part of the larger Reliance-BP joint venture under Reliance BP Mobility Limited (RBML). The company aimed to combine BP‚Äôs global EV charging experience (such as the BP Pulse network in the UK) with Reliance‚Äôs expansive fuel station footprint and real estate reach in India.
This wasn‚Äôt just about launching chargers. It was about reimagining fuel retail in India. Jio-bp Pulse envisioned India‚Äôs existing petrol pumps transforming into multi-energy hubs ‚Äî offering petrol, diesel, compressed natural gas (CNG), and electric vehicle charging under one roof.
The first few EV chargers appeared quietly at existing Jio-bp fuel stations, especially in Maharashtra and Delhi-NCR. But soon after, the company launched its Pulse brand to signal a focused EV initiative. By 2022, Jio-bp Pulse had rolled out dozens of chargers, forming a base for what would later scale exponentially.
The 2024‚Äì2025 Growth Phase: Building Nationwide Momentum Fast forward to 2024, Jio-bp Pulse reported it had crossed the 5,000 charger milestone ‚Äî covering over 500 charging stations in key urban and transit locations. Many of these were installed at or near Jio-bp mobility stations (Reliance fuel stations), and several others were deployed through commercial tie-ups with malls, residential developers, fleet operators, and metro rail stations.
What differentiated Jio-bp Pulse in this period was its focus on:
High-speed DC chargers (30‚Äì60 kW and more) Charging stations along EV corridors (Delhi-Mumbai Expressway, Mumbai-Pune, Bengaluru-Hyderabad) App-enabled, digitally managed infrastructure Co-located retail services like cafes and convenience stores The Pulse network quickly grew in cities like Mumbai, Delhi, Pune, Bengaluru, Ahmedabad, and Chennai. Users started to recognize the green-and-black Pulse branding as a sign of a reliable, well-lit, secure, and fast EV charging option.
What Jio-bp Pulse Offers Today (2025) 1. A Multi-Tiered Charging Infrastructure Jio-bp Pulse offers three major types of chargers:
AC Chargers (3.3 kW‚Äì7.4 kW): Best for two-wheelers, e-autos, or long parking sessions DC Fast Chargers (30‚Äì60 kW): Ideal for passenger EVs like the Tata Nexon EV, MG ZS EV, or BYD Atto 3 Ultra-Fast DC Chargers (100‚Äì480 kW): For long-range premium EVs, fleet operators, and upcoming commercial EVs These are spread across fuel stations, commercial buildings, parking lots, highways, and business parks. Most stations support CCS2 connectors, which are standard for Indian EVs, along with Type 2 AC plugs for slower charging.
2. App Ecosystem and RFID Access The Jio-bp Pulse App lets users:
Find the nearest charger Check availability in real-time Navigate to the station Start and stop charging Pay through UPI, cards, wallets, or Pulse subscriptions The company also offers RFID cards for fleet and private users who prefer a tap-to-charge option. Some larger fleet users (like BluSmart and e-commerce delivery companies) have dedicated Pulse fleet accounts to manage billing, usage, and access.
3. Battery Swapping Pilots For electric two- and three-wheelers, Jio-bp Pulse has started pilot programs with battery swapping infrastructure in Mumbai and Hyderabad. The idea is simple: instead of waiting 1‚Äì2 hours for a charge, just swap the depleted battery with a fully charged one in under 2 minutes. This model especially appeals to delivery riders, gig workers, and autorickshaw fleets.
Strategic Collaborations and Commercial Partnerships One reason for the rapid scale of Jio-bp Pulse is its well-planned partnerships:
BluSmart Mobility: Jio-bp has built dedicated charging hubs for BluSmart, India‚Äôs all-electric ride-hailing service, across Delhi-NCR and Mumbai. House of Hiranandani: EV chargers in premium residential townships in Chennai, Bengaluru, and Mumbai. Piramal Realty: Providing residential and commercial EV charging integration in upcoming developments. Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (DMRC): Chargers installed at metro stations like Rithala and Rajiv Chowk. Apollo Tyres and Mahindra Logistics: Fleet charging partnerships at warehouses and last-mile hubs. These alliances help Jio-bp Pulse serve not just individual drivers, but also large mobility players looking to electrify their operations.
How Jio-bp Pulse Compares With Other Charging Networks Let‚Äôs break down how Jio-bp stacks up against some of India‚Äôs top EV charging companies:
Tata Power EZ Charge Strength: Scale (100,000+ home + public chargers), utility backing, OEM tie-ups Weakness: Slower rollout of ultra-fast highway chargers Jio-bp Edge: Faster DC rollout at fuel stations, focus on EV corridors
ChargeZone Strength: Largest roaming-enabled network, 13,000+ chargers, 150+ cities Weakness: Mostly partner-based, not all owned Jio-bp Edge: More integrated retail experience, reliability, and service uptime
Statiq Strength: Strong app, low-cost charging, tier-2 city penetration Weakness: Limited ultra-fast charging Jio-bp Edge: Faster chargers and premium station setups
Ather Grid Strength: Widely used among e-scooter users, high urban density Weakness: Not suitable for 4-wheelers Jio-bp Edge: Full-size EV focus, four-wheeler and fleet infrastructure
The Road Ahead: What‚Äôs Next for Jio-bp Pulse (2025‚Äì2030) 1. 30,000 Charging Points by 2030 Jio-bp has committed to installing 30,000+ EV charging points across India by the end of this decade. This will include:
Fuel station integration Urban and rural charging Fleet and depot charging Residential society partnerships 2. Renewable-Powered Charging Hubs By 2030, Jio-bp aims to power its entire EV charging network with renewable energy. In cities like Bengaluru and Pune, they‚Äôve already installed solar-powered canopy chargers. Over 1,000 stations are expected to run on green power by 2026.
3. AI and Smart Charging Infrastructure The future of charging is smart. Jio-bp is piloting AI-based load balancing, time-of-day pricing, and even energy storage integration using lithium battery banks at busy locations. This will make peak-hour charging more efficient and affordable.
4. Battery Swapping Scale-up Based on positive feedback from pilot programs, Jio-bp is planning to roll out hundreds of battery swapping stations in urban centers by 2026. This will target delivery platforms like Zomato, Swiggy, and Dunzo.
5. Pan-India EV Corridor Network Jio-bp is building what it calls the EV Super Highway Grid ‚Äî connecting all major cities through ultra-fast chargers every 100 km. This includes:
Delhi‚ÄìMumbai Chennai‚ÄìBengaluru Kolkata‚ÄìBhubaneswar Hyderabad‚ÄìNagpur Each stop is expected to have restrooms, cafes, and Wi-Fi, creating a true EV-friendly ecosystem for long-distance travel.
Final Thoughts Jio-bp Pulse may have started later than some EV players, but it‚Äôs now one of the fastest-growing EV infrastructure providers in India. With Reliance‚Äôs retail muscle and BP‚Äôs global energy expertise, the company is well-positioned to serve both the private and commercial EV market.
Its strategy‚Äîrooted in fast charging, user convenience, renewable integration, and smart mobility partnerships‚Äîmakes it a formidable player in India‚Äôs electrification journey.
As India‚Äôs EV adoption climbs through 2025 and beyond, Jio-bp Pulse isn‚Äôt just catching up‚Äîit‚Äôs racing ahead.

Introduction If India is serious about going electric, it‚Äôs going to need much more than a fleet of shiny new vehicles. It needs the backbone to support that shift‚Äîa dense, smart, and reliable electric vehicle charging network.
That‚Äôs where ChargeZone steps in.
While other players are still making announcements or pilot installations, ChargeZone is already on the ground, building what could be India‚Äôs most practical and scalable EV charging solution.
From highway corridors to commercial vehicle depots, from two-wheelers to electric buses, ChargeZone has rapidly evolved into India‚Äôs most ambitious full-stack EV infrastructure company. And they‚Äôre just getting started.
In this blog, we‚Äôre taking you behind the scenes of ChargeZone‚Äôs journey‚Äîits history, technology, expansion strategies, and what lies ahead on the road to 2030.
Founding Story: From Vision to Execution ChargeZone was founded in 2018 by Kartikey Hariyani, an entrepreneur and clean energy specialist who understood one hard truth early on‚ÄîEVs are inevitable, but the infrastructure needed to support them is missing.
At the time, electric vehicles in India were still seen as experimental. electric vehicle Charging stations were rare, mostly found in parking lots of 5-star hotels or government buildings.
Instead of waiting for change, Kartikey decided to build it himself.
His goal? Create a fast, tech-enabled, and future-ready charging network that could serve:
City-based EV drivers Fleet owners and logistics companies Long-distance travelers Public transportation operators From a handful of fast chargers in Gujarat, ChargeZone has grown into a full-blown infrastructure company with a nationwide network and a bold plan to support millions of EVs in the years ahead.
Company Overview: What Exactly Does ChargeZone Do? ChargeZone isn‚Äôt just putting up a few charging points‚Äîthey are building a scalable and connected charging ecosystem across India. The company is involved in every layer of the EV infrastructure chain:
Manufacturing & deploying DC fast chargers Developing proprietary charging management software (CMS) Building app-based EV navigation and billing platforms Providing end-to-end EV charging solutions for businesses, fleets, and governments Creating solar-integrated charging hubs Whether you‚Äôre a daily commuter in an EV car, a delivery fleet owner, or a bus transport agency, ChargeZone has tailored solutions designed for reliability, scalability, and energy efficiency.
Where Is ChargeZone Operating? Today, ChargeZone has over 1,500 active charging points deployed across more than 300 locations in India. The network is growing rapidly, with new installations happening every month.
Here‚Äôs a breakdown of their key operational zones:
1. Highway Fast Charging Corridors ChargeZone has installed fast chargers every 80‚Äì100 km on major intercity highways. These include routes like:
Mumbai‚ÄìAhmedabad Expressway Delhi‚ÄìAgra‚ÄìLucknow Expressway Pune‚ÄìGoa Highway Chennai‚ÄìBangalore‚ÄìHyderabad Corridor These stations make EV road trips possible, safe, and predictable.
2. City-Wide Charging Networks You‚Äôll find ChargeZone stations in cities like:
Ahmedabad Pune Bangalore Delhi NCR Hyderabad Surat They are placed strategically in shopping malls, corporate campuses, residential societies, and business districts.
3. Government and Bus Transport Depots ChargeZone is working with State Transport Units (STUs) to power electric buses. These depots require multi-vehicle, high-capacity charging infrastructure with load balancing and 24/7 uptime monitoring.
Core Technology: Smart, Scalable, and Reliable ChargeZone‚Äôs biggest differentiator is its technology infrastructure. Rather than depending on third-party software or hardware, ChargeZone has built its entire backend in-house.
DC Fast Chargers (30kW‚Äì120kW) These chargers are the backbone of their network. With power outputs ranging from 30kW to 120kW, they can charge a Tata Nexon EV or BYD Atto 3 from 20% to 80% in about 40 minutes.
Charging Management System (CMS) Their CMS remotely manages every charging station and:
Tracks real-time usage Flags malfunctions immediately Handles dynamic load distribution Integrates energy source optimization (solar + grid) Smart Mobile App More than just a locator, the ChargeZone app is a full-fledged platform that:
Displays available chargers Offers one-tap charging start/stop Handles payment through UPI, wallets, or cards Shows session history and billing details Sends completion and error notifications Who Uses ChargeZone? ChargeZone‚Äôs charging solutions are being used by a wide range of customers:
1. Private EV Owners EV users plug in at ChargeZone stations while shopping, working, or dining. The ease of use and fast charging speed make it a preferred option in cities.
2. Fleet Operators From cab aggregators to food delivery fleets, ChargeZone offers:
Dedicated depots Scheduled charging slots Real-time dashboards Maintenance SLAs 3. Public Transport Operators ChargeZone has built charging infrastructure for electric buses in Gujarat, Uttar Pradesh, and Maharashtra. These systems are designed to:
Charge multiple buses simultaneously Operate overnight Run on both grid and renewable power ChargeZone‚Äôs 2025‚Äì2030 Roadmap ChargeZone‚Äôs strategy isn‚Äôt limited to expanding its network. It‚Äôs about building a future-proof, technology-first infrastructure ecosystem that aligns with India‚Äôs long-term EV vision.
Here are the five major pillars of their roadmap:
1. Scaling Up to 10,000 Chargers By 2027, ChargeZone plans to install over 10,000 fast chargers across India. These will cover:
Tier 1 and Tier 2 cities National and state highways Transport logistics hubs Tourist circuits The goal is to make EV charging as available and reliable as petrol pumps.
2. Battery Swapping Stations ChargeZone is piloting battery swap kiosks for:
E-rickshaws Two-wheelers used in food and parcel delivery Cargo three-wheelers Swapping reduces downtime for commercial users. ChargeZone‚Äôs kiosks are built for high throughput and compatibility with multiple vehicle formats.
3. Solar-Powered Charging Hubs They are actively building solar-integrated hubs with:
On-site rooftop solar Battery storage for night-time usage Smart energy management software By 2030, up to 40% of their stations will run on renewable energy.
4. Charging-as-a-Service (CaaS) Fleet and institutional users can subscribe to a monthly plan that includes:
Charging infrastructure Software dashboard Real-time analytics Maintenance and energy billing This model simplifies operations for commercial clients and ensures predictability in costs.
5. Global Expansion ChargeZone is eyeing markets like:
UAE (Dubai, Abu Dhabi) Indonesia Vietnam Malaysia They plan to license their CMS software and deploy physical stations through joint ventures.
Real-World Scenario: An EV Road Trip with ChargeZone Let‚Äôs say you‚Äôre driving from Ahmedabad to Mumbai in a Tata Nexon EV. Here‚Äôs what a typical trip looks like with ChargeZone:
Start: Ahmedabad, 90% battery Stop 1: Bharuch ‚Äì Fast charger with coffee shop Stop 2: Vapi ‚Äì Top up while having lunch Arrival: Mumbai with 50% battery remaining This is not a hypothetical‚Äîit‚Äôs the new normal thanks to ChargeZone‚Äôs strategically placed fast chargers.
The Mobile App: A Seamless Experience for EV Owners ChargeZone‚Äôs mobile app has quietly become one of the most effective EV tools in India.
Here‚Äôs why:
Features that Actually Matter: Real-time charger availability Session start/stop with a single tap Secure payments (UPI, wallets, cards) Charging history and usage reports Push notifications for completion alerts UI That Works for Everyone Whether you‚Äôre a techie or a first-time EV user, the app is intuitive:
Simple layout Easy filter by power type and vehicle compatibility Hindi and regional language support They are also integrating voice assistant features, ideal for on-the-go access.
Partnerships and Collaborations To scale quickly and effectively, ChargeZone has entered several strategic partnerships:
Oil companies (like Indian Oil) for highway installations Vehicle OEMs like Tata Motors and Ashok Leyland State governments for public transport electrification Real estate developers for society and mall installations Fleet and delivery companies for customized depots This partnership-led model allows them to deploy faster, reduce risk, and optimize utilization.
Why ChargeZone Matters in India‚Äôs EV Push India is aiming for 30% of all vehicles to be electric by 2030. But vehicles alone can‚Äôt make that happen.
Without dependable infrastructure:
Range anxiety will slow adoption Fleet operators will face bottlenecks Governments will miss policy targets ChargeZone is solving these problems today‚Äînot five years from now.
They‚Äôre not just building stations; they‚Äôre enabling confidence in electric mobility.
Final Thoughts: A Charging Company That‚Äôs Actually Moving the Needle ChargeZone isn‚Äôt in the news every day. They don‚Äôt spend all their time announcing pilot projects. But in the background, they‚Äôre executing quietly and effectively‚Äîbuilding India‚Äôs electric highway brick by brick.
With a strong technological backbone, a user-first mobile app, and a clearly defined roadmap, ChargeZone is set to be a core pillar of India‚Äôs electric transformation.
If you‚Äôre an EV owner, investor, policymaker, or just someone trying to understand where India‚Äôs transportation future is headed‚ÄîChargeZone is a name you should know.

contents:
Electric vehicles (EVs) are no longer a futuristic concept in India‚Äîthey‚Äôre here, and they‚Äôre gaining ground fast. But ask any EV owner about their biggest challenge, and most won‚Äôt mention battery life or vehicle cost. They‚Äôll say: ‚ÄúWhere do I charge easily, and without burning a hole in my wallet?‚Äù
That‚Äôs exactly the problem Statiq is solving.
While many EV infrastructure companies chase premium installations and highway fast-charging hubs, Statiq is focusing on the real everyday need‚Äîaffordable, reliable EV charging for daily Indian users. This blog is a deep dive into how Statiq is quietly building one of the most user-centric EV charging networks in the country.
Understanding the Problem: EV Adoption vs Charging Realities India is pushing hard on electric mobility. The government is rolling out subsidies. Automakers are launching new EV models every quarter. And sales figures? They‚Äôre climbing.
But EV users in urban and semi-urban areas still face a major pain point‚Äîpractical, affordable charging infrastructure. Most fast-charging stations are expensive and meant for long-distance travel. They aren‚Äôt ideal for daily users who just want to top up during work or shopping hours.
Imagine this: you own a Tata Nexon EV and commute 40‚Äì60 km daily. You don‚Äôt need a ‚Çπ25/kWh charger every day. You need something budget-friendly, nearby, and available when you need it.
That‚Äôs where Statiq shines.
Who Is Statiq? Statiq is a Gurugram-based electric vehicle charging startup founded in 2020 by Akshit Bansal and Raghav Arora. While most companies entered the space with highway fast chargers in mind, Statiq took a different route‚Äîliterally and strategically.
They focused on urban and semi-urban hubs, placing chargers where people live, work, and relax. Their target audience? Not luxury EV users‚Äîbut the growing crowd of everyday EV owners using electric scooters, hatchbacks, and compact SUVs for daily transportation.
Their network today spans across Delhi NCR, Jaipur, Chandigarh, Bhopal, Indore, and several tier 2 and tier 3 cities‚Äîwith thousands of charging points live and more being added every month.
The Vision Behind Statiq‚Äôs Strategy The idea wasn‚Äôt just to build a network‚Äîit was to build one that people would actually use every day.
Statiq asked the most fundamental question that often gets ignored in the EV ecosystem:
‚ÄúHow do we make charging affordable and accessible for regular users?‚Äù
Their answer:
Place chargers in everyday locations: apartments, offices, cafes, malls, and hospitals. Offer both AC and DC chargers, depending on use case and budget. Keep charging rates affordable‚Äîeven if that means slower charging. Build a seamless app experience so users don‚Äôt waste time hunting for available chargers. Partner with local authorities, RWAs, and businesses to integrate chargers naturally into city life. The Cost Factor: Why Statiq is India‚Äôs Most Affordable Charging Option Let‚Äôs get into what matters most to users‚Äîmoney.
In most Indian cities, the cost of charging an EV at a fast-charging station can range between ‚Çπ20‚Äì‚Çπ30 per kWh. This works out to ‚Çπ600‚Äì‚Çπ900 for a full charge for a vehicle like the Tata Nexon EV (30 kWh battery).
Statiq, in contrast, offers:
AC charging at ‚Çπ12‚Äì‚Çπ18 per kWh DC charging at ‚Çπ18‚Äì‚Çπ22 per kWh in selected locations So instead of paying ‚Çπ800 to fully charge your EV, you might end up paying ‚Çπ350‚Äì‚Çπ500 using Statiq. That‚Äôs a 40‚Äì60% saving, and for users who charge multiple times a week, the monthly savings are significant.
If you‚Äôre running an electric scooter like the Ather 450X or Ola S1, the cost per charge is often under ‚Çπ50.
Statiq‚Äôs App Experience: Charging Made Effortless The Statiq mobile app is not just functional‚Äîit‚Äôs intuitive.
Many EV users avoid public charging because they don‚Äôt know which stations are available, how much they‚Äôll be charged, or whether the plug will even work. Statiq addresses all of this with a simple, well-designed app.
Key features of the Statiq App:
Real-time charger availability: No guesswork. Slot reservation: Book your time in advance. Transparent pricing: See cost per kWh before charging. Multiple payment options: UPI, Paytm, Credit Card, Wallets. Charging progress tracker: Know how long until your battery is full. Billing history: View your past sessions and costs. It turns what could be a frustrating experience into a no-hassle routine.
Where Are Statiq Charging Stations Located? As of 2025, Statiq has more than 7,000 charging points across India, with a strong concentration in the northern and central regions.
Some key locations include:
Delhi NCR: Gurugram, Noida, Faridabad, South Delhi, East Delhi Chandigarh & Mohali: In partnership with municipal bodies Jaipur & Udaipur: Located in malls, hospitals, and cafes Bhopal, Indore, and Gwalior: With support from local RWAs and city authorities Pune, Ahmedabad, Bengaluru (pilot): Rapid expansion underway Each of these locations features a mix of AC and DC chargers, with clear markings and proper signage. Many are powered by solar grids, especially in Tier 2 city deployments.
Hardware Overview: Types of EV Chargers by Statiq Statiq provides a wide range of EV chargers to suit different vehicles and needs.
1. AC Chargers (3.3‚Äì22 kW)
Perfect for overnight or slow day-time charging Installed in apartments, malls, offices Ideal for two-wheelers and private cars Very low cost per unit Safe and stable for Indian power grids 2. DC Fast Chargers (30 kW, 60 kW)
Found in commercial hubs and key public zones Suitable for fleet vehicles, taxis, and highway stops Charge from 20% to 80% in 30‚Äì45 minutes Slightly more expensive than AC but still affordable 3. Bharat Standard Chargers (AC-001 & DC-001)
Compatible with most Indian EVs Government-supported specs Best suited for electric autos and small cars 4. Upcoming
Statiq is testing Level 2 smart chargers with dynamic load management and remote support Battery swapping solutions are in pilot phase for two-wheelers and small fleets Partnerships and Alliances: Building at Scale One reason Statiq has grown so fast is its ability to form strategic partnerships.
Notable collaborations include:
Hero Electric: Statiq stations support Hero‚Äôs entire scooter range, including dedicated charging bays in metro cities. Hyundai India: Chargers deployed at Hyundai showrooms and service stations for test drives and new EV buyers. Lemon Tree Hotels: Guests can charge overnight while staying. Stations listed on Statiq‚Äôs app. Government Bodies: State transport departments in MP, Rajasthan, and UP have partnered for EV policy support. Real Estate Developers: Statiq installs society-based chargers in DLF, ATS, and Omaxe residential townships. These partnerships make Statiq‚Äôs deployment organic and embedded in real infrastructure, not just bolted on.
Statiq for Residential Societies and Commercial Buildings Statiq doesn‚Äôt just build public chargers. They also work closely with:
RWAs (Resident Welfare Associations) Corporate parks Tech campuses Retail outlets For apartment societies, Statiq offers shared AC chargers with RFID access, billing management, and 24√ó7 tech support. For offices, they provide custom EV zones for employees and visitors.
For shop owners and gyms, Statiq brings in EV foot traffic and revenue via pay-per-use charging. It‚Äôs a win-win.
Real-World User Stories Ajay Mehra, 38, Delhi NCR
‚ÄúI use my MG Comet for office commutes. There‚Äôs a Statiq charger outside my office building. Costs me less than ‚Çπ500 a month to run the car. Can‚Äôt think of going back to petrol.‚Äù Deepika Sharma, 26, Chandigarh
‚ÄúAs a food delivery partner on an Ola S1, Statiq makes my life easy. I charge while having lunch. It‚Äôs reliable and safe‚Äîsomething you really need when working late hours.‚Äù Nikhil Joshi, 45, Indore
‚ÄúOur RWA got Statiq installed in the basement. Everyone from our block now uses EVs. It’s like we have our own petrol pump at home.‚Äù Environmental Impact and Clean Energy Focus Statiq is not just solving an infrastructure problem‚Äîit‚Äôs contributing to India‚Äôs clean energy mission.
Here‚Äôs how:
Solar Integration: Many stations, especially in Tier 2 cities, are powered by rooftop solar. Smart Load Management: Prevents power surges during peak hours. DISCOM Collaboration: Charging stations aligned with state grid guidelines. Carbon Offset Tools (Upcoming): Statiq plans to allow users to track and offset their carbon savings from EV usage. Roadmap: Statiq‚Äôs Growth Plan (2025‚Äì2030) Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs next for Statiq in their journey to dominate EV charging in India:
2025: Expand to 10 new cities in South India and 5 more in the Northeast. Launch subscription-based charging plans for frequent users. 2026: Launch battery-swapping pilot programs for two-wheelers. 2027: Integrate charging APIs with Google Maps and EV dashboards in Ola, Ather, and Tata EVs. 2028: Build 500 solar-powered EV zones in tier 2 and 3 towns. 2030: Reach 100,000 public charging points and 25,000 private installations across India. Final Word: Why Statiq Deserves Your Attention If you‚Äôre one of the lakhs of Indians who use their EVs not for adventure or long highway drives‚Äîbut for your daily city life‚Äîthen Statiq may be the best charging network out there for you.
It‚Äôs not about bells and whistles. It‚Äôs about affordability, availability, and trust.
Statiq understands Indian EV users. They know the challenges we face with charging. And they‚Äôre building a network not just for the rich or the early adopters‚Äîbut for the everyday Indian who chooses to go electric.
If you haven‚Äôt tried Statiq yet, this is your sign. Download the app, find a nearby charger, and plug into India‚Äôs most practical EV charging solution.

When we talk about electric mobility in India, the spotlight usually shines on big players like Tata Power, ChargeZone, and Ather Grid. But every now and then, a local company rises from the grassroots, not only to compete with these giants but to offer solutions that truly understand the pulse of the region. One such name that‚Äôs steadily gaining recognition across South India ‚Äî particularly in Tamil Nadu ‚Äî is Relux Electric.
From its humble beginnings to becoming one of the fastest-growing EV charging infrastructure providers in South India, Relux Electric is a story worth telling. It‚Äôs not just about EV charging. It‚Äôs about empowerment, decentralization, and reshaping how people travel across towns, highways, and cities in Tamil Nadu.
From a Regional Idea to a Statewide Movement Relux Electric wasn‚Äôt founded in the boardrooms of metropolitan cities. It was born in Tamil Nadu ‚Äî a state with a proud tradition of embracing technology, sustainable practices, and homegrown entrepreneurship. The founding team, made up of engineers and infrastructure experts, noticed a pattern that others ignored ‚Äî EV adoption was growing not just in cities like Chennai and Coimbatore but also in towns like Madurai, Salem, and Tirunelveli.
Yet, these areas had little to no public EV infrastructure. No chargers at rest stops, no apps to locate charging points, no roadside help if a battery drained mid-journey. That‚Äôs where Relux came in.
From day one, their goal was clear: Make EV charging available and affordable across all of Tamil Nadu, especially in places where others wouldn‚Äôt bother going.
Understanding the Relux Approach Most EV charging startups have focused on big-ticket partnerships, glitzy locations, and metro cities. Relux did the opposite. They focused on:
Partnering with local petrol bunks, community halls, schools, colleges, and small hotels. Building chargers in semi-urban and rural districts. Offering Tamil-language customer support and an app interface. Training local electricians and workers to install and service stations. This approach didn‚Äôt just help Relux scale quickly ‚Äî it built trust. A trust that‚Äôs visible today in the number of EV drivers who swear by their services in towns where no other charger exists.
Charging Infrastructure: How Big Is Relux‚Äôs Network? As of 2025, Relux operates over 150 electric vehicle charging stations across Tamil Nadu and has begun expanding into neighboring states like Karnataka and Kerala. Their presence spans:
Highways: You‚Äôll find Relux chargers on NH-44, NH-32, NH-79, and other major roadways. Cities and Towns: Chennai, Coimbatore, Madurai, Trichy, Erode, Salem, Nagercoil, Vellore, and over 30 Tier-2/3 towns. Strategic Public Spaces: Railway stations, tourist spots, shopping centers, and religious pilgrimage centers. Apartments and Commercial Buildings: Installation services are offered through B2B partnerships. They provide both fast and slow chargers including AC chargers (3.3kW‚Äì7.2kW) and DC fast chargers (15kW‚Äì60kW). These cater to two-wheelers, e-rickshaws, passenger EVs, and even electric buses.
Relux‚Äôs Product Ecosystem: Not Just Chargers Relux has quietly built a solid product and service ecosystem that supports end-to-end EV adoption.
Public electric vehicle Charging Stations Their primary offering remains well-positioned electric vehicle charging stations. Each station has 2 to 6 chargers and includes:
Dual connectors to support different car types Safety features for surge protection Real-time monitoring and remote diagnosis On-ground service teams in every district Residential and Fleet Charging Relux offers charger installation at homes and fleet depots. This includes:
Site inspection Electrical load assessment Installation by trained technicians AMC (Annual Maintenance Contracts) EV Charging App Their app (available on both Android and iOS) allows users to:
Locate nearby chargers View real-time status of each charging point Reserve a slot Pay via UPI, debit/credit card, wallets Access user history and reports The app is available in English and Tamil, catering directly to the state‚Äôs core population.
Solar Hybrid Stations Some of Relux‚Äôs newer stations integrate solar energy, especially in towns that face frequent power cuts. This reduces operational costs and promotes green energy at the source.
Strategic Expansion and Partnerships Relux didn‚Äôt scale on its own. It formed partnerships that made expansion smoother and smarter.
Petrol Pump Alliances: Agreements with Bharat Petroleum and Indian Oil retailers allowed them to install chargers at pump locations. Real Estate Developers: Tie-ups with gated communities and apartment complexes brought in residential users. Tamil Nadu Transport Corporation: Pilot charging infrastructure for electric buses. Educational Institutions: Installed EV chargers in over 50 colleges and universities. Tourist Boards: Chargers deployed at hill stations, beach resorts, and pilgrimage destinations like Rameswaram and Kanchipuram. Their success also owes a lot to the Tamil Nadu state EV policy, which offers subsidies, single-window approvals, and incentives for green infrastructure. Relux took full advantage of these schemes, especially to set up in smaller municipalities and panchayats.
Unique Features That Make Relux Stand Out Unlike national players that try to apply a one-size-fits-all strategy, Relux customizes its approach based on the locality:
Tamil-First Customer Service
Every call center employee speaks fluent Tamil and understands regional dialects. Price-Per-Minute Charging
Instead of per-kWh, many Relux stations use a time-based model to simplify pricing. Franchisee Model
Local entrepreneurs can run their own Relux station under guidance ‚Äî helping create jobs and grow income in Tier-3 towns. Mobile Charging Vans
Introduced in Coimbatore, these EV vans help stranded vehicles on highways. They‚Äôre equipped with 15kWh battery packs. Educational Drives
Relux frequently hosts community EV awareness programs in temples, schools, and panchayats. Real Impact on the Ground: Customer Testimonials Case 1: A Solo Trip Across Tamil Nadu Arun Prasad, a travel vlogger from Chennai, completed a 900 km round trip covering Pondicherry, Thanjavur, Kodaikanal, and Dindigul ‚Äî charging only at Relux stations. His review?
‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think a local company could give me such peace of mind. The stations were clean, well-lit, and working every time I reached. That‚Äôs all I need.‚Äù Case 2: Women‚Äôs Self-Help Group in Karur A group of women running an e-rickshaw service now saves over ‚Çπ7,000/month by charging at Relux‚Äôs subsidised EV station near the textile market.
Case 3: College Campus Charging in Namakkal A private college installed a Relux 7.2kW charger in its parking lot. Now faculty and students use it daily ‚Äî building a new generation of EV users.
Comparing Relux with Bigger Names Relux may not yet have the national visibility of Tata Power or Statiq, but it holds its own in many key areas:
Category <th> Relux Electric </th> <th> Statiq </th> <th> ChargeZone </th> <th> Tata Power </th> Headquarters <td> Tamil Nadu </td> <td> Delhi NCR </td> <td> Gujarat </td> <td> Mumbai </td> Focus Region <td> South India </td> <td> Pan India </td> <td> Highways </td> <td> Metro Cities </td> Language Support <td> English + Tamil </td> <td> English </td> <td> English </td> <td> English </td> Local Partnerships <td> Yes </td> <td> Moderate </td> <td> High </td> <td> Moderate </td> Mobile Vans <td> Yes </td> <td> No </td> <td> No </td> <td> Limited </td> Solar Stations <td> Yes </td> <td> No </td> <td> Yes </td> <td> Yes </td> EV Training <td> Yes </td> <td> No </td> <td> No </td> <td> No </td> Where Relux wins is in hyper-localization, grassroots awareness, and reliability. Many EV owners report fewer failures and better uptime on Relux stations compared to competitors.
Roadmap: What‚Äôs Coming in 2025 and Beyond Relux has big plans for the future, and their team has been transparent about upcoming milestones.
300+ electric vehicle charging stations across South India by 2026 Solar-powered hubs in at least 100 villages EV fleet depot solutions for last-mile delivery companies R&D into battery swapping stations for electric two-wheelers Relux Academy: A vocational training program to train electricians and mechanics in EV support Mobile chargers in all major TN districts Integration with navigation apps like Google Maps and MapMyIndia Their goal is not just to install chargers but to build a full EV ecosystem that supports both urban and rural EV growth in India.
Final Thoughts: Relux Is the EV Backbone South India Deserves The electric revolution in India is happening ‚Äî but not evenly. While metro cities enjoy the benefits of early infrastructure and investment, towns and highways are often left behind.
Relux Electric is bridging that gap. Not with billion-dollar backing or flashy PR campaigns, but with simple, meaningful work rooted in Tamil Nadu‚Äôs communities, values, and needs.
Whether you‚Äôre riding a two-wheeler in Karur, driving a Nexon EV from Salem to Trichy, or planning a road trip from Madurai to Kanyakumari ‚Äî chances are, a Relux charger is part of your journey.
That‚Äôs what makes them a hero ‚Äî quiet, committed, and always moving forward.

When we talk about the electric vehicle (EV) revolution in India, names like Tata Power, ChargeZone, and Statiq often dominate the conversation. But quietly and consistently, Magenta ChargeGrid has carved out its own space‚Äînot by copying global models, but by building an EV charging ecosystem that‚Äôs proudly Indian, solar-integrated, and designed for scalability.
In this blog, let‚Äôs take a deep dive into the story of Magenta, explore how it started, what makes it different, where it‚Äôs headed, and how it compares with other players in the market. This is a story of clean energy, innovation, and what happens when you combine vision with local insight.
The Beginning: From a Vision to India‚Äôs EV Infrastructure Pioneer Magenta ChargeGrid wasn‚Äôt born in a boardroom‚Äîit started in a small setup in Navi Mumbai in 2017, led by Maxson Lewis, a former energy sector executive. At the time, EVs were barely registering in the Indian automotive space. Charging stations were almost non-existent. Most companies were watching and waiting.
But Maxson and his co-founders weren‚Äôt interested in waiting.
They understood that if India wanted to transition to EVs, the groundwork needed to be laid early. And that groundwork was charging infrastructure‚Äîbut not just any infrastructure. Magenta aimed to develop a Made-in-India, solar-powered, smart EV charging network.
The idea was simple but powerful: make EV charging not just accessible, but sustainable and Indian by design.
What is Magenta ChargeGrid? Magenta ChargeGrid is the EV charging arm of Magenta Power, a larger entity focused on clean energy solutions. Under this umbrella, ChargeGrid emerged as a full-stack EV charging company.
What does that mean?
It means Magenta doesn‚Äôt just install chargers‚Äîthey:
Design and manufacture chargers in India Build the software platforms to manage them Develop mobile apps for users Integrate solar energy into the charging network Offer turnkey solutions for commercial, residential, and public use So, while many companies focus only on hardware or software, Magenta offers an end-to-end ecosystem‚Äîa key advantage in a complex market like India.
Early Days: Challenges and First Wins Back in 2018 and 2019, Magenta‚Äôs biggest challenge wasn‚Äôt building chargers‚Äîit was convincing stakeholders to believe in EVs.
From housing societies to malls, from government officials to real estate developers, the skepticism was everywhere: ‚ÄúWill EVs even come to India in a big way?‚Äù
Magenta took a leap of faith. They deployed their early charging stations in Navi Mumbai and Bengaluru, targeting forward-thinking customers. One of their first high-profile collaborations was with HPCL to install solar-integrated chargers at fuel stations‚Äîan early step that helped them gain visibility.
Their approach worked: small but consistent wins helped them build credibility, and slowly, clients started coming to them instead of the other way around.
What Does Magenta ChargeGrid Offer Today? Fast forward to now, Magenta ChargeGrid has a diverse product portfolio designed to serve multiple segments of the EV ecosystem.
Here‚Äôs a closer look at what they offer:
1. AC and DC Public Chargers These are installed at malls, fuel stations, and office parks. They support both Type 2 AC and CCS/CHAdeMO DC fast charging standards.
2. Residential Charging Solutions Magenta provides compact chargers for apartment complexes and individual homes. These units are Wi-Fi enabled and can be monitored via app.
3. Fleet Charging Hubs Built for commercial fleet operators, these hubs offer multiple high-speed chargers, often integrated with solar power. Fleet companies like BigBasket and Amazon have already partnered with Magenta for EV logistics.
4. Pole-Mounted Charging Stations (ChargeGrid Flare) Perhaps one of their most unique innovations, the ChargeGrid Flare is designed to be mounted on existing streetlight poles. It reduces the cost of civil infrastructure and makes urban EV charging scalable.
5. Mobile App and Platform The ChargeGrid app allows users to:
Locate chargers Reserve time slots Pay digitally via UPI and wallets Monitor usage and history Rate charging locations This app integrates with their backend ChargeGrid CMS, used by admins to manage the entire network.
Where Can You Find Magenta ChargeGrid in India? Magenta has deployed over 1,200+ chargers across 20+ cities.
Some major locations include:
Mumbai Pune Bengaluru Chennai Hyderabad Delhi NCR Goa Nagpur Coimbatore Noida They‚Äôve also been working on highway charging corridors, notably the Mumbai‚ÄìPune Expressway, where ChargeGrid stations are being installed every 50-60 km.
This push toward intercity travel is part of their 2025 vision‚Äîto enable long-distance EV travel without range anxiety.
Real-World Example: Charging at Seawoods Mall, Navi Mumbai Let‚Äôs take a real-world scenario.
You‚Äôre shopping at Seawoods Grand Central Mall in Navi Mumbai. Your EV battery is low. Instead of hunting for a charging point elsewhere, you plug into a Magenta ChargeGrid station in the parking lot.
By the time you‚Äôre done with your shopping and coffee break, your vehicle is ready.
That‚Äôs the kind of user-friendly experience Magenta is building‚Äîseamless, intuitive, and integrated into your daily life.
Unique Technology: What Makes ChargeGrid Different? There are plenty of EV charging providers now. But here‚Äôs how Magenta stands out in terms of technology:
1. Solar Integration Magenta‚Äôs parent company started with solar solutions, and that DNA is embedded into ChargeGrid. Many of their chargers, especially in rural areas, are powered by rooftop solar or solar canopies, reducing carbon footprint significantly.
2. Smart Load Management Their software ensures that charging load is distributed across stations to prevent grid stress. This is crucial in high-usage areas like commercial hubs.
3. OCPP-Compliant Backend Open Charge Point Protocol (OCPP) compatibility allows interoperability. This means you can plug in a Tata EV, BYD, or even an international model‚ÄîMagenta‚Äôs system adapts.
4. Data-Driven Decisions Through its CMS, Magenta tracks usage patterns, charger health, and real-time analytics, which helps in proactive maintenance and capacity planning.
Expansion Beyond EVs: Battery Swapping & Microgrids Magenta isn‚Äôt stopping at fixed charging. They are actively piloting battery swapping stations for electric rickshaws in Uttar Pradesh and Bihar‚Äîregions where e-rickshaws dominate local transport but don‚Äôt have stable charging access.
These swap stations allow drivers to change batteries in under five minutes, increasing productivity and uptime.
They‚Äôre also integrating microgrids in remote areas. This means a combination of solar panels, battery storage, and chargers‚Äîan independent, clean power system for EVs in locations with unreliable electricity.
Magenta‚Äôs Roadmap: What‚Äôs Coming Between 2025‚Äì2030? Magenta‚Äôs growth plan is ambitious and grounded in India‚Äôs EV needs.
By 2025: 2,500+ chargers across India Launch in 2 ASEAN countries (likely Vietnam and Sri Lanka) 30+ fleet partnerships with e-commerce and logistics brands 100+ solar-integrated public charging hubs By 2030: 11,000+ chargers deployed 150+ cities covered 25% of network solar-powered Battery swapping stations in 100+ towns They‚Äôre also investing in R&D and manufacturing capacity, building a new factory in Maharashtra to scale up production of indigenous EV chargers.
Funding and Strategic Partners Magenta has raised multiple rounds of funding. Some of their backers include:
Hindustan Petroleum (HPCL) Microsoft Startup Program Indian Angel Network Government of India‚Äôs Startup India initiative These partnerships give Magenta a solid foundation‚Äînot just in terms of capital, but also in operational expertise and distribution.
Comparison with Competitors: Where Does Magenta Stand? Let‚Äôs break it down with a few key players:
Feature <th> Magenta ChargeGrid </th> <th> ChargeZone </th> <th> Statiq </th> <th> Tata Power EZ </th> Founded <td> 2017 </td> <td> 2018 </td> <td> 2020 </td> <td> Legacy (2017 EV ops) </td> Solar Integration <td> ‚úÖ Yes </td> <td> ‚ùå No </td> <td> ‚ùå Limited </td> <td> ‚ùå Limited </td> Fleet Services <td> ‚úÖ Yes </td> <td> ‚úÖ Yes </td> <td> ‚úÖ Yes </td> <td> ‚úÖ Yes </td> Battery Swapping <td> ‚úÖ Pilot Projects </td> <td> ‚ùå </td> <td> ‚ùå </td> <td> ‚ùå </td> Intercity Coverage <td> Growing </td> <td> Strong </td> <td> Moderate </td> <td> Strong </td> In-house Manufacturing <td> ‚úÖ Yes </td> <td> ‚ùå </td> <td> ‚ùå </td> <td> ‚úÖ Limited </td> Price Range <td> Competitive </td> <td> Premium </td> <td> Budget </td> <td> Mid-range </td> Magenta clearly holds an edge in solar-first deployment, battery swapping, and custom Indian manufacturing. While it may not have the nationwide scale of Tata Power yet, it‚Äôs building depth where others go for breadth.
Challenges Ahead Like any startup in the EV space, Magenta faces its share of hurdles:
High capital expenditure for charger deployment State-level EV policies are inconsistent Land and grid permissions take time Competing with heavily funded players But their strength lies in adaptability and local focus. While others go after flashy highway stations, Magenta‚Äôs focus on housing societies, fleet depots, and tier-2 cities might just give them the long-term edge.
Final Thoughts: Why Magenta ChargeGrid Matters Magenta ChargeGrid is more than just another EV charging company. It represents a different kind of thinking‚Äîclean energy first, Indian-made, scalable by design.
They‚Äôve shown that you don‚Äôt need to import ideas to build great infrastructure. You can create it locally, using local materials, solving local problems.
So, the next time you see a ChargeGrid station at your mall, office, or even a rural highway stop, remember‚Äîyou‚Äôre not just plugging in your EV. You‚Äôre plugging into an ecosystem built for India, by India.
title: Magenta ChargeGrid: India‚Äôs Renewable EV Charging Pioneer with Solar-First Infrastructure and Scalable Growth Vision

When we think about electric vehicles (EVs) in India, Ather Energy is one of the first names that comes to mind. From launching some of the smartest electric scooters to setting up a city-wide charging network called Ather Grid, this Bengaluru-based company has been a true pioneer.
But what exactly is Ather Grid? How does it work? Is it only for Ather scooters? And more importantly, how is it shaping the EV ecosystem in India?
Let‚Äôs break it all down in this detailed guide, built from real-world insights, user experiences, and everything you need to know if you own‚Äîor plan to own‚Äîan EV in India.
What is Ather Grid? Ather Grid is Ather Energy‚Äôs public charging network for electric vehicles. It is designed to provide fast, accessible, and smart charging options for Ather scooters and other EVs across major Indian cities.
Launched: 2018 Cities Covered (as of 2025): 150+ cities Charging Points: Over 2,000 fast chargers and growing Availability: Open 24/7, most installed at malls, cafes, tech parks, fuel stations, and public places Unlike traditional electric vehicle charging stations, Ather Grid chargers are designed to blend into urban infrastructure and provide real-time updates through the Ather app.
Ather‚Äôs Vision Behind Building the Grid From the beginning, Ather Energy understood that selling electric scooters without solving the charging problem would limit adoption.
Their co-founders, Tarun Mehta and Swapnil Jain, saw the future of EV adoption being tied closely to a reliable charging ecosystem. So instead of waiting for government infrastructure, they built their own.
Key goals of Ather Grid:
Make charging as easy and accessible as buying petrol Remove ‚Äúrange anxiety‚Äù from the minds of users Encourage the shift to electric mobility even in Tier-2 and Tier-3 cities Set a benchmark for charging experience in India Where Can You Find Ather Grid Chargers? You‚Äôll find Ather Grid chargers installed at:
Coffee shops like Third Wave Coffee, Starbucks Malls such as Phoenix Market City, VR Mall, Lulu Mall Restaurants and hotels Tech parks and co-working spaces BPCL and HP petrol bunks Local service hubs and experience centers They are mostly installed in locations where people naturally spend 30 minutes to 2 hours‚Äîmaking it ideal for fast charging during errands or downtime.
Pro Tip: You can find the exact location of each charger using the Ather App, which shows availability in real-time.
How Fast is Ather Grid Charging? Ather Grid supports fast charging up to 1.5 km per minute, depending on your scooter model.
For Ather 450X:
0 to 80%: ~45 minutes on Ather Grid Full charge: ~60‚Äì75 minutes depending on external conditions This kind of speed ensures that users can get a quick top-up even if they stop by for just a coffee.
Note: Non-Ather vehicles can also use the Grid if compatible, though charging speed may vary.
Is Ather Grid Free or Paid? Ather initially offered free charging at Ather Grid for early adopters. However, starting 2023, they have moved towards a pay-per-use model.
Pricing as of 2025:
‚Çπ1.5 ‚Äì ‚Çπ2.5 per minute for non-Ather vehicles Ather scooters get preferential pricing via Ather subscription plans Ather One & Ather Connect users may get complimentary hours The pricing is still competitive and cheaper than petrol.
Ather Grid App: A Smart Charging Companion The Ather App is more than just a tool to check battery levels. It‚Äôs an integral part of the Grid experience.
App features:
Real-time charger availability Start/stop charging remotely Charging session analytics Navigation to nearest Ather Grid station QR-based authentication for secure charging This app-centered approach makes the experience smoother and user-friendly‚Äîespecially compared to traditional charging setups.
Ather Grid‚Äôs Expansion Strategy: City by City Ather Energy has taken a strategic, city-focused rollout for Ather Grid. Instead of spreading too thin, they first saturate Tier-1 cities like:
Bengaluru Chennai Pune Hyderabad Delhi NCR Mumbai Once the density is strong, they move into:
Tier-2 cities like Coimbatore, Ahmedabad, Jaipur Tier-3 regions including pilgrimage towns, remote suburbs, and highways This hub-and-spoke model ensures that no user is ever too far from a charger.
Real-life Example: In Coimbatore, Ather Grid added over 50 chargers in just 6 months to support growing scooter adoption and dealership expansion.
Is Ather Grid Open to All EVs? Initially, Ather Grid was built for Ather scooters, but today, the network supports a broader range of EVs.
Compatibility:
Ather 450X, 450 Plus (native support) Hero Vida, TVS iQube (limited support) Ola S1 Pro, Bounce Infinity (some chargers support via Type-1 or CCS1 adaptors) Ather is also pushing for standardization of connectors, working with industry bodies to ensure smoother interoperability in the future.
How Ather Grid Stands Out from Competitors Let‚Äôs compare Ather Grid with other players in the Indian EV charging space:
Feature <th> Ather Grid </th> <th> Statiq </th> <th> ChargeZone </th> <th> Tata EZ Charge </th> Main Use Case <td> 2-wheeler fast charging </td> <td> Public + B2B </td> <td> Long route charging </td> <td> Home & commercial </td> App Experience <td> Highly integrated </td> <td> Good </td> <td> Decent </td> <td> Moderate </td> Availability in Cities <td> 150+ </td> <td> 60+ </td> <td> 25+ </td> <td> 100+ </td> Compatibility <td> Limited </td> <td> Broad </td> <td> Broad </td> <td> Broad </td> Reliability <td> High </td> <td> Moderate </td> <td> High </td> <td> High </td> Ather Grid wins in urban usability, especially for two-wheeler users.
User Experience & Real-World Feedback Case 1 ‚Äì The Daily Commuter (Bengaluru) Ajay, a software developer, uses his Ather 450X for daily commute. He charges once every 2‚Äì3 days at a caf√© near his home.
“The best part is I don‚Äôt have to wait in line. I book it from the app, grab a coffee, and come back in 30 minutes with 60% battery.” Case 2 ‚Äì EV Explorer (Hyderabad) Priya travels frequently within Hyderabad. She uses Ather Grid located in Phoenix Gachibowli.
“It‚Äôs available even at night. That alone makes me prefer Ather over any other scooter brand.” These stories show that the Grid doesn‚Äôt just solve a technical problem‚Äîit enables a lifestyle.
Challenges Ather Grid Faces While Ather Grid has been successful, it‚Äôs not without its hurdles.
High Cost of Deployment: Each charger setup costs ‚Çπ2‚Äì5 lakhs, including site lease and electricity infra. Grid Overload in Popular Locations: During peak hours, some users report wait times. Non-standard Connectors: Limits adoption across multiple EV brands. Electricity Supply Reliability: In some regions, outages affect uptime. Ather is actively addressing these by:
Partnering with local vendors for solar + battery backup Upgrading popular sites with multiple chargers Pushing for connector standardization via BIS & Niti Aayog Ather Grid‚Äôs Role in India‚Äôs EV Push India‚Äôs EV adoption is tightly linked to infrastructure. With initiatives like FAME II and state-level EV policies, the pressure is on both government and private players to build networks.
Ather Grid serves as a model of what private EV infrastructure can look like‚Äîdata-driven, user-first, and scalable.
In fact, several states like Tamil Nadu and Karnataka have used Ather‚Äôs grid rollout as a case study while drafting their EV policies.
The Road Ahead: What‚Äôs Coming Next? Here‚Äôs what we know about Ather Grid‚Äôs 2025‚Äì2030 roadmap:
Expansion to 5000+ chargers across 300+ cities Integration with highways to enable inter-city EV travel Dynamic pricing based on grid load & time of day Cross-brand partnerships for better compatibility Ather Grid 3.0 ‚Äì with solar-powered smart chargers, faster top-up, and AI-based load management By 2030, Ather wants to be the backbone for 2-wheeler EV infrastructure in India‚Äînot just a scooter company.
Final Thoughts: Why Ather Grid Matters Ather Grid is not just a utility‚Äîit‚Äôs a key enabler of electric mobility in urban India.
By combining smart hardware, a seamless app, and thoughtful placement of chargers, Ather Energy has created something truly user-centric.
Whether you‚Äôre an Ather owner, planning to switch to an EV, or just curious about the EV ecosystem‚ÄîAther Grid is a success story worth watching.

Introduction: India‚Äôs EV Push Needs Smart Charging India‚Äôs electric vehicle revolution is in full swing. From two-wheelers buzzing through traffic to electric buses gliding on city routes, the shift is unmistakable. But one major roadblock remains: reliable and accessible EV charging. That‚Äôs where ElectricPe steps in, aiming to change how India charges its electric vehicles‚Äîmaking it faster, smarter, and more affordable.
If you‚Äôre an EV owner or just considering the switch, this blog will give you a complete understanding of how ElectricPe is shaping the future of e-mobility in India.
Who Is ElectricPe? ‚Äì The Brand Behind the Buzz Founded in 2021, ElectricPe is a Bengaluru-based EV charging platform on a mission to make clean mobility accessible to every Indian. Their approach is straightforward but ambitious: build the country‚Äôs largest and most reliable EV charging network by collaborating with existing infrastructure owners, like kirana stores, malls, apartments, fuel stations, and commercial complexes.
The company doesn‚Äôt believe in owning and building massive infrastructure from scratch. Instead, they smartly aggregate and digitize already existing power sources and locations‚Äîmaking them accessible to the EV public through one easy-to-use platform.
Founders‚Äô Vision and Company Background ElectricPe was co-founded by Avinash Sharma (former Ola and Bounce exec) and Rakesh Sharma, with deep expertise in mobility, logistics, and energy. Their vision was clear: most Indians won‚Äôt switch to electric unless charging becomes as easy as filling petrol. They aimed to bridge the ‚Äúlast-mile‚Äù charging gap for urban EV users.
Under their leadership, ElectricPe has grown from a pilot project in Bangalore to a multi-city smart charging ecosystem trusted by thousands of EV riders.
Why ElectricPe Stands Out in India‚Äôs EV Landscape ElectricPe is not just another charging company. It‚Äôs building a software-first solution that makes EV charging:
Frictionless ‚Äì Book, unlock, and pay for charging‚Äîall through one app. Affordable ‚Äì Dynamic pricing models ensure low cost for consumers. Distributed ‚Äì Chargers are available not just at malls, but also in your street‚Äôs tea shop or apartment basement. Data-Driven ‚Äì Usage insights help optimize availability, pricing, and grid load. This asset-light model means faster scaling and wider reach‚Äîespecially in urban India where space is a constraint.
The ElectricPe App ‚Äì How It Works and What It Offers At the heart of ElectricPe‚Äôs solution is its mobile app, available on Android and iOS. Here‚Äôs what the app offers:
Live Map of Nearby Electric Vehicle Charging Stations
Whether you’re in Bengaluru, Delhi, or Mumbai, just open the app and see all available Electric Vehicle Charging Stations with real-time availability. Station Booking & Access
You can pre-book charging slots or simply walk-in and scan the QR code at the station. Cashless Payment Options
UPI, credit/debit cards, wallets‚Äîeverything is integrated. Charging Analytics
Track your vehicle‚Äôs charging sessions, cost per kWh, and energy usage patterns. In-App Support & Feedback
Raise tickets, rate stations, and view live updates from the ElectricPe team. Types of Chargers and Station Categories ElectricPe supports various EV types‚Äîtwo-wheelers, three-wheelers, and even cars. Here‚Äôs what you‚Äôll find at different ElectricPe stations:
Charger Type <th> Supported Vehicles </th> <th> Average Charging Time </th> Level 1 (AC) <td> E-scooters, E-bikes </td> <td> 3‚Äì5 hours </td> Level 2 (AC) <td> E-rickshaws, EV cars </td> <td> 2‚Äì4 hours </td> DC Fast <td> Premium EVs, taxis </td> <td> 30‚Äì90 minutes </td> They prioritize smart metering and power efficiency, ensuring energy consumption is logged accurately and billed fairly.
Where Is ElectricPe Available? ‚Äì Current Network Map As of mid-2025, ElectricPe has over 15,000 charging points across India. Their strongest presence is in:
Bangalore Delhi NCR Mumbai Hyderabad Pune Chennai They are rapidly expanding into Tier-2 cities like Jaipur, Indore, Lucknow, and Coimbatore through strategic local partnerships.
Partnerships and Collaborations ‚Äì A Big Force Behind Their Growth ElectricPe‚Äôs biggest strength lies in its partnerships. These include:
Smart parking operators ‚Äì Integrating chargers within parking lots. Housing societies ‚Äì Private EV parking solutions. Retail chains ‚Äì electric vehicle Charging stations at stores like Reliance Fresh and Spencer‚Äôs. Battery swapping firms ‚Äì Interlinking infrastructure for e-rickshaws. In 2024, ElectricPe also announced a partnership with Indian Railways, installing electric vehicle charging stations at select railway parking zones.
Smart Charging & Load Management ‚Äì What Makes ElectricPe Tech-Savvy ElectricPe uses AI-based load balancing to avoid grid overload during peak hours. Their backend systems analyze:
Local energy demand Charger availability Real-time user density This enables smart energy distribution, reduced power loss, and better uptime, even in high-demand areas like IT parks or residential societies.
Sustainability Goals ‚Äì Green Charging & Grid Optimization ElectricPe is committed to India‚Äôs net-zero goals. They integrate:
Solar-powered stations in Tier-1 locations Green energy sourcing partnerships with renewable providers Smart energy dashboards for housing societies to monitor carbon impact Their goal is to ensure 60% of all charging on their network is powered by renewables by 2027.
Pricing, Plans, and User Benefits Unlike others, ElectricPe doesn‚Äôt have a one-size-fits-all model. They offer:
Pay-per-use (‚Çπ3.5‚Äì‚Çπ5 per kWh) Monthly charging plans (‚Çπ499‚Äì‚Çπ1499) Bulk subscription for fleet operators Users benefit from:
Loyalty rewards First 5 charges free on sign-up Referral bonuses Fleet operators get dashboard access to monitor usage, billing, and savings.
User Experience ‚Äì Real Feedback from Daily EV Users Here‚Äôs what some daily users say:
‚ÄúI use an Ola S1 and stay in HSR Layout. ElectricPe‚Äôs kirana station near my home is a lifesaver.‚Äù ‚Äì Ramesh, Bengaluru ‚ÄúUnlike other apps, this one never hangs. Booking is super fast.‚Äù ‚Äì Priya, Delhi ‚ÄúAs a fleet manager for 20 EV autos, ElectricPe‚Äôs dashboard helps me save ‚Çπ15,000/month in operations.‚Äù ‚Äì Sameer, Pune The focus on reliability and usability is a huge win in a market that‚Äôs often riddled with faulty or busy chargers.
ElectricPe vs Statiq vs ChargeZone ‚Äì A Comparison {.wp-block-heading} Feature <th> ElectricPe </th> <th> Statiq </th> <th> ChargeZone </th> Cities Covered <td> 20+ </td> <td> 20+ </td> <td> 25+ </td> Fast Charging <td> Available </td> <td> Available </td> <td> Widely available </td> App Experience <td> Highly Rated </td> <td> Mixed Reviews </td> <td> Good </td> Smart Load Management <td> Yes </td> <td> Partial </td> <td> Yes </td> Pricing Transparency <td> Very Clear </td> <td> Moderate </td> <td> Clear </td> Renewable Integration <td> Actively focused </td> <td> Low </td> <td> Moderate </td> While Statiq and ChargeZone are strong contenders, ElectricPe edges ahead in app experience, local station distribution, and renewable goals.
Challenges and How ElectricPe Is Solving Them Some challenges ElectricPe tackles include:
Charger misuse ‚Äì Solved with smart locks and user identity verification. Grid overload ‚Äì Tackled with AI-based energy balancing. EV parking congestion ‚Äì Coordinated parking partners to reserve charging slots. Lack of awareness ‚Äì Partnering with local RTOs and dealerships to spread awareness about EV charging. ElectricPe‚Äôs Role in Public and Commercial Charging ElectricPe isn‚Äôt just for private vehicle owners. Their B2B offering includes:
Bulk installations for delivery fleets (Zomato, Swiggy, Dunzo) Integration into logistics hubs EV parking plus charging models in corporate parks This dual focus on B2C and B2B makes their model highly scalable.
Recent Updates and Growth Milestones (2024‚Äì2025) Reached 1 million charges milestone in Q4 2024 Expanded into 6 new cities including Nagpur, Bhopal, and Kochi Raised $18M in Series B funding to scale infrastructure Launched ‚ÄòElectricPe SolarPods‚Äô, portable solar EV charging for events and campuses Future Roadmap ‚Äì What‚Äôs Coming by 2030? ElectricPe has publicly announced some bold targets:
1 lakh charging points by 2030 Integration with EV toll roads and highways Launch of battery swapping lockers for last-mile delivery fleets EV Travel Planner for intercity routes in the app Smart vehicle integration for auto-charging session start Why ElectricPe Could Be the Game-Changer for India‚Äôs EV Ecosystem India‚Äôs EV market is fragmented and still maturing. What sets ElectricPe apart is its inclusive, low-cost, and tech-driven approach.
They don‚Äôt just serve Tesla-like customers. They cater to college kids on e-bikes, delivery boys on scooters, and office-goers with Tata Nexon EVs‚Äîall through a network built around daily Indian life.
How to Join, Locate, and Start Using ElectricPe Today Getting started is easy:
Download the ElectricPe app (Android/iOS) Sign up and add your EV type View nearby stations Book a slot or walk-in Scan and charge! You‚Äôll also get updates on new station launches and special discounts based on your location.
Conclusion: Building India‚Äôs Future with Every Charge ElectricPe isn‚Äôt just building chargers. It‚Äôs building confidence among EV users, breaking myths, and making clean mobility an everyday reality.
If India‚Äôs future is electric, companies like ElectricPe are laying the power lines‚Äîquietly, reliably, and smartly.
