As electric mobility gains momentum in India, one of the most critical enablers of this transformation is the availability of reliable electric vehicle charging stations. While many large companies focus on high-capacity fast chargers installed along highways and urban centers, another revolution is quietly happening in local neighborhoods, small towns, and even remote areas. This revolution is powered by Bolt.Earth, a company that is building India‚Äôs most inclusive and intelligent electric vehicle charging station network.
Formerly known as REVOS, Bolt.Earth has evolved into a driving force behind India‚Äôs decentralized charging model. This comprehensive article explores Bolt.Earth‚Äôs journey, its vision, its technologies, and why it has become a leader in building scalable and community-powered electric vehicle charging stations across the country.
The Transformation: From REVOS to Bolt.Earth The journey of Bolt.Earth started under the brand REVOS (Revolutionary EV Operating System). Initially focused on smart connected vehicle technology for electric two-wheelers, the founders‚ÄîMohit Yadav and Rashi Agarwal‚Äîsoon realized that without a strong network of electric vehicle charging stations, EV adoption would remain limited.
Recognizing this gap, they rebranded as Bolt.Earth in 2022 and expanded their mission to empower every Indian city, town, and street with accessible and affordable electric vehicle charging stations. Their goal wasn‚Äôt just to build infrastructure‚Äîit was to make charging as commonplace as mobile top-ups.
Why Bolt.Earth‚Äôs Model is Different Bolt.Earth isn‚Äôt just another charging solutions provider. It‚Äôs creating a hyper-local electric vehicle charging station ecosystem by turning small businesses, homes, and shops into public charging hosts.
Here‚Äôs what makes their model truly disruptive:
Community-Based Charging: Anyone can install a Bolt charger and turn their space into an electric vehicle charging station. Smart IoT Integration: Each station is connected to the Bolt cloud and app, giving users real-time access to station availability. Affordability: With prices starting around ‚Çπ4,500, Bolt chargers are among the most cost-effective options for personal and commercial EV charging. Earn from Charging: Hosts earn every time someone uses their electric vehicle charging station, creating a new stream of passive income. This model doesn‚Äôt just add chargers‚Äîit multiplies opportunities and democratizes the growth of India‚Äôs EV ecosystem.
Bolt Lite: Powering the Neighborhood Charging Network Bolt.Earth‚Äôs flagship device, Bolt Lite, is a smart and compact electric vehicle charging station suitable for homes, businesses, and public places. It delivers 3.3 kW AC output, ideal for charging electric two-wheelers, e-bikes, and entry-level EV cars like the Tata Tiago EV and MG Comet EV.
Bolt Lite Specifications: Charging Output: 3.3 kW Input: 230V AC Plug: Type 2/Indian standard Protection: IP55 weather-resistant enclosure Connectivity: Wi-Fi and Bluetooth Installation Type: Wall-mounted Price: ‚Çπ4,500‚Äì‚Çπ7,000 This makes Bolt Lite a perfect fit for residential areas, small businesses, gated communities, and street-side vendors. Any place can become an electric vehicle charging station with a simple installation and mobile app connection.
How the Bolt Charging Experience Works Charging your electric vehicle through a Bolt.Earth charging station is straightforward and user-friendly:
Download the Bolt App Locate the Nearest Electric Vehicle Charging Station Scan the QR Code on the Charger Start Charging and Track in Real-Time Pay via UPI, Wallet, or Card Leave a Rating for the Station This seamless experience ensures that even first-time EV users can easily locate and use an electric vehicle charging station without needing any technical knowledge.
Enabling Small Businesses to Become EV Charging Hosts One of the most impactful parts of Bolt.Earth‚Äôs mission is empowering small business owners to participate in India‚Äôs clean mobility journey.
Shopkeepers, hoteliers, apartment managers, and even local caf√©s are now becoming charging hosts by installing a Bolt Lite electric vehicle charging station.
Benefits include:
Generating passive income from EV users Attracting more foot traffic to physical stores Supporting India’s transition to green transport Contributing to local infrastructure without major investment By turning every street corner into a potential electric vehicle charging station, Bolt.Earth is making EV adoption not just practical but profitable for common people.
Expanding Smart EV Software: Bolt OS While Bolt.Earth has become known for its physical electric vehicle charging stations, it continues to lead in smart EV software through its Bolt OS platform.
Bolt OS integrates advanced IoT and cloud features into electric vehicles, enabling:
Real-time GPS tracking Battery health diagnostics Anti-theft alerts Geo-fencing Trip data analysis Fleet-level analytics for businesses Vehicle OEMs can embed Bolt OS into their scooters or delivery bikes to offer smarter rides. This reinforces Bolt.Earth‚Äôs role not just in charging but in powering a fully connected EV experience.
Growth Across India: Reaching Urban and Rural India Alike Bolt.Earth is rapidly expanding its footprint by enabling thousands of electric vehicle charging stations in locations traditional providers often miss.
By the Numbers (as of 2025): Chargers Installed: 35,000+ Cities Covered: 400+ Daily Charging Sessions: 3,500+ Top States: Karnataka, Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu, Delhi, Uttar Pradesh Common Locations: PG hostels, residential apartments, kirana stores, petrol bunks By allowing anyone to host an electric vehicle charging station, Bolt.Earth is solving the range anxiety problem from the bottom up.
How Bolt Compares to Other Charging Companies Here‚Äôs a simple comparison with other leading electric vehicle charging station companies in India:
Company <th> Focus </th> <th> Charger Type </th> <th> Cost Range </th> <th> Model </th> Bolt.Earth <td> Community-based </td> <td> 3.3kW AC </td> <td> ‚Çπ4,500+ </td> <td> Crowd-sourced </td> Statiq <td> Urban + public </td> <td> 7kW‚Äì22kW AC/DC </td> <td> ‚Çπ20,000+ </td> <td> B2B </td> ChargeZone <td> Highways </td> <td> Fast DC </td> <td> ‚Çπ50,000+ </td> <td> B2B/B2G </td> Ather Grid <td> Private use </td> <td> Fast AC </td> <td> Internal pricing </td> <td> Closed loop </td> Relux <td> Tamil Nadu </td> <td> AC/DC </td> <td> ‚Çπ7,000+ </td> <td> Local B2C </td> Bolt.Earth‚Äôs strength lies in its low-cost and high-volume approach, making electric vehicle charging stations viable in both premium and budget markets.
For EV Manufacturers: Bolt OS Integration OEMs like Bounce Infinity, eBikeGo, and Batt:RE are already using Bolt OS to deliver smarter electric vehicles. This includes remote battery checks, location tracking, predictive maintenance, and over-the-air updates.
Manufacturers benefit by offering modern tech features without investing in proprietary software. Their customers, in turn, get access to integrated apps and nearby electric vehicle charging stations through the same ecosystem.
Sustainability Commitment In addition to promoting EV adoption, Bolt.Earth ensures that every electric vehicle charging station it enables is part of a greener future:
Solar Compatibility: Chargers can integrate with rooftop solar panels. Recycling: Old or broken chargers are recycled. Biodegradable Packaging: Environmentally friendly packaging is used. Low Power Footprint: 3.3 kW models use standard grid electricity efficiently. This makes Bolt not just a smart choice but a responsible one for eco-conscious users and communities.
The Road Ahead: 2025 and Beyond Here‚Äôs what Bolt.Earth has planned for the future of electric vehicle charging stations in India and beyond:
Scale to 100,000 Chargers by 2026 Launch Bolt Pro 7.4 kW AC charger for residential car users Partner with builders for EV-ready residential zones Enter new international markets, starting with Bangladesh and Sri Lanka Build a full-stack EV fleet management system with smart charging and vehicle analytics These goals signal a long-term commitment to building India‚Äôs most inclusive electric vehicle charging station network.
User Voices: Testimonials from Real India ‚ÄúWe installed a Bolt charging point outside our general store. Now we have EV riders coming in every day, and it‚Äôs increased our daily footfall by 20%.‚Äù
‚Äì Ravi, Shop Owner, Nashik ‚ÄúOur society added three Bolt Lite chargers. It‚Äôs been a game-changer for our EV users. No need to go outside looking for an electric vehicle charging station.‚Äù
‚Äì Meera, Secretary, Bengaluru Apartment Complex ‚ÄúI drive a Bounce scooter for deliveries. Knowing I have multiple Bolt chargers nearby reduces my anxiety about running out of power during work.‚Äù
‚Äì Suraj, EV Delivery Rider, Delhi Final Thoughts: A Community-Led Charging Revolution Bolt.Earth isn‚Äôt just creating a company‚Äîit‚Äôs enabling a movement. By allowing everyday Indians to become part of the EV ecosystem, it‚Äôs turning India‚Äôs EV dream into a grassroots reality.
With over 35,000 active electric vehicle charging stations and a roadmap to reach 100,000 in just a few years, Bolt.Earth is setting the pace for smart, inclusive, and scalable infrastructure.
If India is to succeed in transitioning to clean mobility, it needs solutions that work for everyone‚Äînot just the elite or urban class. And that‚Äôs exactly what Bolt.Earth offers.

When we talk about the rapid growth of electric vehicles (EVs) in India, it‚Äôs not just about the cars or two-wheelers‚Äîit‚Äôs also about the backbone that supports them: the charging infrastructure. And one company that‚Äôs quietly but steadily becoming a significant name in this space is Zeon Charging.
Based out of Tamil Nadu, Zeon Charging isn‚Äôt just another startup jumping into the EV space for hype. It‚Äôs one of the few companies with a grounded, region-specific, and customer-focused approach to building a sustainable EV ecosystem. Whether you‚Äôre an EV car owner looking for fast charging on highways or a business exploring EV fleet partnerships, Zeon‚Äôs network is worth knowing about.
In this blog, we‚Äôll dive deep into everything about Zeon Charging‚Äîits origin, technology, network, app, partnerships, vision, pricing model, and future roadmap. We‚Äôll also compare it with other leading players like Tata Power, Statiq, and ChargeZone to give you a broader perspective.
What is Zeon Charging? Zeon Charging is an Indian EV charging network provider that focuses on building a fast and accessible charging infrastructure across South India, especially in Tamil Nadu, Kerala, and Karnataka. Their stations are primarily DC fast chargers, allowing EV users to top up their batteries during long-distance drives or urban commuting.
Mission: Zeon‚Äôs core mission is to ‚Äúaccelerate India‚Äôs transition to sustainable mobility by enabling reliable charging options where users need them most.‚Äù
Unlike companies that focus only on metro cities, Zeon‚Äôs approach involves building reliable charging stations along national highways, Tier 2 cities, and high-traffic routes, making it easier for people to travel between cities like Chennai, Coimbatore, Madurai, and Bengaluru without worrying about range anxiety.
Zeon‚Äôs Origin Story: Built for Southern India Zeon Charging was founded with a simple idea: India needs a dependable EV charging network that extends beyond the metro cities.
Initially started in Tamil Nadu, Zeon quickly identified that most of the major EV infrastructure was concentrated in Mumbai, Delhi, or Bengaluru. Southern India, especially Tamil Nadu and Kerala, with their rising EV adoption and tourism-heavy roadways, had very few fast-charging options.
The founding team‚Äîconsisting of engineers and mobility enthusiasts‚Äîstarted small. Their first few stations were set up on the Chennai-Trichy highway and in Coimbatore. Today, Zeon operates one of the most extensive highway charging networks in Tamil Nadu.
Charging Network: Where Can You Find Zeon Stations? As of 2025, Zeon has operational charging stations in:
Chennai Coimbatore Madurai Salem Tirunelveli Trichy Vellore Nagercoil Erode Kochi Bangalore outskirts Station Placement Strategy Zeon follows a hub-and-spoke model where chargers are placed:
At restaurants or cafes on highways At shopping malls or petrol pumps in cities Near large apartment complexes and hotels This approach allows EV users to charge while doing other tasks‚Äîeating, shopping, or staying overnight.
What Kind of Chargers Does Zeon Use? Zeon Charging primarily installs DC fast chargers ranging between 30 kW and 60 kW. These are suitable for most electric cars currently on Indian roads‚ÄîTata Nexon EV, MG ZS EV, Hyundai Kona, BYD Atto 3, and even newer models like Mahindra XUV400 and Tata Punch EV.
Technical Features: CCS2 connectors: Most compatible fast-charging standard in India OCPP protocol: For remote monitoring and interoperability Smart load balancing: Efficient power management between chargers App integration: Start, stop, and monitor sessions via smartphone They have also begun testing Type 2 AC chargers for residential and semi-public installations, ideal for overnight charging at apartments and gated communities.
Zeon Mobile App: A Must-Have for EV Owners in South India Zeon has a well-designed, user-friendly mobile app available on Android and iOS.
Features of the Zeon App: Find the nearest charger with real-time availability Start/Stop charging sessions Pay securely via UPI, credit card, or wallet View session history and consumption reports Navigation support via Google Maps integration 24/7 customer care support through in-app chat or call The app also shows tariff rates, expected wait times (if any), and lets users provide feedback and report issues.
Zeon Charging Tariffs and Payment Options Pricing is one of the most important factors when choosing a public charging network. Zeon‚Äôs pricing is transparent and reasonably competitive compared to other national players.
As of 2025, Zeon‚Äôs average DC fast-charging rate is: ‚Çπ20‚Äì‚Çπ24 per kWh for 30kW‚Äì60kW chargers ‚Çπ16‚Äì‚Çπ18 per kWh for slower 22kW Type 2 AC chargers They also offer subscription plans for frequent users and special pricing for fleet operators. Payment can be made via:
UPI (Google Pay, PhonePe, etc.) Debit/Credit Cards Net Banking Wallet recharge in the app Partnerships: Who‚Äôs Collaborating with Zeon? Zeon has partnered with several hospitality and infrastructure companies to increase its footprint across South India. Some of the notable partnerships include:
A2B (Adyar Ananda Bhavan) ‚Äì Highway restaurants GRT Hotels & Resorts SRM Hotels SPAR Hypermarkets TN Tourism Development Corporation These partnerships allow Zeon to place chargers in locations with good visibility, footfall, and parking.
They are also working closely with state governments of Tamil Nadu and Kerala under EV promotion schemes and policies.
Zeon Charging vs Other Charging Companies Let‚Äôs compare Zeon with some of the other major players in the Indian EV charging space:
Company <th> Focus Area </th> <th> Charger Type </th> <th> Price per kWh </th> <th> App Quality </th> <th> Notable Feature </th> Zeon Charging <td> Tamil Nadu, Kerala </td> <td> DC Fast (30‚Äì60 kW) </td> <td> ‚Çπ20‚Äì24 </td> <td> High </td> <td> Strong highway presence </td> Statiq <td> Pan India </td> <td> AC + DC (7‚Äì60 kW) </td> <td> ‚Çπ15‚Äì23 </td> <td> Moderate </td> <td> Affordable plans </td> ChargeZone <td> Highways, Urban </td> <td> DC Fast (60‚Äì240 kW) </td> <td> ‚Çπ22‚Äì26 </td> <td> High </td> <td> Fleet charging focus </td> Tata Power EZ <td> Tier 1 cities </td> <td> AC & DC mix </td> <td> ‚Çπ16‚Äì24 </td> <td> Very High </td> <td> Largest network in India </td> Jio-BP Pulse <td> Metro cities </td> <td> Ultra-fast DC (60 kW+) </td> <td> ‚Çπ22‚Äì27 </td> <td> Developing </td> <td> Reliance network support </td> Real User Reviews and Feedback Zeon has consistently received positive feedback for:
Reliability: Chargers work consistently without software bugs Location: Strategically placed stations with clean surroundings Service: Quick response from the support team in case of issues UI/UX: Mobile app is clean and efficient Sample User Comments: ‚ÄúI used Zeon‚Äôs charger between Chennai and Madurai. The restaurant had clean restrooms, and the charging experience was smooth. 45 minutes gave me 80% charge!‚Äù
‚Äì Mahesh Babu, Nexon EV Owner ‚ÄúThe support team is very responsive. Once, my session didn‚Äôt start, and they manually restarted it within 2 minutes.‚Äù
‚Äì Nandita K, ZS EV Owner Zeon for Commercial Fleets and Business Use Zeon is increasingly becoming a preferred charging partner for businesses operating fleets of EVs. This includes:
Food delivery companies Hyperlocal logistics startups Employee transport operators Hotel chains and malls Custom B2B Services: Bulk charging packages Private EV chargers for company premises Dedicated parking slots Usage analytics dashboard Priority support team Zeon also provides consultation services for real estate developers and gated communities planning to offer EV charging.
Zeon‚Äôs Vision for 2025‚Äì2030 Zeon Charging‚Äôs roadmap is both ambitious and practical. Here‚Äôs what they aim to achieve:
Short-Term Goals (2025‚Äì2026): Expand to 500+ stations across South India Launch ultra-fast 120kW chargers on high-traffic corridors Increase uptime reliability to 98% Add multi-vehicle support per site (3+ chargers) Mid-Term Goals (2027‚Äì2028): Collaborate with OEMs for integrated in-car navigation Enable solar-powered stations to cut grid dependency Build EV charging hubs at key logistics locations Long-Term Vision (2029‚Äì2030): Become South India‚Äôs largest EV charging operator Reach Tier 2/3 cities and rural towns Create a pan-India app platform through API integration with other charging networks Challenges and How Zeon is Addressing Them Like every player in the EV ecosystem, Zeon has faced its share of hurdles:

They work closely with DISCOMs and state electricity boards Partner with landowners and local hotels for easy setups Run awareness campaigns about EVs and charging etiquette Why Zeon Matters in India‚Äôs EV Story Zeon is not just a charging company; it‚Äôs a critical piece of India‚Äôs clean mobility puzzle.
It‚Äôs building trust among first-time EV buyers in non-metro cities It’s helping reduce range anxiety by ensuring reliable highway coverage It’s showing how regional players can make a national impact through consistency and focus For anyone in South India‚Äîbe it a daily commuter, road-tripper, or EV fleet owner‚ÄîZeon is quickly becoming the go-to charging network.
Conclusion: Zeon is Quietly Leading the EV Charging Game in South India While big names like Tata Power and Jio-BP make headlines, Zeon is building real-world impact. With reliable infrastructure, fast-growing coverage, and a people-first approach, Zeon Charging is setting benchmarks for how regional EV charging networks should be built.

Introduction: The Future of Transportation Starts in Your College Workshop Imagine cruising across your college campus on a silent, battery-powered ride that you built with your own hands. Feels like something out of a tech movie, right? But this is real, and it‚Äôs happening across colleges in India. From engineering festivals to startup incubators, students are showcasing their self-built electric vehicles‚Äîand you can too.
Building a DIY electric vehicle as a college project is not just a trend; it‚Äôs a practical path to understanding the future of mobility. It teaches you how EVs work, how batteries and motors function, and how sustainability meets engineering. It‚Äôs hands-on learning, career-boosting exposure, and serious fun‚Äîall rolled into one.
Whether you‚Äôre a mechanical engineering student looking for a final-year project, or an interdisciplinary team interested in sustainability and innovation, this guide will help you build a working electric vehicle with components easily available in India.
Why Should You Build a DIY EV in College? Let‚Äôs start with the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù before the ‚Äúhow.‚Äù
Electric vehicles are the future of personal and public transportation. Governments are pushing for EV adoption. Companies are investing billions. But the real revolution will be led by students like you who learn, tinker, and innovate.
Here‚Äôs what you gain from a student EV project:
Practical exposure to real-world engineering challenges. Direct experience with EV components‚Äîmotors, controllers, batteries, and more. Opportunities to present at tech expos, win grants, and participate in competitions. A portfolio project that impresses recruiters and investors. Possibility to turn your prototype into a startup or patentable product. When you build your own EV, you‚Äôre not just making a vehicle. You‚Äôre building your understanding of electrical, mechanical, and sustainable technologies‚Äîand creating something that could shape your future.
Choosing the Right DIY EV Project for College Before you start building, you need to decide what kind of EV you want to build. Your decision should depend on your:
Technical skill level Budget Team size Project duration Academic goals (mini project, major project, competition) Here are the most popular types of DIY EVs built by Indian college students:
Electric Bicycle A simple and cost-effective option. Ideal for beginners or as a mini project.
Pros: Low cost, lightweight, uses available bicycle frame
Cons: Limited scope for complex electronics or innovation
Electric Scooter Conversion Take an old petrol scooter and convert it into an electric one using a hub motor and battery.
Pros: Real-world application, practical daily use
Cons: Needs more fabrication and electrical work
Electric Go-Kart A popular choice for final-year or competition projects.
Pros: Allows performance tuning, speed optimization, fun to drive
Cons: High budget, more complex chassis work
Solar-Assist EV Add solar charging panels to any of the above to increase range or recharge on the go.
Pros: Innovative, great for sustainability-focused projects
Cons: Efficiency depends on sunlight and panel quality
Three-Wheeled EV (Trike) Useful if you‚Äôre looking to build a delivery EV or something with load capacity.
Pros: Can carry heavier payloads, useful for real-world applications
Cons: Needs more frame design and fabrication effort
Choose the format that matches your team‚Äôs strengths and interests. Each type offers unique learning and presentation opportunities.
Tools and Skills You‚Äôll Need You don‚Äôt have to be an expert to start building an EV‚Äîbut it helps to know the basics. Here‚Äôs a checklist of skills and tools you‚Äôll need:
Skills Required:
Electrical wiring and circuit knowledge Basic fabrication or welding Battery management understanding Motor installation and alignment Soldering and insulation techniques Basic programming (if using Arduino/BMS modules) Tools Required:
Spanner and wrench set Wire stripper and cutter Soldering iron and flux Multimeter for voltage checks Drill machine Screwdriver set Welding machine (optional) Teamwork makes things easier. Divide roles based on expertise‚Äîmechanical, electrical, electronics, and documentation.
Core Components of an Electric Vehicle Let‚Äôs break down the main parts you‚Äôll need to build your electric vehicle. These are available from local EV parts dealers or online platforms like Robu.in, Amazon India, and EVparts.in.
1. Electric Motor Most student projects use BLDC (Brushless DC) hub motors or chain-drive motors. Choose your motor based on the size and weight of your EV.
For electric bikes/scooters:
250W to 1000W motors
For go-karts or heavier models:
1000W to 2000W motors
The motor decides your top speed, torque, and climb capability.
2. Battery Pack You can choose between:
Lithium-ion batteries: Lightweight, fast charging, longer lifespan Lead-acid batteries: Cheaper but heavier, slower charging A typical battery spec for a student EV is 36V or 48V with 10Ah to 30Ah capacity.
Ensure you use a Battery Management System (BMS) to monitor safety, charging, and discharging.
3. Motor Controller This component links your motor, battery, and throttle. It manages the speed and torque output from the motor based on user input.
Buy a controller compatible with your motor wattage and voltage.
4. Throttle This is your accelerator. You can get twist-grip throttles for bikes and scooters, or pedal-style for karts and cars. Some throttles also include battery level indicators.
5. Frame or Chassis This is your vehicle‚Äôs body. You can:
Reuse a bicycle or scooter frame Build your own using MS tubes and welding Modify a discarded chassis from scrap yards Design your frame to hold all components safely and comfortably.
6. Wiring and Connectors Use heat-resistant wiring. Plan your layout to avoid loose connections. Include fuses or circuit breakers for added safety.
Use insulated connectors and secure all connections with shrink tubes or electric tape.
7. Safety Features On/off kill switch Fuse box Battery cut-off relay Insulated connectors Helmet and protective gear (for testing) Cost Breakdown: How Much Will It Cost to Build a DIY EV? Let‚Äôs break down the approximate cost for three types of projects:
1. Electric Bicycle (Low Budget Project) BLDC Hub Motor Kit (250W): ‚Çπ4,500 Lithium-ion Battery (36V 10Ah): ‚Çπ9,500 Controller + Throttle: ‚Çπ2,000 Cycle Frame: ‚Çπ2,000 Miscellaneous (wires, lights, tools): ‚Çπ2,000 Total: ‚Çπ20,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ25,000
2. Electric Scooter Conversion Hub Motor (500W‚Äì1000W): ‚Çπ6,500 ‚Äì ‚Çπ12,000 Battery (48V 20Ah): ‚Çπ14,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ18,000 Controller: ‚Çπ2,500 Fabrication and painting: ‚Çπ5,000 Extra electricals: ‚Çπ3,000 Total: ‚Çπ30,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ45,000
3. Electric Go-Kart BLDC Motor (1000W‚Äì2000W): ‚Çπ12,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ20,000 Lithium-ion Battery Pack (60V 20Ah): ‚Çπ20,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ30,000 Controller: ‚Çπ4,000 Chassis fabrication: ‚Çπ15,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ20,000 Suspension, wheels, brakes: ‚Çπ10,000 Steering, throttle, seat: ‚Çπ5,000 Total: ‚Çπ60,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ1,00,000
Plan your budget and get sponsorship from your college, alumni networks, or local businesses.
Step-by-Step Assembly Guide Here‚Äôs a simplified process you can follow:
Step 1: Planning and Design
Draw sketches, layout component positions, and simulate load balance.
Step 2: Buy Components
Purchase the motor, battery, controller, and wiring first. Make sure all voltage ratings are compatible.
Step 3: Frame Setup
Weld or mount your frame. Install brackets or plates to hold the motor, battery, and controller.
Step 4: Install Motor
Fit the hub motor into the wheel rim or attach the chain-driven motor securely.
Step 5: Battery Integration
Mount the battery in a waterproof, insulated box. Use straps or brackets to secure.
Step 6: Wiring and Testing
Connect all components using a wiring diagram. Test voltage using a multimeter.
Step 7: First Test Run
Place the vehicle on a stand. Run without load. Then test on flat terrain with proper gear.
Step 8: Optimization
Improve acceleration, range, or control response. Add lights, horn, reflectors.
Step 9: Documentation
Prepare a detailed report with photos, diagrams, bill of materials, test results, and a video demo.
Safety Guidelines You Should Never Ignore Use fuses for overcurrent protection. Do not overcharge batteries‚Äîalways use a charger with cutoff. Avoid short circuits while testing. Wear gloves and goggles during wiring and soldering. Test your vehicle in open spaces‚Äînot inside classrooms or hostels. Keep a fire extinguisher near the charging station. Charge under supervision only. Tips for Showcasing Your Project Once your project is done, don‚Äôt keep it hidden. Showcase it well:
Create a professional PPT and report Record a high-quality video of the test drive Print a brochure with your innovation and stats Present in college expos, inter-college competitions, and YouTube Register for startup incubation programs or technical fests Career Opportunities After Building a DIY EV A self-built EV on your resume opens many doors:
Internships at EV startups (Ather, Ola, Bounce Infinity) Jobs in R&D, EV design, battery tech, or mobility services Scholarships for masters programs in electric mobility or clean tech Start your own venture with crowdfunding or grant support What you learn here goes beyond marks‚Äîit‚Äôs future-ready skill development.
Student EV Competitions to Participate In Formula Bharat ‚Äì Build a race-ready electric car EFFI-CYCLE (SAEINDIA) ‚Äì Hybrid or electric three-wheeler e-Yantra (IIT Bombay) ‚Äì Robotics and automation with EV tracks ISIE Electric Kart ‚Äì Go-kart racing challenges Smart India Hackathon ‚Äì Real-world EV problem statements These are great platforms to present your EV and get national recognition.
Final Thoughts: Build, Learn, Lead College is the perfect time to explore, experiment, and express your ideas. A DIY electric vehicle project is more than just a vehicle‚Äîit‚Äôs a launchpad. It could be the start of your career, your startup, or even your legacy.
Build your EV not just for grades, but to shape your skills and ideas. Ask questions. Seek help. Make mistakes. And when it works‚Äîwhen your wheels spin for the first time‚Äîyou‚Äôll feel the reward of building something that truly moves.
Want to showcase your EV project on EVBlogs.in?
Submit your story, photos, and build process to avmedianews321@gmail.com. Let your innovation inspire thousands of young EV enthusiasts across India.

Introduction: From Petrol to Plug ‚Äì Why This Project Matters If you‚Äôre a college student in India with a knack for engineering, sustainability, or simply making things work, here‚Äôs a project that could define your resume: converting an old petrol scooter into a fully functional electric vehicle. Imagine taking that old, unused Activa or Scooty lying in your backyard and transforming it into a zero-emission ride. It‚Äôs not just cool‚Äîit‚Äôs practical, eco-friendly, and a smart way to learn about electric mobility from the inside out.
This blog will walk you through the entire process‚Äîfrom understanding the benefits to getting your hands dirty with tools and wires. Whether you‚Äôre planning this for your final-year project or just as a DIY weekend challenge with friends, you‚Äôll find this guide packed with real advice, cost breakdowns, safety tips, and useful links to help you execute a conversion project that actually works on Indian roads.
Why Convert a Petrol Scooter into an Electric Vehicle? Petrol prices are rising, pollution is choking our cities, and the Indian government is pushing for clean energy mobility. Here‚Äôs why converting a scooter to electric makes perfect sense:
It cuts your running cost drastically. Charging a battery is far cheaper than filling a tank with petrol. On average, it costs about ‚Çπ0.25 to ‚Çπ0.50 per km with electricity, compared to ‚Çπ2‚Äì3 per km using petrol.
It offers a great hands-on learning experience with EV components such as motors, batteries, controllers, and charging systems. This knowledge is increasingly in demand.
It gives a second life to an old or unused vehicle. Instead of scrapping, you repurpose.
It aligns with India‚Äôs larger goals under the FAME II policy and electric mobility push.
It gives you an edge in college competitions, startup ideas, and academic research.
Real-Life Student Case Studies Many students across India have already built working prototypes or functional EVs from old scooters.
Students from VIT University converted a decade-old TVS Scooty into a functioning electric scooter using a 1000W hub motor, lithium battery pack, and a custom-designed controller enclosure. Their project went viral on LinkedIn.
A group from Chandigarh Engineering College used a retrofitting kit on a discarded Honda Activa and turned it into a campus shuttle. They managed to complete the project under ‚Çπ40,000.
An interdisciplinary team at IIT Bombay incorporated a GPS tracker and Arduino-controlled speed limiting system for added safety. They also filed for a student-level patent.
These are just a few inspiring examples proving that with proper planning and teamwork, you can achieve remarkable results as a student.
Legal Requirements: Is It Allowed in India? Yes, but you need to follow specific legal protocols.
As per Indian government norms, EV retrofitting is allowed but must be done using approved conversion kits. These kits are certified by the Automotive Research Association of India (ARAI) or the International Centre for Automotive Technology (ICAT).
You cannot legally drive a DIY EV on public roads unless you update your Registration Certificate (RC). You‚Äôll need to:
Submit the kit certification papers and vehicle details to your Regional Transport Office (RTO). Get the converted vehicle inspected and certified. Update the fuel type on your RC book. Obtain new insurance and road tax documentation (if required). For campus or exhibition use, you don‚Äôt need registration, but it‚Äôs good practice to maintain safety and documentation.
Tools and Components You‚Äôll Need To complete the project, you‚Äôll need both mechanical tools and electric vehicle components.
EV Components:
BLDC Hub Motor (1000‚Äì2000W) Lithium-ion Battery Pack (48V/60V, 20‚Äì40Ah) Motor Controller (compatible with battery and motor) Throttle Grip with Indicator Display DC-DC Converter (for 12V systems like horn, lights) Battery Management System (BMS) Smart Charger (with auto cut-off) Wiring, Fuses, Relays, and Connectors Tools:
Spanner Set Wire Cutter and Crimper Multimeter Electric Drill Soldering Kit Cable Ties and Clamps Heat Shrink Tubes Try to source quality components to ensure safety and longevity of the build.
Budget Breakdown (Estimated for Students) Here‚Äôs a realistic cost estimate assuming a decent-quality conversion suitable for student showcase or daily use within a campus.
Component <th> Estimated Cost (INR) </th> 1000W BLDC Hub Motor <td> ‚Çπ7,500 ‚Äì ‚Çπ10,000 </td> Lithium-ion Battery 60V 25Ah <td> ‚Çπ18,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ25,000 </td> Controller + Throttle <td> ‚Çπ2,500 ‚Äì ‚Çπ3,500 </td> DC-DC Converter <td> ‚Çπ1,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ1,500 </td> Wiring & Safety Accessories <td> ‚Çπ2,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ3,000 </td> Chassis Modification <td> ‚Çπ3,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ5,000 </td> Painting and Enclosures <td> ‚Çπ2,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ3,000 </td> Display Meter (Optional) <td> ‚Çπ1,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ2,000 </td> Total <td> <strong>‚Çπ37,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ53,000</strong> </td> Costs may vary based on brand, region, and existing scooter condition.
Step-by-Step Conversion Process 1. Dismantling the Petrol Components: Remove the engine, exhaust pipe, fuel tank, wiring harness, speedometer cable, and ignition system. Carefully disconnect and keep reusable parts.
2. Mounting the Motor: If using a hub motor, replace the rear wheel with the motorized one. For mid-drive motors, align and bolt to the central frame.
3. Battery Placement: Install the battery pack under the footboard or in the storage compartment. Ensure it‚Äôs mounted using brackets, cushioned with foam, and waterproofed.
4. Controller Wiring: Fix the controller near the motor or battery. Connect throttle, battery input, motor output, and auxiliary outputs. Label all wires to avoid confusion.
5. DC Systems: Use the DC-DC converter to step down power for horn, lights, and indicators. Connect it to the main battery line.
6. Fuse Installation: Place a fuse (rated 1.5x your motor current) between the battery and controller for safety.
7. Testing and Debugging: Before final enclosure, test the entire system on a stand. Check throttle response, brake switches, indicator lights, and voltage stability.
8. Final Assembly: Mount plastic covers, repaint the frame if needed, label switches, and do a slow-speed test in an open field.
Common Mistakes to Avoid Using a motor or controller that‚Äôs incompatible with the battery voltage Incorrect wiring causing short circuits or component burnout Poor-quality connectors or open-end terminals No fuse or circuit protection Loose battery mounting leading to physical or fire damage Ignoring balance and weight distribution Customization Ideas You can take your project further with these smart add-ons:
Solar charging input on the dashboard IoT-based mobile app for GPS tracking and battery health monitoring Anti-theft system with remote cut-off Adjustable throttle sensitivity for ride control Smart display with battery percentage and distance-to-empty Regenerative braking module (advanced) Competitions and Showcases to Apply Formula Bharat EV Division Smart India Hackathon ‚Äì Mobility Theme EVangelize by Skill Shark ISIEINDIA Go-Kart Design Challenge Electric Vehicle Expo Student Showcase College fests like Kshitij (IIT Kharagpur), Shaastra (IIT Madras), and Techfest (IIT Bombay) Career and Startup Opportunities Building your own electric scooter makes you stand out. You can:
Intern at EV firms like Ather, Ola, Revolt, Bounce Infinity Apply for campus incubators or startup funding Launch a YouTube channel or blog showcasing conversions Freelance as a retrofitting consultant or EV content creator Write patents or whitepapers for further research The skills you gain‚Äîbattery integration, power electronics, mechanical design‚Äîare all directly aligned with future green tech jobs.
Final Thoughts: From Old Ride to New Pride There‚Äôs something powerful about breathing new life into an old machine. You‚Äôre not just creating an electric scooter; you‚Äôre building proof that sustainable transport is possible without buying new vehicles.
If you‚Äôre planning to build your own EV conversion project, document everything. Take photos, make a build video, write a blog. These assets can help with future interviews, internships, or even raising funds for a startup.
Want your project featured? Send us a brief summary with photos to avmedianews321@gmail.com and we‚Äôll publish it on EVBlogs.in to inspire thousands of students across India.

Introduction: Why Lithium-Ion Battery Safety Matters for Student EV Projects If you‚Äôre a college student working on a DIY electric vehicle project, chances are you‚Äôre using a lithium-ion battery. They‚Äôre lightweight, high-performance, and power everything from e-bikes to go-karts and scooters. But they‚Äôre also sensitive, and without proper care, they can overheat, swell, or even catch fire.
Understanding how to handle, charge, store, and protect your lithium-ion battery is not just good practice‚Äîit‚Äôs essential. Whether you‚Äôre part of a student team building an e-bike for a competition or converting an old scooter into an EV for daily use, battery safety is the one area where you can‚Äôt afford shortcuts.
In this guide, we‚Äôll cover everything you need to know as a student to ensure lithium-ion battery safety during your EV project. We‚Äôll break it down in simple terms, with real examples, pro tips, and step-by-step advice.
What Are Lithium-Ion Batteries? A lithium-ion battery is a type of rechargeable battery widely used in EVs due to its high energy density, long cycle life, and compact size. Compared to older lead-acid or nickel batteries, lithium-ion packs are more efficient and charge faster.
Common types used in EVs:
NMC (Nickel Manganese Cobalt) LFP (Lithium Iron Phosphate) NCA (Nickel Cobalt Aluminum) Each type has its own pros and cons in terms of cost, safety, and performance. As a student, you‚Äôre likely to use off-the-shelf lithium-ion packs or assemble your own pack using 18650 or 21700 cells.
Why Are Lithium-Ion Batteries Risky If Mismanaged? Lithium-ion batteries are sensitive to temperature, overcharging, and physical damage. If misused, they can experience thermal runaway‚Äîa chain reaction that leads to heat buildup and sometimes explosions or fire.
Here‚Äôs what makes them risky:
Overcharging or short-circuiting Mechanical damage (drops, punctures, vibration) Exposure to moisture or extreme heat Using poor-quality cells or chargers Lack of proper Battery Management System (BMS) For a student working in a college lab or hostel room, these risks increase due to lack of industrial-grade safety setups. That‚Äôs why basic knowledge of handling these batteries can prevent major accidents.
Key Components That Affect Battery Safety 1. Battery Cells: Quality matters. Use certified cells from brands like LG, Samsung, Panasonic, or reliable Indian suppliers. Avoid recycled or no-name cells.
2. Battery Management System (BMS): A BMS monitors cell voltage, temperature, and current flow. It prevents overcharging and deep discharge and helps balance cells during charging.
3. Charger: Always use a charger that matches your battery voltage and current rating. Cheap or mismatched chargers are a fire hazard.
4. Enclosure: Your battery needs to be stored in a waterproof, vibration-resistant, and ventilated box. This protects against external damage.
5. Wiring: Use high-quality silicone-coated wires. Poor insulation or loose terminals are leading causes of short circuits.
Safe Charging Practices Most battery-related accidents happen during charging. Follow these steps to stay safe:
Always charge in a well-ventilated space Never charge unattended‚Äîespecially at night Use a charger with auto cut-off Avoid charging batteries immediately after a ride (let them cool) Don’t place the battery on beds, sofas, or wooden surfaces while charging If you notice swelling, overheating, or unusual smell, stop charging immediately How to Store Lithium-Ion Batteries Safely When not in use for long durations, like semester breaks or exam periods, follow these storage tips:
Store at around 50% charge, not fully charged Keep in a cool, dry place away from direct sunlight Avoid storing in extremely cold or hot environments Don‚Äôt seal the battery in an airtight container Check voltage every 2‚Äì3 weeks and top up if necessary Safe Handling During Assembly and Installation Many student teams make mistakes during installation that can lead to short circuits or mechanical damage. Here‚Äôs how to avoid them:
Always wear insulated gloves and safety goggles Never let positive and negative terminals touch Pre-check polarity before connecting wires Secure the battery with foam padding or shock-absorbing brackets Use insulated tools to avoid accidental bridging Do not solder directly on cells‚Äîuse nickel strips and spot welders Signs of Battery Trouble to Watch For Battery gets hot while charging or discharging Swelling or bulging of the pack Leaking or burning smell Sudden drop in range or voltage Battery shuts off under mild load If you notice any of these, disconnect the battery immediately and inspect for damage.
What to Do If a Battery Catches Fire First of all, prevention is better. But in case of emergency:
Do not try to extinguish with water Use a Class D fire extinguisher or sand to smother flames Evacuate the area and alert security or lab staff Do not touch the battery for hours after the fire Dispose of the burnt battery at authorized e-waste centers Disposal and Recycling of Damaged Batteries Don‚Äôt throw old or damaged lithium-ion batteries in the trash. Contact:
E-waste collection centers Battery manufacturers (many offer take-back programs) Local municipality e-waste drives Document your disposal method, especially if it‚Äôs part of a college project report.
Tips to Choose the Right Battery for Your DIY EV Choose a battery that matches your motor controller voltage (e.g., 48V or 60V) Estimate your energy needs using Wh = V x Ah Higher Ah means more range, but also more weight Look for cells with high discharge rating (C rating) If you‚Äôre buying prebuilt packs, check if they include BMS and charger Real-World Examples from Indian Colleges At NIT Trichy, students working on an electric kart project had to redo their battery system after initial overheating issues caused by improper mounting and heat dissipation.
In Pune, a final-year engineering group used an old laptop cell-based DIY pack, but it failed during testing due to uneven cell performance. They later switched to a certified 18650 pack and won second place at a regional EV expo.
A team from Delhi built a portable battery swap system using LFP batteries with metal enclosures. Their design was later selected for incubation support.
Recommended Brands and Suppliers If you‚Äôre buying in India, consider:
BatX Energies LiEnergy (Chennai) EVeium Batterywale Amazon (for individual cells) Robu.in Always verify the specs, reviews, and warranty. Request a datasheet if possible.
Maintenance Checklist for Students Create a weekly battery health checklist:
Check voltage using multimeter Inspect for swelling, corrosion, or damage Test connector tightness Monitor temperature during usage Recharge if below safe threshold (usually 3.2V per cell) Log cycles and total charge time Include this in your project documentation or maintenance logbook.
Final Thoughts: Respect the Power, Own the Project Lithium-ion batteries are the beating heart of your EV project. If handled correctly, they will serve you safely and efficiently. But neglecting safety basics can turn your hard work into disaster.
Be proactive. Educate your team. Create a battery safety SOP (Standard Operating Procedure) for your college project. And never compromise on safety, no matter how tight the deadline.
If you‚Äôre building or showcasing a student EV project powered by lithium-ion batteries, and you want your work featured, write to us at avmedianews321@gmail.com. Let‚Äôs inspire other students with your innovation.

Introduction: Why Students Should Explore Solar EV Charging If you‚Äôre a student passionate about electric vehicles, renewable energy, or sustainability, building your own solar EV charging setup is one of the most exciting and meaningful projects you can take on. With the push for clean mobility across India, solar power is becoming the go-to source for recharging electric vehicles‚Äîespecially in college campuses, rural areas, and homes with limited access to public charging infrastructure.
Whether you‚Äôre converting a petrol scooter to an electric one or already own an EV, adding solar charging gives you the independence to charge without paying for electricity. It also teaches you real-world applications of solar power systems, energy storage, and system design‚Äîall highly valuable skills in the modern green energy landscape.
This guide is designed for students who want to build their own solar-powered EV charging setup. We‚Äôll walk through the planning, tools, components, wiring, safety, and everything else you need to make your project a success.
Why Solar Charging for EVs Is the Future Electric vehicles are gaining ground rapidly, but the true potential of sustainable transport is realized only when those EVs are charged with clean energy. Here‚Äôs why solar charging is the perfect match:
Reduces dependency on fossil-fuel-based electricity Saves cost on long-term EV charging Enables off-grid charging in remote or rural areas Eliminates carbon emissions from energy production Promotes energy independence for homes and institutions Solar power and EVs go hand in hand, especially for Indian students living in sunny regions where solar energy is abundant throughout the year.
Can You Build Your Own Solar EV Charger? Yes, absolutely. As a college student, you can set up a basic solar-powered charging system for an electric cycle, scooter, or even a small e-car.
There are three main types of solar EV charging setups:
Direct Solar Charging (No Battery Storage) ‚Äì Simple, suitable for daytime charging only. Solar + Battery Storage (Off-Grid) ‚Äì Best for night or cloudy-day charging. Solar + Grid-Tied Hybrid (With Net Metering) ‚Äì Advanced setup, allows both solar and grid power. This guide focuses on the first two, which are affordable and easy to implement as student projects.
Understanding How a Solar Charging System Works A solar EV charger uses solar panels to capture sunlight and convert it into electricity. That power either:
Directly charges the EV (in daytime) Charges a battery, which is then used to power your EV Basic system components include:
Solar panel(s) Charge controller Battery (optional for storage-based systems) Inverter (for AC charging systems) EV charger or output connection This setup helps you learn about DC systems, energy conversion, charge controllers, and load balancing.
What You‚Äôll Need: Components and Tools Let‚Äôs list all the major components and tools you‚Äôll need to build a student-grade solar EV charging system.
Essential Components:
Solar Panel (100W to 500W or more) MPPT or PWM Charge Controller 12V, 24V, or 48V Battery Bank (Lead-acid or Lithium-ion) DC-DC Converter or Inverter (optional, based on EV input) EV Charger (compatible with your vehicle) Mounting Structure for Panels Wires, Connectors, Fuses, MCB, Switches Tools:
Screwdriver and spanner set Wire stripper and cutter Digital multimeter Solar panel tester (optional) Drill machine and clamps Safety gloves and goggles Choosing the Right Solar Panel Size and Type Solar panels come in different wattages, voltages, and technologies. For EV charging, monocrystalline panels are recommended due to their high efficiency.
Estimate your requirement:
Electric Bicycle: 100W‚Äì200W panel is enough Electric Scooter: 300W‚Äì500W Electric Car (entry level): 1kW and above Use this formula:
Charging Time (hours) = Battery Capacity (Wh) / Panel Output (W)
So, a 48V 20Ah battery = 960Wh. With a 300W panel, it would take around 3‚Äì4 hours under full sunlight.
Types of Solar Charging Setups 1. Direct Solar-to-EV (No Battery Storage):
Daylight-only usage Cheapest and easiest Suitable for e-bikes and scooters 2. Solar with Battery Storage:
More flexible, works even at night Requires charge controller and battery bank Ideal for EVs that need reliable daily charging 3. Grid-Tied with Net Metering (Advanced):
Allows two-way electricity flow Expensive and needs government approvals Useful for homes or institutions with high EV usage For students, the first two setups are more achievable and budget-friendly.
Step-by-Step Assembly: From Panel to Plug Step 1: Panel Installation
Mount panels on roof or ground with proper angle (ideally south-facing in India) Use a tilt of 15¬∞‚Äì30¬∞ depending on location Ensure no shading throughout the day Step 2: Connecting the Charge Controller
Connect panel output to the solar charge controller (use MC4 connectors) Match voltage ratings (e.g., 12V panel to 12V controller) Step 3: Battery Bank Setup (If Storage-Based)
Connect batteries in series or parallel for desired voltage/capacity Use fuses and thick gauge wires for connections Step 4: Output to EV Charger
Connect output from charge controller or inverter to your EV charging port Make sure voltage and current are compatible Add switch, MCB, or relay for safety Step 5: Grounding and Safety Checks
Ground the panel frame and controller Test voltage and polarity before final connection Wiring Diagram and Connection Tips Make a simple wiring plan before starting. Label wires and follow color coding:
Red for positive Black for negative Use proper wire gauges:
14AWG for 10A 10AWG for 30A Tips:
Always fuse between panel and controller Use heat shrink tubes on open terminals Check tightness of all screws and clamps Real-Life Student Projects from Indian Colleges At Amrita University, students created a solar-based EV charging station for campus e-cycles using 200W panels and lead-acid batteries.
Students at SRM University built a mobile solar cart with panels mounted on a moving platform. It was used to charge electric wheelchairs.
A team from IIT Guwahati installed a hybrid solar + wind EV charger as part of their environmental engineering project.
These examples prove it‚Äôs possible to build effective solar chargers using accessible components.
How Much Will It Cost? Budget for DIY Setup Let‚Äôs assume a solar charger setup for an electric scooter (48V, 20Ah battery).
Component <th> Estimated Cost (INR) </th> 300W Solar Panel <td> ‚Çπ8,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ10,000 </td> MPPT Charge Controller <td> ‚Çπ2,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ3,500 </td> 48V Lithium Battery <td> ‚Çπ18,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ25,000 </td> Mounting Structure <td> ‚Çπ2,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ3,000 </td> DC Charger <td> ‚Çπ1,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ2,500 </td> Wiring, Fuses, MCB <td> ‚Çπ1,500 ‚Äì ‚Çπ2,500 </td> Tools & Accessories <td> ‚Çπ1,000 </td> Total <td> <strong>‚Çπ33,500 ‚Äì ‚Çπ47,500</strong> </td> To reduce costs, use recycled panels or share components with college labs.
Safety Guidelines for Solar Installations Never touch panel wires during daylight without insulation Always connect battery to charge controller before connecting solar panel Avoid water contact with open terminals Use gloves while handling metal brackets and live wires Turn off system before servicing Always fuse the system Document your safety measures in your project report.
Maintenance and Performance Optimization Clean panels once every 2 weeks Check wire tightness monthly Monitor battery health regularly (voltage, temperature) Keep charge controller firmware updated (if digital) Shade monitoring: use apps like SolarEdge or SMA for optimal placement Future Add-Ons: App Control, IoT Monitoring, MPPT Integration To make your project stand out:
Add IoT sensors for real-time monitoring via apps Use ESP8266 or Arduino for remote status updates Install a GSM module to get SMS alerts for charge status Upgrade PWM controller to MPPT for higher efficiency Add a camera to monitor EV and panel status How to Present Your Solar EV Project at Competitions Make your project shine at hackathons and expos:
Record a time-lapse of your build process Present data logs showing charging performance Use a solar performance calculator to estimate annual output Add charts comparing solar vs grid costs Create a safety checklist and SOP document Events to consider:
Smart India Hackathon Solar Decathlon India ISIE Innovation Challenge Techkriti, Techfest, Pragyan (college fests) Conclusion: Clean, Green, and Student-Built Charging Power Solar EV charging is no longer a dream‚Äîit‚Äôs a project you can build with the right planning, components, and motivation. As a student, this project shows your commitment to sustainability, innovation, and hands-on problem solving.
It‚Äôs more than just a charger. It‚Äôs your contribution to India‚Äôs green future.

Introduction: Why Build a Smart E-Rickshaw? Electric rickshaws are becoming a common sight in Indian towns, cities, and even remote villages. They‚Äôre affordable, eco-friendly, and a practical solution for last-mile mobility. As a college student, building a smart electric rickshaw gives you the opportunity to work on a real-world project that combines engineering, sustainability, and innovation.
Whether you‚Äôre planning a final-year engineering project, participating in a competition, or exploring startup ideas, a DIY smart e-rickshaw is a meaningful project with long-term value. It teaches you the basics of EV systems, electric motors, battery management, solar integration, and smart features like GPS, mobile charging, and digital dashboards.
In this guide, you‚Äôll learn how to build your own electric rickshaw from scratch‚Äîincluding frame design, component selection, wiring, safety, legal requirements, and smart upgrades. Let‚Äôs get started.
Why an Electric Rickshaw Is a Great Student Project This project gives you much more than academic credit. It offers hands-on experience with:
Electrical engineering (motors, batteries, controllers) Mechanical design (chassis, wheel alignment, suspension) Electronics and IoT (GPS, mobile charging, battery indicators) Project management (budgeting, team coordination) Entrepreneurship (startup and product development mindset) Plus, it‚Äôs directly applicable to real-world needs. Whether used on campus for transporting people or in a nearby village for goods delivery, a smart e-rickshaw has actual use cases.
Choosing the Type of Rickshaw You Want to Build Depending on your target use, you can build different models:
Passenger Rickshaw: Carries 2‚Äì3 passengers. Ideal for campus shuttle. Cargo Rickshaw: Used for transporting goods. Useful in markets or rural delivery. Modular Rickshaw: Can be modified between passenger and cargo modes. Solar Rickshaw: Powered partly by solar panels to increase range. Your budget, team size, and available resources will help you decide the model.
Components You‚Äôll Need to Build Your E-Rickshaw 1. Motor
BLDC (Brushless DC) motor Rear hub motor or chain drive Power: 1000W‚Äì1500W for rural roads and slopes 2. Battery Pack
Lithium-ion (48V or 60V) preferred over lead-acid Capacity: 30Ah to 50Ah depending on range 3. Controller
Must match the voltage and wattage of the motor Handles throttle, power delivery, and sometimes regenerative braking 4. Throttle and Brakes
Twist throttle with display Brake switches for safety 5. Frame or Chassis
Mild steel or aluminium tubing Either design your own or repurpose an old chassis 6. Wheels and Suspension
Use three wheels: two rear and one front Add telescopic suspension in front and spring-loaded rear suspension 7. Lights and Indicators
Headlight, tail light, turn indicators, reflectors 8. Smart Features (Optional but recommended)
GPS module USB charging port Solar panel on roof Battery display Tools and Materials Required Welding machine Wire cutter and crimping tools Drill machine Screwdriver and wrench set Multimeter Battery charger (Li-ion compatible) Safety gloves, glasses, and fuse box Budgeting Your E-Rickshaw Project Here‚Äôs a realistic budget estimate for a smart e-rickshaw project built in an Indian college setup:
Component <th> Approximate Cost (INR) </th> BLDC Motor (1500W) <td> ‚Çπ10,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ15,000 </td> Lithium-ion Battery (48V, 30Ah) <td> ‚Çπ18,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ25,000 </td> Controller Kit <td> ‚Çπ2,500 ‚Äì ‚Çπ4,000 </td> Steel Frame (Raw or Recycled) <td> ‚Çπ8,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ12,000 </td> Suspension + Wheels <td> ‚Çπ5,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ7,000 </td> Lights and Indicators <td> ‚Çπ1,500 ‚Äì ‚Çπ2,000 </td> Smart Features <td> ‚Çπ5,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ8,000 </td> Wiring, Tools, Fasteners <td> ‚Çπ2,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ3,000 </td> Total <td> <strong>‚Çπ50,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ70,000</strong> </td> Reduce cost by sourcing second-hand parts, using your college workshop, or getting local sponsorship.
Designing the Chassis and Body Draw the layout of your frame before fabrication. Make sure the weight is balanced between front and rear. Allow enough space under the seat or floorboard for battery placement. Use rust-free paint or powder coating to prevent corrosion. For passenger models, add weatherproof canopy and hand grips. Step-by-Step Build Process Step 1: Fabricate the Frame Weld or bolt together your steel tubes into a 3-wheel design. Ensure proper width for stability.
Step 2: Install Motor and Wheels Mount the BLDC motor in the rear hub or attach chain-sprocket if using external motor. Fix wheels.
Step 3: Set Up Battery Pack Place the battery in a waterproof box. Fix securely to avoid vibrations. Ensure proper ventilation.
Step 4: Wiring the Controller Connect battery to controller, motor, throttle, and display. Use heat-shrink insulation for safety.
Step 5: Add Lights, Horn, and Dashboard Connect DC-DC converter to run 12V systems like indicators, headlights, USB charger.
Step 6: Smart Integration (Optional) Add GPS tracker using GSM module. Install solar panel and connect to charge controller and battery.
Step 7: Testing Perform dry testing (without wheels on ground). Then do real test runs in open area. Check speed, braking, battery response.
Performance and Range Your range depends on battery size and load. A 48V, 30Ah battery will run about 40‚Äì50 km with moderate load. Use a charge indicator to track usage.
Speed limit can be adjusted via the controller. For campus or village use, keep max speed around 25‚Äì30 km/h.
Safety Checklist Fuse between battery and controller Proper braking system Working headlights and indicators Rainproof wiring insulation Helmets for test rides Fire extinguisher near charging point Legal Requirements for Road Use If the vehicle is used only on private land or inside the campus, no RTO approval is needed. But for public road use:
Use ARAI or ICAT certified conversion kits Register the vehicle at local RTO Update fuel type and get new insurance Adhere to road-worthy rules like mirrors, speed limiters, seat belts Where to Buy Components in India Robu.in (EV parts) EVparts.in Amazon India Local scooter scrap markets Batterywale Buy from trusted sources and always ask for warranty and datasheets.
Student Success Stories IIT Delhi students built a solar-powered cargo e-rickshaw which was later adopted for use in Ladakh. MIT Pune developed an e-rickshaw fleet for campus transport, managed via mobile app. SRM University students added smart diagnostic modules to their rickshaw and won at Smart India Hackathon. Your project could be next.
How to Present This Project in Competitions Include cost-benefit comparison (electric vs petrol) Create a 3-minute project pitch video Print posters showing wiring diagrams, solar integration, and battery layout Include safety SOP document and risk mitigation plan Record performance results: range, charging time, speed Startup Potential: Can You Scale This Idea? Yes. Rural logistics, hyperlocal delivery, and even school transport in Tier 2/3 cities can use this model. With a solar roof and GPS-based control, your rickshaw could be the future of affordable, smart mobility in India.
You can:
Apply for incubation grants Launch a startup for EV assembly or retrofitting Build rental EV fleets for rural mobility Conclusion: Take the Driver‚Äôs Seat in India‚Äôs EV Journey An electric rickshaw may look simple from the outside, but designing and building one gives you deep knowledge of what powers India‚Äôs EV movement. As a student, you‚Äôll learn electrical systems, build mechanical structures, and develop smart features.
You‚Äôre not just building a vehicle‚Äîyou‚Äôre building your future.
Have a smart e-rickshaw project in progress? Submit your story with photos to avmedianews321@gmail.com and we‚Äôll feature it on EVBlogs.in to inspire thousands of students like you.

Introduction: Why Build a Solar Electric Delivery Cart? India‚Äôs roads are buzzing with delivery vehicles‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs for groceries, e-commerce, school supplies, or hostel essentials. But many of these vehicles still run on fuel, creating pollution and high operating costs. Now imagine a vehicle that is small, efficient, doesn‚Äôt require petrol or diesel, and charges using sunlight.
This is where a solar-powered electric delivery cart becomes the perfect solution.
As a college student, building one offers a powerful mix of learning and real-world application. Whether for a project submission, startup prototype, or Smart India Hackathon entry, this project hits all the right notes: sustainability, innovation, and utility.
This blog will guide you step by step to build your own solar electric cart‚Äîcomplete with components, frame design, wiring, testing, budgeting, and how to pitch it for maximum impact.
Why a Solar EV Cart Is a Great Student Project This isn‚Äôt just a theoretical idea. Colleges, rural vendors, and even small-scale logistics startups can use such a cart daily.
You‚Äôll learn and apply:
Solar energy systems BLDC motors and EV wiring Battery charging cycles Load balancing and mechanical design GPS, IoT, and smart alert integration It‚Äôs perfect for mechanical, electrical, electronics, and even computer science students looking to collaborate on an interdisciplinary innovation.
Ideal Use Cases for Solar EV Carts in India Campus Deliveries: Canteen to hostel food cart, library book courier, or store supplies. Rural Last-Mile Delivery: Carrying fruits, vegetables, groceries, and medicine from kirana shops. Mobile Medical Units: Rural clinics on wheels for small equipment and first-aid. Solar-Powered Trolleys in Industrial Units: Carrying parts from one department to another. Livelihood Support: For rural entrepreneurs delivering milk, tools, or household goods. Components You‚Äôll Need for Your Solar Delivery Cart 1. Motor BLDC motor (500W‚Äì1000W depending on load) Hub motor or external drive with chain/sprocket 2. Battery Pack Lithium-ion battery (48V, 30Ah‚Äì40Ah) Can also use two 12V batteries in series for budget projects 3. Solar Panel 300W to 500W Monocrystalline panels Charge in 5‚Äì6 hours of good sunlight 4. Charge Controller (MPPT preferred) Manages charging efficiency Prevents overcharging and deep discharge 5. Frame & Chassis Mild steel or aluminium tubing Designed to carry 100‚Äì150 kg load 6. Controller + Throttle Speed regulation Brake cut-off Optional display for battery, speed, temperature 7. Dashboard and Features Speedometer Mobile charging port GPS unit Load sensors (optional) 8. Accessories LED headlight and brake light Indicators and horn Suspension (if rough terrain) Tools and Workshop Setup Welding machine Drilling tools and metal cutters Wire stripper and crimping tool Soldering kit Multimeter Solar panel stand or adjustable mount Make sure you work in a well-ventilated, supervised environment‚Äîpreferably your college‚Äôs mechanical or electrical workshop.
Choosing the Right Motor and Battery Combo For light delivery (up to 75 kg):
500W BLDC motor 48V, 24Ah battery For medium-duty delivery (75‚Äì120 kg):
750W‚Äì1000W motor 48V or 60V, 30Ah‚Äì40Ah battery Estimated Range:
30‚Äì45 km on one full charge Charging Time via Solar Panel:
4 to 6 hours in direct sunlight Budget Estimate (Student-Friendly) {.wp-block-heading} Component <th> Cost (INR) </th> 500W‚Äì1000W Motor Kit <td> ‚Çπ7,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ12,000 </td> 48V Lithium Battery <td> ‚Çπ18,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ25,000 </td> Solar Panel (300W‚Äì500W) <td> ‚Çπ10,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ15,000 </td> MPPT Charge Controller <td> ‚Çπ2,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ3,000 </td> Frame + Welding <td> ‚Çπ6,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ8,000 </td> Wiring and Lights <td> ‚Çπ2,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ3,000 </td> Dashboard + Features <td> ‚Çπ2,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ4,000 </td> Total Estimate <td> <strong>‚Çπ47,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ70,000</strong> </td> Step-by-Step Assembly Guide Step 1: Design the Frame
Sketch layout: motor mount, cargo bed, panel space Allocate space for battery and electronics Step 2: Build Chassis
Weld tubing as per dimensions Fix wheelbase and balance Step 3: Install the Motor and Wheels
Fit hub motor in rear wheel or chain drive to axle Ensure motor is aligned and securely fastened Step 4: Mount Battery Pack
Enclose in waterproof box Add foam padding to absorb vibration Step 5: Wire Controller and Throttle
Connect all components Use fuse and circuit breaker for safety Step 6: Install Solar Panel on Roof Frame
Fix at an angle for maximum sunlight Connect to charge controller and battery Step 7: Add Dashboard Features
Install voltmeter, speed display, USB port, etc. Step 8: Test and Calibrate
Check throttle response, battery discharge, and sunlight charging efficiency Smart Features to Make Your Project Stand Out GPS Tracker: Monitor delivery location and anti-theft Bluetooth App Control: Lock/unlock or monitor battery via phone Solar Monitoring Display: Track how much power is generated and used Weight Sensor: Alerts if cargo limit is exceeded Mobile Charging Station: Deliver power and products Where to Buy Components in India EV Parts: Robu.in, EVparts.in, Batterywale, Amazon India Solar Gear: Loom Solar, UTL Solar, Luminous Distributors Mechanical Supplies: Local scrap yards, metal market, or college workshop inventory Safety Guidelines for Assembly and Use Fuse between battery and motor Use insulated connectors and clips Add a fire extinguisher near the charging zone Test indoors first, then do road testing in open space Don‚Äôt use in heavy rain unless waterproofed Presenting This Project in Competitions or Grants Create a 3-minute video demo Use a cost-saving vs petrol cart chart Display solar energy contribution statistics Print wiring diagram and performance charts Submit for innovation challenges and college expos Real Student Project Examples VIT Vellore: Students built a solar milk delivery cart for farmers in Erode IIT Roorkee: Created a modular EV cart for on-campus parcel transport Jamia Millia Islamia: Solar-assisted garbage collection cart for Delhi localities Startup and Incubation Potential Your solar delivery cart can turn into:
Campus logistics solution (rent-a-cart) Rural delivery network for kirana stores Partnership with Swiggy/BigBasket/local milk vendors Tie-ups with Gram Panchayats for daily needs delivery Pitch to:
Atal Incubation Centres MSME Innovation Fund Startup India programs FAME India (for EV components) Conclusion: Be the Change in Sustainable Mobility When you build a solar-powered delivery cart, you‚Äôre not just making a college project‚Äîyou‚Äôre contributing to India‚Äôs clean energy future.
This single innovation teaches you mechanical assembly, solar energy, electric drive systems, circuit protection, and sustainable transport‚Äîall in one real-world, hands-on project.
You could help deliver more than just goods. You‚Äôll be delivering solutions.

Introduction: Why Electric Cargo Bikes Are Gaining Global Momentum In cities like Amsterdam, Berlin, and London, electric cargo bikes have become the go-to choice for delivery services, food vendors, and eco-conscious families. They are compact, efficient, and‚Äîmost importantly‚Äîemission-free. But here‚Äôs the exciting part: this idea has huge potential in India too.
If you‚Äôre a college student in India looking for a real-world, globally inspired project, building an electric cargo bike is not only innovative but also impactful. This project can help solve urban delivery issues, create startup opportunities, and promote clean mobility‚Äîall while teaching you the fundamentals of EV technology.
In this blog, we‚Äôll walk you through every aspect of building your own electric cargo bike as a college project: design, components, costs, assembly, smart upgrades, safety tips, and how to pitch it in competitions and grants. Let‚Äôs get started.
Why Build an Electric Cargo Bike as a Student Project? An electric cargo bike project is the perfect fusion of global trends and local needs. Here‚Äôs why this project makes sense for Indian students:
Encourages hands-on learning in electric mobility and sustainable design. Ideal for Smart India Hackathon, college exhibitions, and final-year engineering projects. Promotes entrepreneurship through low-cost delivery innovation. Combines mechanical, electrical, electronics, and business model elements. Aligns with India‚Äôs goals under the FAME II scheme and urban EV mobility plans. What Is an Electric Cargo Bike? An electric cargo bike is a bicycle equipped with a motor and a cargo space, capable of carrying goods, groceries, or even passengers. It‚Äôs powered by a battery and typically has two or three wheels for better balance when loaded.
Common types include:
Front-loading bikes (Long John style) Rear cargo rack bikes Trike-based cargo bikes (Three wheels for balance) For student projects, a rear-rack or trike-style design is easier to build and customize.
International Models and How They Inspire Indian Adaptation Urban Arrow (Netherlands): Electric front-loading cargo bikes used by DHL and postal services. Tern GSD (USA): Compact two-wheeler with battery-assist and foldable design. RadWagon (USA): Rear-cargo utility bike popular among food delivery startups. These models prove that cargo bikes can be efficient alternatives to petrol-powered scooters or vans. India‚Äôs crowded lanes, short-distance deliveries, and growing e-commerce network make it the perfect ground for such solutions.
Ideal Use Cases in India Campus deliveries (canteen, stationery, parcels) Local grocery and vegetable delivery E-commerce and courier delivery in narrow lanes Milk and newspaper delivery in residential areas Municipal service bikes (waste collection, water tankers) Solar-powered carts for farmers‚Äô markets Your project can directly address any of these needs, especially in Tier 2 and Tier 3 cities.
Components You‚Äôll Need to Build the Cargo Bike Here‚Äôs what you‚Äôll need to assemble a functional electric cargo bike:
1. Frame
Bicycle or custom-built cargo bike frame Rear rack or cargo basket design 2. Motor
BLDC hub motor (250W‚Äì500W) Rear wheel integration 3. Battery Pack
Lithium-ion battery (36V or 48V) 10Ah to 20Ah depending on range 4. Controller + Throttle
Matches battery and motor ratings With pedal-assist sensor (PAS) 5. Pedal Assist System (PAS)
Automatically adjusts motor support based on pedaling 6. Cargo Compartment
Wooden or metal crate Custom-built box with lid 7. Suspension and Brakes
Front fork suspension Disc or drum brakes for safety 8. Display Meter and Lights
LCD display for speed and battery LED headlight and brake light 9. Solar Integration (Optional)
50W‚Äì100W flexible solar panel Charge controller and mount Tools Required Welding machine and grinder Spanner set, screwdriver kit Wire cutter and crimping tool Multimeter for voltage checks Battery charger (lithium-compatible) Budget Estimate (Student-Friendly) {.wp-block-heading} Item <th> Approximate Cost (INR) </th> BLDC Hub Motor (250W) <td> ‚Çπ4,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ6,000 </td> Lithium-ion Battery (36V, 15Ah) <td> ‚Çπ8,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ12,000 </td> Controller + Throttle Kit <td> ‚Çπ1,500 ‚Äì ‚Çπ2,500 </td> Cargo Frame & Fabrication <td> ‚Çπ4,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ6,000 </td> Suspension & Brakes <td> ‚Çπ2,500 ‚Äì ‚Çπ3,500 </td> LCD Display + Lights <td> ‚Çπ1,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ1,500 </td> Pedal Assist Sensor <td> ‚Çπ500 ‚Äì ‚Çπ700 </td> Solar Panel + Charge Controller <td> ‚Çπ3,500 ‚Äì ‚Çπ5,000 (optional) </td> Total Estimate <td> <strong>‚Çπ25,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ38,000</strong> </td> Step-by-Step Build Process Step 1: Frame Design and Fabrication
Start with a strong bicycle frame or fabricate a custom one. Weld or bolt cargo carrier to rear or front side. Ensure load balance and low center of gravity. Step 2: Install Motor and Wheel Assembly
Replace rear wheel with hub motor wheel. Check spoke alignment and tension. Step 3: Battery Placement and Wiring
Fix battery pack below cargo box or near center frame. Connect controller, throttle, and PAS unit. Step 4: Add Cargo Compartment
Use wood, aluminum sheet, or fiberboard Secure cargo using bungee cords or lid mechanism Step 5: Integrate Solar Panel (Optional)
Mount panel on roof frame or cargo lid Use solar charge controller to avoid overcharging Step 6: Final Wiring and Testing
Connect display meter, headlight, and brakes Test all connections with multimeter before switching on Step 7: Field Test
Check pickup, turning radius, cargo stability, braking distance Test range on full charge under different loads Smart Features to Add GPS tracking with SIM card module Mobile charging port for delivery use Load weight sensor and alert system Bluetooth unlock feature Anti-theft alarm or wheel lock Real-Life Student Projects from India IIT Hyderabad: Solar electric bike for intra-campus waste collection Amrita University: Dual cargo bike for delivery and agricultural transport SRM Institute: Lightweight last-mile cargo bike with regenerative braking These projects have received grants from DST and Smart India Hackathon.
Safety and Testing Guidelines Always fuse between battery and controller Use reflector strips and proper lighting Avoid loose wiring near cargo area Add rainproofing if used in monsoon Perform brake tests with full load How to Present the Project Prepare a poster showing technical diagrams Print a wiring chart, CAD design, and parts list Record a 2-minute working demo video Show cost comparison vs. petrol scooter delivery Create a simple pitch deck for startup potential Government Grants and Startup Support Atal Incubation Mission (AIM) Startup India Seed Fund Scheme State MSME boards College innovation cells CSR grants from EV companies or logistics firms Conclusion: Deliver the Future with Pedal Power An electric cargo bike is not just a student project‚Äîit‚Äôs a functional, scalable innovation that solves real problems. It‚Äôs eco-friendly, budget-friendly, and fits perfectly into India‚Äôs dense, busy delivery landscape.
As a student, this project can launch your career in the EV industry, spark a micro-startup, or win you awards at innovation challenges. Start now, build it step by step, and take your idea from classroom to real roads.
Have a working electric cargo bike or prototype? Share your project and photos with us at avmedianews321@gmail.com and get featured on EVBlogs.in.
