Introduction: Why Build Your Own Electric Bike? The electric bike (e-bike) revolution is happening across India. Whether it‚Äôs delivery partners in cities, college students riding to class, or tech-savvy commuters avoiding petrol bills‚Äîeveryone is exploring electric two-wheelers. But buying a new e-bike can be expensive.
As a college student, imagine taking an old cycle or a lightweight petrol moped and converting it into a fully functioning electric bike. Not only is it budget-friendly, but it‚Äôs also a fantastic hands-on learning project that teaches you real engineering skills: wiring, battery systems, motor control, energy optimization, and more.
This guide will help you plan, build, test, and showcase your electric bike conversion project using locally available components‚Äîall with a student budget and a practical, India-ready mindset.
Why This Project Makes Sense for Students Saves money: Build an e-bike for ‚Çπ25,000 or less. Great for college expos, final-year engineering projects, or startup ideas. Helps understand India‚Äôs booming electric mobility sector. Ideal for city, rural, and even campus-only usage. Combines mechanical, electrical, electronics, and programming skills. Start With a Clear Use Case Before you build, decide how and where the bike will be used:
Campus rides (short distances, low load) Urban commuting (traffic handling, range optimization) Rural roads (shock absorbers, extra load) Last-mile delivery (cargo box at rear) Your use case will help you select the right motor, battery, frame, and features.
Choosing the Right Donor Bike Start with a strong, lightweight, and rust-free cycle or moped. Your options:
Mountain Bike (MTB): Good for rough terrain and budget builds. Road/Hybrid Cycle: Best for speed and smooth rides. Old Moped (like Luna or TVS XL): Sturdier frame and larger tires. Make sure the frame has:
Space for battery mounting (under seat or inside triangle) Enough strength to handle motor torque and battery weight Strong fork and rear stays to handle hub motor Motor Selection: Hub or Mid-Drive? You‚Äôll choose between two main motor types:
1. Hub Motor (Rear or Front Wheel) Easy to install Less complicated wiring Best for flat terrains and city rides 2. Mid-Drive Motor (Crank Area) Better weight distribution Uses existing gears‚Äîgood for hilly areas Slightly more complex installation For student projects, rear hub motors (250W to 500W) are affordable and effective.
Battery Selection: Powering Your Ride The battery is your fuel tank. Choose based on your required range and weight handling.
Popular Battery Options: 36V 10Ah: Range ~25‚Äì35 km; compact, lightweight 48V 15Ah: Range ~50‚Äì60 km; heavier but higher performance Lithium-ion batteries are recommended over lead-acid. Look for:
Integrated BMS (Battery Management System) Waterproof casing Brackets for mounting Core Components Checklist BLDC Hub Motor (250W or 500W) Lithium-ion Battery (36V or 48V) Controller (compatible with voltage and motor) Throttle (thumb or twist grip) Pedal Assist Sensor (PAS) E-brakes (auto-cut feature) LCD Display (for speed, voltage) Wiring Harness and Connectors Optional:
Headlight and tail light Horn USB mobile charging port Tools and Equipment Needed Basic hand tools (screwdriver, spanner, plier) Multimeter Drill and clamps Cable ties and heat shrink tubes Soldering iron Battery charger (based on battery type) Budget Estimation (As per Indian Market) {.wp-block-heading} Component <th> Approx. Cost (INR) </th> Hub Motor (250W‚Äì500W) <td> ‚Çπ4,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ6,000 </td> Lithium-ion Battery (48V) <td> ‚Çπ8,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ12,000 </td> Controller + Throttle Kit <td> ‚Çπ1,500 ‚Äì ‚Çπ2,500 </td> Pedal Assist System <td> ‚Çπ500 ‚Äì ‚Çπ800 </td> E-brakes + LCD Display <td> ‚Çπ1,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ1,800 </td> Frame/Donor Bike <td> ‚Çπ2,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ4,000 </td> Wiring and Fittings <td> ‚Çπ1,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ1,500 </td> Lights, Horn, Accessories <td> ‚Çπ800 ‚Äì ‚Çπ1,200 </td> Total Estimate <td> <strong>‚Çπ20,000 ‚Äì ‚Çπ30,000</strong> </td> Step-by-Step Assembly Process Step 1: Strip and Clean the Donor Bike
Remove any unwanted accessories or broken parts. Clean and repaint frame if needed. Step 2: Install Hub Motor Wheel
Replace rear or front wheel with motor-integrated wheel. Check wheel alignment and tighten spokes if needed. Step 3: Mount the Battery
Fix using battery rack, cage, or custom welded box. Ensure it‚Äôs secure and vibration-free. Step 4: Wiring and Controller Setup
Mount controller under seat or inside triangle. Connect motor, throttle, PAS, and brakes to controller. Test all wires with multimeter before final fit. Step 5: Install Display and Controls
Fit LCD display on handlebar. Connect throttle, brakes, and headlight controls. Step 6: Final Test and Calibration
Do dry test (on stand) before road test. Ride slowly and check throttle, PAS, brakes. Note voltage drop and motor heating after short rides. Smart Features You Can Add GPS tracking via SIM card module Bluetooth connectivity for ride data Solar trickle charging for battery (via panel on rear rack) Voice control or app-based lock/unlock Regenerative braking (advanced) Safety and Testing Guidelines Always use fuse and circuit breaker between battery and controller Insulate all terminals and use proper connectors Keep battery away from direct rain Check e-brake cut-off before every ride Install reflective tape for night visibility How to Present the Project Prepare technical poster and cost breakdown chart Create demo video with GPS path and range stats Print before-after photos of bike Include use case (e.g., food delivery, campus rides) Submit for student competitions or display in college startup showcase Real Student Examples VJTI Mumbai students converted an old Hero cycle into a 60 km range e-bike with smartphone control. IIT Guwahati team added solar panel and regenerative braking to a local cargo e-bike. Chandigarh University team built an e-bike fleet for campus shuttle using low-cost kits. Startup and Funding Potential Offer retrofitting kits to local students or delivery boys Collaborate with kirana shops for last-mile delivery e-bikes Apply for Startup India grants or Atal Innovation Mission Present to CSR teams of EV companies like Ola Electric, Ather, or Ampere Conclusion: Your Journey Starts With One Bike By converting a regular bike into an electric bike, you‚Äôre not just saving money‚Äîyou‚Äôre stepping into India‚Äôs electric mobility revolution. This project builds your technical, creative, and entrepreneurial skills. It‚Äôs eco-friendly, locally relevant, and full of potential.
Whether it‚Äôs for your college, your community, or your first business idea‚Äîthis e-bike conversion can take you places.

Introduction: Why Build a Foldable Electric Scooter? Indian cities are becoming more crowded each day, and the need for efficient, compact, and clean transport has never been more urgent. Foldable electric scooters are already making waves globally for their sleek design and last-mile convenience. But here‚Äôs the exciting part‚Äîyou can build one yourself.
As a college student, this project is not just an opportunity to learn practical EV design. It‚Äôs a chance to create a usable, lightweight vehicle that can be carried into metros, stored under desks, or ridden through campus without burning a drop of fuel. It‚Äôs simple, practical, and future-ready.
In this guide, we‚Äôll help you plan, design, and assemble your own foldable electric scooter. We‚Äôll also show you how to optimize for weight, safety, range, and urban usage‚Äîwhile staying within a student budget.
Why This Project Makes Sense for Students Learn real-world EV concepts like portability, weight distribution, and energy efficiency Perfect for Smart India Hackathon, final-year engineering project, or startup idea Great YouTube content or documentation potential Extremely relevant to India‚Äôs urban commuting challenges Low investment, high usability Key Use Cases in India Last-mile transport from metro/bus to college Campus commuting (especially in IITs, SRM, VITs) Startups focusing on compact rental mobility Delivery boys needing a secondary vehicle Elderly or differently abled individuals in gated communities Frame Design and Foldability ‚Äì Engineering a Compact Ride Foldability is the core innovation. Here‚Äôs what your frame must do:
Collapse in one or two motion points Lock tightly when riding Unlock safely without pinch risk Materials:
Aluminium 6061 (lightweight, durable) Mild steel (heavier but easy to weld) Carbon fiber (costly, but futuristic) Mechanisms:
Handlebar folding latch Rear frame hinge Footpeg and base lock Keep final weight under 18 kg for easy carrying.
Selecting the Right Motor Choose a hub motor (BLDC) for compactness. Mount it directly on the front or rear wheel.
Options:
250W 24V ‚Äì Ideal for flat urban roads 350W 36V ‚Äì Handles minor slopes, better acceleration Make sure:
Motor fits wheel rim diameter (usually 8″ or 10″) Voltage matches battery Waterproof rating if riding outdoors Battery Selection: Balance Range and Weight Use lithium-ion battery packs. Keep it light but enough to power 15‚Äì25 km range.
Best configurations:
36V 10Ah ‚Äì Around 20 km range 48V 7.5Ah ‚Äì More torque, 25‚Äì30 km range Look for:
BMS (Battery Management System) Fast charging (2‚Äì3 hours max) Compact casing for under-deck mounting Full Components List BLDC Hub Motor (250W‚Äì350W) Lithium-ion Battery Pack (36V) Motor Controller Throttle with Battery Indicator Folding Handlebar System Aluminium/Steel Frame Tubing Foldable Footrest E-Brakes with Cut-Off LED Headlight + Brake Light DC-DC Converter (if adding USB charger) Side Stand Display Panel (optional) Tools You‚Äôll Need Welding Machine / Riveting Tools Soldering Iron + Heat Shrink Tubing Drill and Bits for Steel/Aluminium Spanner, Screwdriver Set Multimeter Battery Charger (36V or 48V as per pack) Step-by-Step Build Instructions Step 1: Design the Frame on Paper Sketch your idea. contents:
India‚Äôs transition to electric mobility is not just about reducing carbon emissions ‚Äî it‚Äôs a strategic move to curb fuel imports, improve air quality, and become a global leader in EV technology. To make this happen, the Government of India has rolled out several electric vehicle policies that provide financial incentives, tax benefits, infrastructure support, and ease of doing business for EV manufacturers, fleet operators, charging companies, and startups.
If you‚Äôre planning to enter the EV industry ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs two-wheelers, charging stations, battery swapping, or electric logistics ‚Äî understanding these government initiatives can help you plan and grow faster.
Let‚Äôs break it down in simple terms.
1. National Electric Mobility Mission Plan (NEMMP) Launched: 2013 | Target Year: 2020 (continued through later policies) The NEMMP was the first major EV policy in India aimed at creating a roadmap for electric and hybrid mobility.
Key Highlights: ‚Çπ14,000 crore outlay planned to promote electric and hybrid vehicles Aimed to achieve national fuel security by promoting EV adoption Focused on R&D, manufacturing, and demand generation Led to the birth of FAME India Scheme 2. Faster Adoption and Manufacturing of Hybrid and Electric Vehicles (FAME India Scheme) Phase 1: 2015‚Äì2019 | Phase 2: 2019‚ÄìMarch 2024 (Extended) This is India‚Äôs flagship scheme for EV promotion under the Ministry of Heavy Industries.
FAME II Scheme Overview: Total outlay: ‚Çπ10,000 crore Focus on electric 2-wheelers, 3-wheelers, 4-wheelers, buses Direct subsidies on vehicles (based on battery size ‚Çπ15,000/kWh for 2Ws) Focus on public transportation & commercial vehicles Support for charging infrastructure in urban areas Beneficiaries: EV Manufacturers Fleet Operators (like Ola, Uber, delivery services) Public Transport Agencies Private EV Buyers (mostly 2Ws and 3Ws) 3. Production Linked Incentive (PLI) Schemes for EV Sector Launched: 2021‚Äì2022 | Managed by: Ministry of Heavy Industries India has introduced two critical PLI schemes aimed at EVs:
a) PLI Scheme for Automobile and Auto Components Outlay: ‚Çπ25,938 crore Incentives for companies manufacturing electric vehicles and advanced auto components Focus on local value addition, job creation, and export competitiveness b) PLI for Advanced Chemistry Cell (ACC) Battery Storage Outlay: ‚Çπ18,100 crore Boosting domestic manufacturing of Li-ion batteries Key for EV battery packs, swapping infrastructure, and cost reduction These PLIs aim to make India self-reliant in EV supply chain and technology.
4. State-Level EV Policies in India Many Indian states have their own custom EV policies aligned with the national mission.
Common Incentives Across States: Purchase subsidies per kWh of battery capacity Scrappage incentives for old petrol/diesel vehicles Road tax exemption (100% in most states) Registration fee waiver Capital subsidies for setting up charging stations Electricity tariff discounts for EV charging businesses Best Performing States with EV Policies: Delhi: 25% subsidy on e-bikes, scrappage benefits, dedicated EV cell Maharashtra: ‚Çπ10,000 subsidy per EV, early-bird incentives Tamil Nadu: 100% road tax exemption, support for EV clusters Gujarat: Subsidies for 2Ws, 3Ws, e-cars; EV component hubs Karnataka: Pioneer in EV policy; offers battery parks, land support Telangana & Andhra Pradesh: Focus on EV manufacturing hubs 5. Battery Swapping Policy (Draft by NITI Aayog) Recognizing the challenge of charging time, the government introduced a Battery Swapping Policy for interoperability and quick turnaround for fleet vehicles.
Policy Highlights: Standardization of battery packs & connectors Encouragement of Battery-as-a-Service (BaaS) model Benefits for last-mile delivery companies, e-rickshaws, and 3Ws Private players like Sun Mobility, BatterySmart welcomed This policy opens up a whole new business segment in EV infrastructure.
6. Charging Infrastructure Guidelines (MoP) The Ministry of Power (MoP) has created detailed charging infrastructure guidelines to promote the growth of public and private EV chargers.
Key Provisions: No license required for EV charging station setup DISCOMs must provide connections in 7 days (urban) / 15 days (rural) Single-window clearances via online portals Time-of-Day tariffs for public chargers (cheaper during off-peak) Public charging station every 3 km in cities, every 25 km on highways Key Focus: Public Private Partnership (PPP) model City-wide master planning by ULBs and state agencies Charging infra for housing societies, malls, offices, parking lots 7. EV Business & Startup Opportunities Supported by Policy If you‚Äôre planning to start an EV-related business, government policy is already enabling the following areas:
Business Ideas Backed by Policy: EV Dealerships & Distribution Battery swapping stations Home charging installation services EV leasing & financing Fleet electrification (cargo/logistics) EV aggregators (e-bikes, 3W delivery) Smart charging software & billing EV retrofitting kits for old scooters and cars Many of these are eligible for subsidies, soft loans, and state incentives.
8. GST and Tax Benefits for EV Businesses The government has aligned the taxation policy to support EV adoption and manufacturing:
Key Tax Benefits: GST on EVs reduced to 5% (compared to 28% on petrol/diesel) GST on charging equipment is 5% Income tax deduction up to ‚Çπ1.5 lakh on interest for EV loans under Section 80EEB (for individuals) EV startups can apply for tax holiday under Startup India norms These tax benefits lower the overall cost of ownership and operations, making it easier to scale.
9. Green Energy Integration with EV Policies To promote clean charging, the government is integrating solar, wind, and bio-energy policies into the EV ecosystem.
Renewable Synergy Support: EV charging stations allowed to install solar panels Net metering allowed for home chargers Dedicated solar park zones for EV charging corridors States like Gujarat, Rajasthan promoting solar EV hubs Green charging is expected to be a big trend in 2025‚Äì2030 as more consumers seek zero-emission lifestyle solutions.
10. Institutional Support and EV Cells Multiple departments are working in sync to build India‚Äôs EV future.
Key Institutions Supporting EV Policy: NITI Aayog ‚Äì Policy think tank & roadmap creator Ministry of Heavy Industries (MHI) ‚Äì Core EV schemes (FAME, PLI) Ministry of Power (MoP) ‚Äì Charging infra & power distribution Bureau of Energy Efficiency (BEE) ‚Äì Urban EV implementation cell State Transport Departments ‚Äì Registration and subsidy management State Nodal Agencies ‚Äì EV portals, business facilitation 11. Startup India & Make in India Incentives Startups working on EV technology, battery innovation, software platforms, and logistics electrification can register under Startup India.
Advantages: Access to seed funding Relaxed public procurement norms Tax holidays Patent & IP support Under Make in India, there‚Äôs a major push to localize motor controllers, power electronics, and battery packs ‚Äî all of which are business opportunities.
12. Future Roadmap: What to Expect in 2025‚Äì2030 Here‚Äôs what is expected from the government in the next 5 years:
FAME III Policy with a focus on private 4-wheelers and commercial fleet scaling Mandating EV-only sales by certain timelines (under discussion) Nationwide charging station mapping via apps Integrated EV policy that combines mobility + energy + digital ecosystem Focus on indigenous battery chemistries like Sodium-ion and Solid-State Launch of EV finance platforms for easy loans and leasing Conclusion: Policy is the Foundation of India‚Äôs EV Revolution India‚Äôs EV ecosystem is growing rapidly, and government policy is not just support ‚Äî it‚Äôs a full-blown ecosystem catalyst. Whether you‚Äôre an entrepreneur, an OEM, a service provider, or a young startup, these policies can fuel your growth with the right roadmap and incentives.
From central subsidies to state-specific grants, and from PLI schemes to renewable integration ‚Äî the Indian government is laying the groundwork for an EV-first future.

contents:
When we talk about the future of mobility in India, one policy that laid the groundwork for the entire electric vehicle (EV) ecosystem is the National Electric Mobility Mission Plan, also known as NEMMP. Whether you‚Äôre an entrepreneur planning to enter the EV business, an investor looking into the clean-tech space, or simply curious about how the Indian government is supporting the electric vehicle revolution, this guide will help you understand everything about NEMMP.
From its origin story to the latest schemes built upon it, and a step-by-step walkthrough of how to claim its benefits, we‚Äôve broken down this plan in the simplest way possible. If you‚Äôre serious about contributing to or benefiting from India‚Äôs EV sector, read on.
What is the National Electric Mobility Mission Plan (NEMMP)? The National Electric Mobility Mission Plan (NEMMP) is a government initiative launched in 2013 by the Ministry of Heavy Industries (MHI). It was designed as a long-term mission with the goal of promoting electric and hybrid vehicles in the country. The ultimate vision? To reduce India‚Äôs dependency on imported oil, cut down vehicular emissions, and make India a global hub for EV manufacturing.
In a country where urban pollution is rising and the cost of fuel eats up a significant chunk of the average household budget, promoting electric mobility was a natural step. But this policy wasn‚Äôt just about the environment or fuel savings‚Äîit was about building a sustainable industrial sector.
Key Objectives of NEMMP The government didn‚Äôt just draft the NEMMP for the sake of launching another policy. It was crafted with specific, high-impact goals:
Fuel Security: India imports nearly 80% of its crude oil. EV adoption reduces our fuel bill substantially. Environmental Health: By cutting down vehicular emissions, the plan aims to improve air quality, especially in metro cities. Manufacturing Growth: With an eye on Make in India, NEMMP encourages local production of EVs and components. Technology Innovation: R&D investments in battery technology, vehicle design, and charging solutions. Job Creation: A flourishing EV sector means opportunities in design, manufacturing, servicing, infrastructure, and software development. Timeline and Phases of NEMMP When the plan was first introduced in 2013, it was envisioned as a phased initiative:
Phase 1 (2013‚Äì2020): Focus on research, initial infrastructure, and early incentives Phase 2 (2020 onwards): Building on the progress of Phase 1, introducing large-scale adoption programs like FAME (Faster Adoption and Manufacturing of Hybrid and Electric Vehicles) Today, even though NEMMP is not spoken about as actively as newer schemes like FAME or PLI, it still remains the backbone that shaped all of these programs.
Salient Features of the NEMMP Comprehensive Framework The NEMMP isn‚Äôt a standalone scheme with a few subsidies. It is a broad policy framework that aligns multiple departments, ministries, and policies.
Multi-Sectoral Focus It brings together ministries of Heavy Industries, Power, Urban Development, Environment, Finance, and Road Transport.
Investment Commitment The initial budget estimate was Rs. 14,000 crore, with both public and private participation.
Research & Innovation Funding was allocated for battery innovation, vehicle testing, and development of indigenous EV components.
Components Covered Under NEMMP This mission includes support across the value chain. Some of the key components include:
Electric and Hybrid Vehicles Battery Packs (Li-ion, LFP, Solid-State) Motors and Controllers Charging Equipment Software Platforms for Smart Charging R&D Labs and Testing Centres Link Between NEMMP and FAME Scheme You might have heard about the FAME India scheme. It‚Äôs actually the implementation arm of the NEMMP.
FAME I (2015‚Äì2019): Offered direct subsidies to buyers, especially for 2-wheelers and public transport buses. FAME II (2019‚Äìextended till March 2024): More comprehensive, with a Rs. 10,000 crore outlay, targeting electric 2W, 3W, 4W, and buses. It also focuses on charging infrastructure. Both FAME phases are part of the NEMMP roadmap and carry forward its vision.
How NEMMP Benefits Various Stakeholders EV Manufacturers Can register under FAME for vehicle model approval Eligible for demand incentives based on vehicle specs Opportunity to collaborate with testing and research centers funded under NEMMP Charging Infrastructure Developers Government support for land allocation, electricity connections, and capital subsidies Benefit from guidelines established under NEMMP for standardized chargers Battery Makers Get linked benefits under the ACC Battery PLI scheme Eligible for technology development grants and pilot projects Logistics and Fleet Operators Avail subsidies on commercial electric 3W and 4W fleets Participate in pilot programs for last-mile delivery EVs EV Startups Eligible for Startup India benefits, plus additional support through NEMMP-aligned schemes Can apply for incubation support, seed funding, and technical collaboration How to Apply for NEMMP-Linked Benefits While NEMMP doesn‚Äôt have a separate application portal, the benefits are available through platforms and schemes that it gave birth to.
Step-by-Step for OEMs and EV Manufacturers Register on the FAME Portal Visit https://fame2.heavyindustries.gov.in Create a business profile Submit Product for Model Approval Provide specs like battery capacity, motor rating, vehicle range Submit test certificates from ARAI or ICAT Claim Demand Incentives After approval, manufacturers can claim per-unit subsidy for each sale Step-by-Step for Charging Infra Providers Proposal Submission Submit project proposal to Ministry of Power or BEE (Bureau of Energy Efficiency) State-Level Permissions Apply for land allocation, power connection from DISCOMs, and local clearances Installation & Deployment Comply with safety and grid integration norms Integration with PLI Schemes The Production Linked Incentive (PLI) schemes are deeply connected with the NEMMP goals. These include:
Auto and Auto Components PLI Advanced Chemistry Cell (ACC) Battery PLI You can register for these on the PLI portal and receive incentives based on your local production output.
Coordination with State EV Policies Many states have launched EV-specific policies that align with the NEMMP framework. These provide:
Purchase subsidies Road tax waivers Charging infra incentives Support for setting up EV parks or manufacturing hubs Popular states include Delhi, Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, and Gujarat.
To apply:
Register with the state‚Äôs EV portal (e.g., ev.delhi.gov.in) Submit required documents like GST certificate, investment plan, and lease deed Challenges in Implementing NEMMP While the plan is ambitious, it hasn‚Äôt been without challenges:
Lack of awareness among MSMEs Delay in model approvals and fund disbursements Uncertainty in coordination between central and state policies Limited R&D output compared to international EV hubs But with growing momentum and better digital platforms, most of these challenges are now being actively addressed.
Future Scope of NEMMP (2025‚Äì30) India is now gearing up for a new phase of EV acceleration, and NEMMP will remain the guiding light. Here‚Äôs what we can expect:
Introduction of FAME III with a greater focus on private car buyers and rural EV adoption Expanded subsidy schemes for electric tractors and commercial vehicles Development of solar-powered charging corridors Standardization of battery swapping models Wider deployment of smart charging with AI integration State-wide charging infra mapping apps linked to a central dashboard Final Thoughts: Why NEMMP Still Matters Even though it was launched in 2013, the National Electric Mobility Mission Plan remains one of the most important pillars in India‚Äôs EV transformation journey. It set the vision that has now evolved into operational schemes, incentives, and infrastructure investments that we see today.
Whether you‚Äôre just starting your EV business or looking to expand into new segments like battery innovation or charging infra, NEMMP-backed benefits are within reach. All you need is the right strategy, paperwork, and a clear understanding of which scheme to tap into.
So don‚Äôt miss the chance to ride the EV wave‚Äîbecause with the government backing your mission, the road ahead is electric.

contents:
The future of mobility is electric, and India is accelerating that shift with the help of one of its most important initiatives: the FAME India Scheme. If you‚Äôve been hearing the term ‚ÄúFAME‚Äù a lot and wondering what it actually means or how it impacts the EV ecosystem, this guide is for you.
Whether you‚Äôre planning to start an electric vehicle business, install charging stations, or simply want to understand how the government supports EV adoption, this detailed breakdown will help. We‚Äôll explore the scheme‚Äôs objectives, who it benefits, how to apply, and what the future holds.
Let‚Äôs start with the basics.
What is the FAME India Scheme? FAME stands for Faster Adoption and Manufacturing of Hybrid and Electric Vehicles. It‚Äôs a government program launched by the Ministry of Heavy Industries in 2015. The primary aim is to promote the adoption of electric and hybrid vehicles in India by offering financial incentives, improving charging infrastructure, and encouraging local manufacturing.
This scheme is part of a larger vision laid out under the National Electric Mobility Mission Plan (NEMMP).
Why Was the FAME Scheme Introduced? India has several challenges when it comes to transport:
High dependence on imported crude oil Growing air pollution in urban areas Rising carbon emissions from the transport sector Increasing demand for sustainable public transport To address these issues, FAME aims to push both the supply and demand sides of the EV ecosystem.
Phases of the FAME India Scheme Phase I (2015 ‚Äì 2019) Total outlay: Rs. 895 crore Focused on pilot projects Targeted electric 2-wheelers, 3-wheelers, 4-wheelers, and buses Supported 2.8 lakh vehicles Laid the groundwork for infrastructure and policy-making Phase II (2019 ‚Äì March 2024) Outlay: Rs. 10,000 crore Focus: Scaling adoption for commercial use, charging infrastructure, and electric buses Supports: 7,000 electric buses 5 lakh electric 3-wheelers 55,000 electric 4-wheelers 10 lakh electric 2-wheelers FAME II is a much broader and impact-driven policy that directly helps buyers, OEMs, fleet operators, and cities planning clean public transport.
Key Objectives of the FAME Scheme Reduce air pollution in metro cities Promote energy security by cutting fuel imports Develop indigenous EV technology and components Create jobs in battery tech, motor manufacturing, EV design, and software Encourage last-mile delivery electrification Support public transport electrification Components of the FAME Scheme FAME has two main verticals:
1. Demand Incentive Subsidy offered to buyers of eligible EV models. The incentive amount depends on:
Type of vehicle (2W, 3W, 4W, Bus) Battery capacity (‚Çπ10,000 to ‚Çπ20,000 per kWh) Vehicle usage (personal vs. commercial) 2. Charging Infrastructure Financial support for setting up public charging stations Cities and highways prioritised DISCOMs and private players can apply for incentives Vehicles Covered Under FAME II Two-Wheelers: Must have a minimum top speed of 40 kmph Range of 80 km per charge Subsidy of ‚Çπ15,000 per kWh (with a cap of 40% of vehicle cost) Three-Wheelers: Used in delivery or passenger services Approved models get up to ‚Çπ50,000 in subsidy Four-Wheelers: Only commercial vehicles (e.g., fleet taxis, shared mobility) Max subsidy of ‚Çπ1.5 lakh per car Buses: 7,000 e-buses supported under FAME II Cities selected through competitive bidding Eligibility Criteria for OEMs and Products To receive subsidies under FAME, your EV must:
Be manufactured in India Meet performance and efficiency benchmarks Be approved by a certified testing agency (e.g., ARAI or ICAT) Eligible Manufacturers: Some popular brands whose models are approved:
Ather Energy Ola Electric Hero Electric Okinawa TVS Motor Tata Motors Mahindra Electric Ashok Leyland (for buses) How to Apply for FAME II Incentives For EV Manufacturers (OEMs): Register on the FAME Portal Visit https://fame2.heavyindustries.gov.in/ Submit EV Model for Approval ARAI/ICAT testing Vehicle performance details (range, speed, battery capacity) Approval and Listing Once approved, your model is listed for incentives Invoice-linked Claims You submit sales data to claim incentives for each unit sold For EV Buyers: If you are buying an electric vehicle (2W or 3W), your dealer will offer the FAME discount upfront. You don‚Äôt need to apply separately.
For Charging Infrastructure Players: Submit Expression of Interest (EOI) via the Ministry of Power or DISCOMs Mention land availability, project layout, location Selected projects get support for capital expenditure Impact of FAME II So Far Over 11 lakh EVs supported as of early 2024 6000+ charging stations approved under the plan Boost to Indian manufacturing in motors, batteries, chargers Helped reduce 63 crore liters of fuel and 11 lakh tonnes of CO2 State-Level Synergy with FAME Many states have integrated their EV policies with the FAME framework to increase benefits.
Delhi Additional subsidy of ‚Çπ5,000 per kWh for two-wheelers Road tax and registration fee waiver Maharashtra ‚Çπ10,000 per EV as early bird incentive Fleet and logistics subsidies Tamil Nadu EV industrial parks, charging station support 100% road tax exemption Gujarat and Karnataka Capital subsidy for EV startups Waiver on stamp duty and electricity duty Business Opportunities Created by FAME 1. Electric Two-Wheeler Dealership Start your own dealership selling FAME-approved scooters and bikes.

It benefits consumers, manufacturers, infrastructure players, and even state governments. Whether you‚Äôre an individual EV buyer, an OEM, a charging provider, or a budding entrepreneur, this scheme gives you the chance to join India‚Äôs green journey.
Now is the time to act. With support from FAME, you can save money, build a business, and make a real impact. All you need is a little planning, compliance with eligibility rules, and a clear understanding of how the process works.
If you‚Äôre planning to ride the EV wave, let FAME be your launchpad.

India is charging full speed into the electric vehicle (EV) era, and if there‚Äôs one government initiative that‚Äôs transforming the industry from the inside out, it‚Äôs the Production Linked Incentive (PLI) Scheme. Designed to promote large-scale domestic manufacturing, this policy isn‚Äôt just about subsidies. It‚Äôs about building a self-reliant, export-ready EV ecosystem that can compete with the world.
In this detailed guide, we‚Äôll unpack everything you need to know about the PLI Scheme for the EV sector, including how to apply, eligibility criteria, incentive calculations, current beneficiaries, and the opportunities it opens up for startups, OEMs, and component makers in India.
Let‚Äôs break it down step-by-step so that you can confidently understand‚Äîand benefit from‚Äîthis ambitious policy framework.
What is the PLI Scheme? The Production Linked Incentive (PLI) Scheme is a performance-based government initiative that rewards businesses for increasing their manufacturing output within India. Rather than giving upfront subsidies, it offers cash incentives tied to actual sales and production volume over a set period (usually 5 years).
Think of it this way: if you manufacture more and meet localization targets, you get a percentage of your sales back as a government incentive.
In the EV space, the government has introduced two major PLI schemes:
PLI for Automobile and Auto Components ‚Äì Focused on electric vehicles and related components PLI for Advanced Chemistry Cell (ACC) Battery Storage ‚Äì Focused on domestic battery cell manufacturing Both these schemes work in synergy with FAME-II, NEMMP, and various state EV policies to push India towards a cleaner, self-sufficient transport future.
Why the EV Sector Was Chosen for PLI India imports a large chunk of its vehicle components and almost all of its battery cells. This dependence on foreign countries‚Äîespecially for advanced lithium-ion technology‚Äîhas been a strategic concern.
Here‚Äôs why the EV sector is central to PLI:
Reduce import dependency on China, Korea, and Japan Encourage Make in India for critical components like motors, controllers, and battery packs Lower costs of EVs by localizing the supply chain Create jobs in EV design, manufacturing, and R&D Establish India as a global EV export hub Boost investment from both Indian conglomerates and global automotive giants Overview of the Two PLI Schemes for the EV Sector Let‚Äôs understand both schemes and what they offer:
1. PLI Scheme for Automobile and Auto Components Launched by: Ministry of Heavy Industries
Outlay: ‚Çπ25,938 crore
Tenure: 5 years
Focus Areas:
Electric and Hydrogen Fuel Cell Vehicles Advanced automotive components Software, sensors, BMS, drive trains Who can apply:
OEMs making EVs (2W, 3W, 4W, Buses) Component manufacturers making e-mobility parts Startups with innovation in automotive electronics or vehicle systems 2. PLI Scheme for Advanced Chemistry Cell (ACC) Battery Launched by: Ministry of Heavy Industries + NITI Aayog
Outlay: ‚Çπ18,100 crore
Tenure: 5 years
Focus Areas:
Lithium-ion cell manufacturing (LFP, NMC) Future battery technologies (Sodium-ion, Solid-state) Localization of battery supply chain Who can apply:
Battery manufacturers Companies investing in Giga-factories Joint ventures between Indian and global players Key Features of the PLI Scheme for Auto & Components This scheme is split into two categories:
A. Champion OEM Incentive Scheme Targeted at automotive companies that produce EVs and fuel cell vehicles.
Minimum Investment: ‚Çπ2,000 crore Minimum Revenue Requirement: ‚Çπ10,000 crore (global group revenue) Applicable to 4W, 2W, buses, and new-age EV makers B. Component Champion Incentive Scheme For auto component makers producing:
EV drive systems Advanced braking systems Battery packs Motor controllers Software for EVs Minimum Investment: ‚Çπ250 crore Global group turnover requirement: ‚Çπ500 crore Key Features of PLI Scheme for ACC Battery Storage Focused on domestic battery cell production Minimum capacity requirement: 5 GWh per bidder Minimum investment: ‚Çπ225 crore per GWh Incentives up to ‚Çπ2,000 per kWh based on localization targets Maximum incentive tenure: 5 years Eligibility Criteria ‚Äì Who Can Apply? Let‚Äôs simplify this:
Category <th> Eligible Entities </th> <th> Investment Threshold </th> OEM (Auto) <td> EV manufacturers (e.g., Tata Motors, Ola Electric) </td> <td> ‚Çπ2,000 Cr </td> Component Makers <td> Suppliers of motors, ECUs, sensors, packs </td> <td> ‚Çπ250 Cr </td> Battery Manufacturers <td> Cell producers (LFP, NMC, Solid-State) </td> <td> ‚Çπ225 Cr per GWh </td> Startups & MSMEs <td> EV-focused firms with deep tech IP </td> <td> Flexible based on proposal </td> To qualify, your business must:
Be registered in India Meet turnover or investment requirements Commit to manufacturing in India Reach localization & revenue milestones Step-by-Step: How to Apply for PLI in EV Sector Step 1: Monitor Government Announcements PLI applications open periodically. Keep an eye on:
https://heavyindustries.gov.in https://niti.gov.in https://pliauto.in Step 2: Prepare a Detailed Proposal Include:
Business plan (5 years) Investment layout and plant setup Expected sales and production targets Employment generation data Innovation or IP (for startups) Step 3: Register on the Portal Go to https://pliauto.in Register with PAN, GST, CIN Upload documents and submit proposal under RFP or EOI round Step 4: Evaluation by Project Management Agency (PMA) Your application will be reviewed for:
Feasibility Tech readiness Financial capacity Employment and localization goals Step 5: Approval and Signing of Agreement If selected, you‚Äôll get:
Letter of Approval Milestone calendar Terms for incentive disbursement How Are Incentives Disbursed? Payout is linked to actual production and sales You must meet yearly value-addition and investment targets Incentives are paid via direct bank transfer (DBT) Audits and reports need to be filed annually Maximum payout is capped based on your bid and product type Success Stories: Companies Approved Under PLI Some of the beneficiaries include:
Company <th> Segment </th> <th> PLI Scheme </th> Ola Electric <td> 2-Wheeler EVs </td> <td> Champion OEM </td> Tata Motors <td> EV Cars, Buses </td> <td> Champion OEM </td> Mahindra Electric <td> Commercial EVs </td> <td> Champion OEM </td> Reliance New Energy <td> Battery Cells </td> <td> ACC PLI </td> Rajesh Exports <td> Giga-factory (Batteries) </td> <td> ACC PLI </td> Lucas TVS <td> EV Components </td> <td> Component Scheme </td> These companies are now building manufacturing lines in Gujarat, Tamil Nadu, Maharashtra, and Telangana under the PLI roadmap.
Integration with Other Policies PLI is not a standalone initiative. It works alongside:
FAME II ‚Äì for demand-side incentives NEMMP ‚Äì long-term EV vision State EV policies ‚Äì land, power, tax incentives Startup India ‚Äì tax holidays and seed funding Make in India ‚Äì for duty waivers on equipment Together, these create a full-stack policy ecosystem.
What‚Äôs Coming Next: PLI 2.0 and Expansion Plans The government is considering:
Including battery swapping technologies Adding EV software platforms and telematics Creating a special PLI for MSMEs in EV supply chain Encouraging joint ventures with global tech leaders Offering PLI-linked export bonuses Business Opportunities Opened by PLI If you‚Äôre a startup or manufacturer, here‚Äôs where you can benefit:
1. EV Component Manufacturing Start plants to make:
BLDC motors Controllers Battery packs CAN bus systems 2. Giga-factory Investment Enter the battery cell production space‚ÄîIndia currently has low capacity but high demand.
3. EV Assembly Lines Launch white-label or contract manufacturing units.
4. Charging Equipment Manufacturing Produce home chargers, fast DC units, and grid-integration devices.
5. R&D and IP Development Earn incentives for developing software, vehicle management systems, and in-vehicle telematics.
Challenges to Be Aware Of High entry thresholds (small players find it tough) Long gestation period before incentives are paid Localization requirements need deep supply chains Compliances and audits can be paperwork-heavy Investment must begin early to qualify Expert Tips for Applicants Partner with state governments to get land and infra benefits Invest early in testing and certification Join EV industry bodies for early updates and support Focus on value addition, not just assembly Track PLI notification timelines closely Final Thoughts The PLI Scheme is more than just an incentive‚Äîit‚Äôs a strategy. A strategy to make India the next big EV manufacturing hub. It‚Äôs already showing results, with major companies setting up EV and battery plants across the country.
But this is just the beginning.
Whether you‚Äôre a startup with battery tech or an auto giant looking to electrify your fleet, PLI is your gateway to scale, incentives, and long-term market positioning.
So if you‚Äôve been waiting for the right time to invest in India‚Äôs EV growth story, this is it.

India‚Äôs electric mobility journey is progressing quickly. While national schemes like FAME and PLI are making headlines, much of the real impact is happening at the state level ‚Äî where governments are introducing their own electric vehicle (EV) policies to accelerate local adoption and support infrastructure.
Every Indian state has unique EV goals. Some are focusing on purchase subsidies, others on building charging networks, and a few are creating large EV industrial parks to boost manufacturing. Whether you‚Äôre planning to buy an EV or launch a business in the sector, understanding your state‚Äôs EV policy can save you a lot of money and help you plan better.
This guide will give you a complete overview of EV benefits by state, who qualifies, and how you can apply for these incentives.
Why State EV Policies Matter The central government lays down the big picture vision ‚Äî but states are responsible for implementing and executing EV-friendly policies. Transportation, power, urban planning, land use, and local industrial development fall under state control.
Here‚Äôs how state policies help:
They reduce the effective cost of EVs through purchase subsidies They remove road tax and registration charges They offer capital support for charging stations They provide subsidized electricity tariffs for EV-related infrastructure They allocate land and financial assistance to manufacturers and startups If you‚Äôre serious about buying an EV or starting an EV business in India, your state‚Äôs policy is as important as the national schemes.
Common Benefits Across States While the exact numbers vary, most state EV policies include the following:
Purchase Subsidy
A per kWh incentive on the battery capacity of the EV. Usually ‚Çπ5,000‚Äì‚Çπ10,000 per kWh for 2-wheelers and 3-wheelers.
Scrappage Incentive
Extra benefits if the buyer scraps their old petrol or diesel vehicle.
Road Tax and Registration Waiver
Most states offer 100% exemption on both charges for EVs.
Charging Station Subsidy
Capital subsidy on equipment and civil work. Some states offer up to ‚Çπ10 lakh per public station.
Electricity Tariff Discount
Special per-unit rates for EV chargers, usually lower than standard commercial rates.
Manufacturing Support
Subsidies for factory setup, employment generation, land lease waivers, and GST refunds.
Best Performing States and Their EV Policies (2025) Let‚Äôs take a closer look at India‚Äôs leading states in terms of EV policy execution and support.

Subsidies are reimbursed directly after registration and invoice verification.

Imagine a Future Where Your Car Charges in Minutes Picture this: You wake up, unplug your car just like your phone, and it‚Äôs ready to hit the road‚Äîfully charged in just minutes, not hours. No more waiting at charging stations or stressing about running out of power. Just smooth, clean, and effortless driving.
That‚Äôs the promise of Atomic Electric Vehicles (AEVs)‚Äîa revolutionary upgrade to today‚Äôs EVs designed to make electric cars faster, more efficient, and more convenient to use. But what exactly are Atomic EVs, and how do they differ from the electric cars we see on the road today?
Let‚Äôs break it down in simple terms to understand why Atomic EVs might just be the future of driving.
What Exactly is an Atomic Electric Vehicle? An Atomic Electric Vehicle (AEV) is a next-generation electric car that uses advanced battery technologies, like solid-state or graphene-based batteries, to charge faster, last longer, and deliver higher energy efficiency compared to traditional EVs.
Think of an Atomic Electric Vehicle as an EV on steroids‚Äîfeaturing:
Faster Charging: Minutes instead of hours. Longer Battery Life: Minimal degradation over time. Higher Energy Efficiency: Making the most out of every charge. Unlike conventional EVs that use lithium-ion batteries, Atomic EVs leverage next-gen energy storage systems that work on a microscopic, or ‚Äúatomic,‚Äù level to deliver power more efficiently.
The Main Differences Between Atomic EVs and Regular EVs: {.wp-block-heading} Feature <th> Regular EVs </th> <th> Atomic EVs </th> Battery Technology <td> Lithium-ion batteries, prone to degradation </td> <td> Advanced solid-state or graphene-based batteries </td> Charging Speed <td> 30 minutes to several hours </td> <td> Under 10 minutes </td> Energy Efficiency <td> Limited by battery chemistry </td> <td> Ultra-efficient atomic-level power management </td> Range <td> 300-500 km per charge </td> <td> 800-1000 km per charge </td> Weight <td> Heavier due to battery size </td> <td> Lightweight with advanced materials </td> How Do Atomic Electric Vehicles Work? The secret behind Atomic EVs lies in cutting-edge battery technologies and atomic-level energy management. Here‚Äôs a breakdown:
1. Advanced Battery Technology Uses solid-state batteries, graphene-based cells, or ultra-capacitors. Offers higher energy density, resulting in faster charging and longer lifespan. Less prone to overheating or degradation, making them safer and more reliable. 2. Lightning-Fast Charging Regular EVs take around 30 minutes to several hours to charge. Atomic EVs could fully charge in under 10 minutes with ultra-fast charging technology. Future models aim to reduce charging time to 5 minutes, comparable to refueling a petrol car. 3. Regenerative Braking: Free Energy on the Go Converts kinetic energy back into electrical energy during braking. Enables self-charging while driving, reducing overall power consumption. 4. Lightweight and Super-Efficient Design Uses lightweight materials like carbon fiber to reduce energy usage. Lower weight = higher range, allowing longer drives on a single charge. 5. Extended Range Without Compromise Regular EVs offer 300-500 km per charge. Atomic EVs can potentially double that to 800-1000 km, making long trips worry-free. Why Should You Care About Atomic EVs? If you‚Äôre considering an electric car but are concerned about charging times, battery life, or range, Atomic EVs are the solution. Here‚Äôs why they matter:
1. Charge Faster No more waiting hours at charging stations. Ultra-fast charging means your car is ready in minutes. 2. Drive Longer Fewer stops on road trips with a range of up to 1000 km per charge. 3. Save Money on Maintenance Fewer mechanical parts than petrol cars and longer-lasting batteries mean lower maintenance costs. 4. Cleaner and Greener Zero emissions contribute to a healthier planet, especially in urban environments. 5. Future-Proof Technology As the technology matures, Atomic EVs will likely dominate the EV market. Expert Insights: What Do the Industry Leaders Say? According to Dr. Anil Verma, a leading researcher in EV technology:
“The development of Atomic EVs marks a paradigm shift in how we store and use energy in electric vehicles. Their ability to charge in minutes without degrading over time will revolutionize long-distance travel.” Are There Any Downsides? Of course, no technology is perfect. Here are some challenges Atomic EVs still face:
1. High Manufacturing Costs Producing solid-state and graphene-based batteries remains expensive. Economies of scale are required to bring down costs. 2. Limited Availability Most Atomic EVs are still in the development and testing stages. 3. Charging Infrastructure Ultra-fast chargers are not yet widely available, but major automakers are investing heavily in their deployment. Real-Life Examples: Are Atomic EVs on the Market Yet? Some companies are actively developing Atomic EV technology, including:
Tesla and QuantumScape: Working on solid-state battery advancements. Toyota: Investing in solid-state battery research. Indian Startups: Exploring graphene and ultra-capacitor technologies for future models. What‚Äôs Next for Atomic Electric Vehicles? In the next 5-10 years, expect to see:
Charging times dropping to 5 minutes or less. Driving ranges hitting 1000 km on a single charge. Lightweight designs reducing energy consumption by 30%. As technology advances and costs drop, Atomic EVs will become mainstream, transforming the way we travel and commute.
Should You Wait for Atomic EVs or Buy an EV Now? If you‚Äôre planning to switch to an EV soon, don‚Äôt wait. Modern EVs are already efficient and cost-effective. However, if you‚Äôre willing to wait a few more years for cutting-edge technology, Atomic EVs might just be worth it.
No matter what, the future of electric vehicles is exciting and closer than you think!
FAQs Q1: Are Atomic Electric Vehicles commercially available now?
No, they are mostly in the development and testing phases, but some manufacturers are targeting 2027-2030 for commercial releases.
Q2: Will Atomic EVs be more expensive than traditional EVs?
Initially, yes, but as production scales up, prices are expected to become more competitive.
Q3: How do Atomic EVs compare with current Tesla models?
While Tesla‚Äôs current models offer fast charging and long range, Atomic EVs aim to significantly reduce charging time and improve range efficiency.
Final Thoughts: The Road Ahead Atomic Electric Vehicles hold the potential to redefine sustainable transport, making it more efficient and user-friendly. As technology advances, it‚Äôs only a matter of time before we see them on the roads.
Until then, modern EVs remain an excellent choice for those looking to reduce carbon emissions and save on fuel costs. Stay tuned as the EV landscape evolves‚Äîit‚Äôs going to be an exciting journey!

India‚Äôs electric mobility story is fast evolving, and with it comes the growing need for faster, more flexible, and scalable charging solutions. While conventional plug-in EV charging stations are expanding, the Indian government, through NITI Aayog, has introduced a game-changing alternative ‚Äî Battery Swapping.
In 2022, NITI Aayog released a Draft Battery Swapping Policy, recognizing that charging time and space constraints in urban India could slow down EV adoption, especially for commercial vehicles. With last-mile delivery, e-rickshaws, and fleet operators in focus, this policy proposes an interoperable, service-based model that could reshape how EVs are powered across India.
This blog will walk you through everything you need to know about the battery swapping policy ‚Äî why it was introduced, how it works, business potential, technology challenges, implementation roadmap, and how you can benefit from it in 2025 and beyond.
Understanding the Need for Battery Swapping in India Let‚Äôs begin with the basics.
What Is Battery Swapping? Battery swapping is a system where an electric vehicle‚Äôs depleted battery can be quickly replaced with a fully charged one at a designated swapping station ‚Äî much like swapping a gas cylinder at a local vendor.
It eliminates the need to plug in and wait hours for charging.
Why Is It Needed? In India, most EV users live in apartments, shared housing, or congested areas where installing home chargers is a challenge. Moreover, delivery fleets and e-rickshaws need minimal downtime. Plug-in charging stations are still growing, but they‚Äôre expensive, land-intensive, and often face electricity supply limitations.
Battery swapping solves this by offering:
Speed: A swap takes 2‚Äì5 minutes Flexibility: No need for private charging points Service model: EV ownership without owning a battery These are especially important for commercial 2Ws, 3Ws, and urban delivery EVs.
NITI Aayog‚Äôs Draft Battery Swapping Policy: A Breakdown In April 2022, NITI Aayog released a draft policy inviting comments from industry stakeholders. It marks the first step in formalizing a national framework for battery swapping.
Let‚Äôs break down the key components:
1. Interoperability and Standardization The draft proposes that:
Battery swapping should be interoperable across vehicle brands Standardized dimensions and connectors are critical Batteries should comply with safety norms (AIS-156 and BIS standards) The goal is to ensure that one battery fits multiple vehicles, just like SIM cards fit various phones.
2. Battery-as-a-Service (BaaS) Model Instead of selling EVs with a fixed battery, OEMs and operators can now:
Sell EVs without batteries, reducing upfront cost by 30‚Äì40% Offer batteries on lease or subscription Provide pay-per-swap models for fleet operators This opens up a service-led business model that includes fintech, energy, mobility, and retail layers.
3. Incentives for Swapping Infrastructure The policy encourages state governments and DISCOMs to:
Provide land allocation in public parking lots Offer electricity at concessional rates for swapping stations Simplify approvals and compliance (just like fuel stations) Moreover, the government will integrate swapping operators into urban planning via EV master plans.
4. GST and Regulatory Relaxations NITI Aayog has proposed:
Bringing battery leasing under the FAME scheme Reducing GST on battery leasing from 18% to 5% (to match EVs) Allowing portable battery packs to be stored, transported, and swapped under safe norms This ensures battery swapping companies can operate sustainably with a lower tax burden.
Benefits of Battery Swapping for India‚Äôs EV Ecosystem Let‚Äôs explore why this model is ideal for India.
1. Faster Turnaround for Commercial Vehicles Delivery EVs and rickshaws cannot afford 3-hour charging breaks. Battery swapping cuts downtime to just 3 minutes ‚Äî keeping the fleet on the move.
2. Lower EV Purchase Cost Batteries account for 35‚Äì45% of an EV‚Äôs price. By de-linking battery ownership, manufacturers can sell EVs at lower prices and increase affordability, especially in the 2W and 3W segment.
3. Grid Load Management Unlike fast chargers, swapping stations can charge batteries slowly off-peak, reducing stress on the electricity grid and preventing spikes.
4. Promotes Innovation in Energy Services Swapping opens up new business areas such as:
Battery rental networks Fintech for battery subscription AI-based battery health analytics Blockchain for traceability and usage tracking 5. Supports Circular Economy With batteries owned by operators, companies can monitor lifecycle, recycle in bulk, and reduce battery waste.
Business Models Enabled by Battery Swapping Battery swapping isn‚Äôt just a technology ‚Äî it‚Äôs a whole ecosystem of new business opportunities.
1. Battery-as-a-Service (BaaS) Operators Provide batteries on lease and manage health, lifecycle, and charging. Charge a flat monthly fee or per-swap fee.
Examples: Sun Mobility, BatterySmart, VoltUp
2. Swap Station Franchises Own or operate a swap station under an established brand. Think of it like owning a petrol pump franchise, but for EVs.
Revenue Model: Per-swap commission + power sales
3. OEM Partnerships Two-wheeler brands and logistics firms can sell vehicles without batteries, bundling BaaS from a swapping partner.
Examples: Bounce Infinity, Hero Electric with Sun Mobility
4. Battery Manufacturing Produce LFP-based swappable batteries and supply to BaaS operators. Focus on durability, modularity, and safety.
5. Software and Analytics Offer IoT-enabled platforms to track battery health, usage, payments, and optimization.
Who Can Benefit from the Policy? If you‚Äôre involved in any of the following, this policy creates opportunities:
EV manufacturers (2W, 3W) Logistics companies and fleet operators Battery manufacturers Charging/swapping infra startups Mobility SaaS providers Renewable energy companies Smart city planners Even petrol pump operators and parking lot owners can retrofit space to host swap stations.
Early Movers: Battery Swapping Companies in India Several startups and corporates have already entered this space. Let‚Äôs look at the key players.
Sun Mobility Partnership with Piaggio, Ashok Leyland Swap stations in Delhi, Mumbai, Bangalore Modular batteries based on LFP chemistry Focus on fleet electrification BatterySmart Targets e-rickshaw market Operates 700+ stations across north India Focused on fast, low-cost battery services for 3Ws VoltUp Partnered with BPCL and HPCL for station rollout Integrated mobile app for swap bookings Smart grid-linked battery stations Bounce Infinity Offers scooters with ‚ÄúBattery-as-a-Subscription‚Äù Built-in swap compatibility from factory Expanding into Tier 2 cities What Makes a Good Swapping Station? If you‚Äôre planning to enter this space, your station should have:
At least 10 battery slots (5 charging, 5 ready) Load management system for charging cycles Secure lockers or robotic arms for handling Integration with a backend for billing and analytics 24×7 power backup and surge protection Location matters ‚Äî aim for high-traffic commercial areas or near delivery hubs.
Challenges and Considerations While promising, battery swapping is not without hurdles.
Interoperability Concerns Multiple battery sizes and connectors still exist. Unless standardization is enforced, each brand may have proprietary systems.
Fire Safety and Battery Quality Batteries must meet safety certifications. Poor-quality swappable batteries can pose fire hazards if mishandled or poorly maintained.
Investment Requirements Swap stations need upfront capital, consistent power supply, and land leases. For startups, partnering with petrol pumps or malls can reduce costs.
Consumer Awareness Many buyers still don‚Äôt understand the concept of battery leasing. Clear branding and education will be needed.
Government‚Äôs Implementation Roadmap Based on stakeholder consultations, here‚Äôs what the government plans:
Final Battery Swapping Policy notification in 2025 Interoperability standards finalized by BIS and ARAI Integration into FAME III incentives State-level policy alignment with land allocation and tariff models Pilot projects in Tier 1 cities followed by expansion How to Participate or Apply As a Fleet Operator or Logistics Company Partner with a BaaS provider like Sun Mobility Lease swappable EVs from OEMs offering compatible vehicles Apply for state incentives under local EV policy As a Battery Swapping Startup Incorporate your business and register with Startup India Apply for subsidies under state EV charging guidelines Contact DISCOMs for electricity load sanction Partner with OEMs and charging software providers As a Charging Infra Franchise Reach out to swap station aggregators for franchise proposals Secure land or commercial parking with electricity access Use FAME II/state incentives for charger installation Future of Battery Swapping in India The next 5 years could see:
Battery swapping networks in all metro cities Government buses and autorickshaws using standardized swappable packs Integration with metro stations, malls, petrol pumps BaaS linked to solar-powered microgrids AI-powered battery routing and diagnostics Inclusion in EV financing, insurance, and resale frameworks Final Thoughts Battery swapping is not just a technical workaround to slow charging ‚Äî it‚Äôs a strategic infrastructure model that suits India‚Äôs dense urban environments and fast-growing delivery economy.
From two-wheelers to e-rickshaws and cargo vehicles, battery swapping could help India leapfrog challenges faced by countries with mature EV markets. The government‚Äôs draft policy is a welcome step, and with clear business models, strong partnerships, and reliable safety norms, the next phase of India‚Äôs EV revolution could be powered by removable, rentable, and reusable batteries.
title: Battery Swapping Policy in India: A Complete Guide to NITI Aayog‚Äôs Vision, Business Models, and EV Infrastructure Opportunities (2025)

As India accelerates toward its electric mobility goals, the availability of fast, accessible, and affordable charging infrastructure is no longer optional ‚Äî it‚Äôs critical. Recognizing this, the Ministry of Power (MoP) has released detailed Charging Infrastructure Guidelines to simplify the process of setting up EV charging stations and encourage widespread adoption.
If you‚Äôre a business owner, real estate developer, society resident, fleet operator, or even a petrol pump franchisee ‚Äî these guidelines directly affect your ability to participate in India‚Äôs EV growth story.
This blog explains everything in clear terms ‚Äî including how you can set up a charger, what benefits you‚Äôre entitled to, and how to apply for grid connections, approvals, and incentives in 2025.
What Are the EV Charging Guidelines by the Ministry of Power? These guidelines were introduced to:
Encourage public and private players to set up charging stations Remove regulatory bottlenecks Ensure affordable, accessible EV charging infrastructure Provide single-window approval systems Offer tariff clarity, especially for commercial and public charging use These MoP guidelines serve as the national framework under which state electricity boards (DISCOMs), local municipalities, and urban planners operate.
Key Highlights of the MoP Charging Infrastructure Guidelines (2023‚Äì2025) Let‚Äôs decode each major provision in simple terms.
1. No License Required for Setting Up Public Charging Stations If you want to set up a public EV charging station, you do not need a power distribution license.
Under the Electricity Act, 2003 ‚Äî any individual, company, or partnership can set up a public charging station without needing approval from the electricity regulator.
This means:
No license No long delays Faster rollout All you need is:
Land or space (owned or rented) Connection to the electricity grid Charger installation (Bharat/DC001, CCS2, CHAdeMO, etc.) 2. Timeline for DISCOM Connections DISCOMs are now legally required to provide a new power connection for EV charging stations within a fixed time frame.
Urban Areas: 7 days Municipal Zones/Urban Extensions: 15 days Rural Areas: 30 days This clause is binding, and non-compliance can be escalated to the State Electricity Regulatory Commission (SERC).
3. Single Window Clearance System All states and union territories must implement a Single-Window Online Portal for:
Registering as a public charging station Applying for electricity connection Accessing grid upgrade plans Viewing approved locations or sanctioned loads This portal will be operated by DISCOMs and synchronized with municipal building permissions.
Examples:
Delhi: https://delhi.gov.in Maharashtra: https://maitri.mahaonline.gov.in 4. Time-of-Day (ToD) Tariffs Charging stations are allowed to purchase electricity at off-peak rates, making charging cheaper during night hours.
Peak (6 PM to 10 PM): Higher rate Off-Peak (10 PM to 6 AM): Up to 30% lower rate This encourages load balancing and helps save costs for charging station operators.
Pro Tip: You can pass on these savings to customers via night-time charging discounts.
5. Public Charging Station Planning Guidelines As per MoP recommendations:
One charging station every 3 km in cities One fast charger every 25 km on highways One EV charging hub every 100 km for heavy-duty vehicles These are advisory goals, but states are aligning their EV masterplans accordingly.
6. Support for Residential and Commercial Buildings EV-ready infrastructure must now be part of building bye-laws. The MoP guidelines encourage:
Housing societies to reserve 20% parking spaces for EV charging Malls, offices, and parking lots to offer dedicated EV charging bays DISCOMs to offer domestic tariffs for private residential chargers This means your society or office can set up an EV charger using the same electricity rate as your home.
7. Support for Public Private Partnerships (PPP) The government encourages PPP models in charging infrastructure. If you‚Äôre a private investor or startup:
You can lease government land for charging stations Operate under a revenue-sharing agreement with municipal bodies Submit proposals through state-level EV agencies 8. Interconnection and Grid Upgrade Support If a charging station requires a transformer upgrade or new substation, DISCOMs are required to:
Inform the applicant Provide time-bound estimates Enable shared infra where multiple operators use the same grid Cost-sharing models will be based on actual usage over time.
Step-by-Step: How to Set Up an EV Charging Station in 2025 Let‚Äôs now look at the actual process.
Step 1: Choose Your Charging Business Model You can operate in one of the following ways:
Public Charging Station (PCS): Open to all users. Must comply with MoP guidelines. Captive Charging: For your own EV fleet (no commercial use). Residential/Community Charging: For gated societies and housing colonies. Step 2: Identify the Location Ideal locations include:
Parking lots of malls and multiplexes Housing society common areas Commercial real estate, fuel stations Urban transport hubs Highways or expressways Tip: The MoP allows setting up PCS even on leased or rented land.
Step 3: Apply for Electricity Connection Visit your local DISCOM‚Äôs Single-Window Portal. Submit:
Ownership or lease documents of land Load estimate (depends on charger type) Layout plan Safety certification of chargers (BIS, ARAI) Time to connect:
7 days (urban) 15 days (semi-urban) 30 days (rural) Step 4: Choose the Charger Type Comply with government-approved protocols:
Vehicle Type <th> Recommended Charger </th> <th> Power Output </th> 2W/3W <td> Bharat AC-001 </td> <td> 3.3‚Äì5 kW </td> 4W Personal <td> Type 2 AC/CCS-2 </td> <td> 7‚Äì22 kW </td> Fleet Cars <td> DC001, CCS2 </td> <td> 15‚Äì50 kW </td> Buses <td> GB/T or CCS2 </td> <td> 50‚Äì150 kW </td> Step 5: Install and Certify Procure from certified charger manufacturers Install via trained technicians Submit safety compliance reports to DISCOM and local fire authority Step 6: Go Live and Register Your PCS Register your station with the State Nodal Agency or EV Cell.
In Delhi, this would be:
Delhi Dialogue and Development Commission (DDC) https://ev.delhi.gov.in You may also need to list your location on apps like e-Amrit, ReChargeIndia, or your operator‚Äôs app.
Incentives Available for Charging Station Operators Here‚Äôs how you can benefit.
Central Level Accelerated Depreciation under Income Tax Act (40% on EV infra) GST at 5% on EV charger sales Import duty exemptions (for certain components) Integration into FAME II for public chargers State Level (Examples) {.wp-block-heading} State <th> Charging Station Incentive </th> Maharashtra <td> ‚Çπ10 lakh per public charger station </td> Delhi <td> ‚Çπ6,000 per home charger (AC 3.3 kW) </td> Gujarat <td> 25% CapEx subsidy for infra installation </td> Tamil Nadu <td> Land lease support in SIPCOT parks </td> Telangana <td> Capital subsidy via TSREDCO </td> Karnataka <td> Stamp duty waiver + power subsidy </td> Business Opportunities in EV Charging This is a booming sector in 2025. You can:
Start a charging station franchise Develop EV charging mobile apps Set up battery diagnostics and servicing Sell value-added products like WiFi, food, or advertising at your station Lease space to third-party operators Common Challenges and How to Overcome Them {.wp-block-heading} Challenge <th> Solution </th> Land availability <td> Partner with petrol pumps, malls, or ULBs </td> Grid load limitations <td> Use load management and battery buffering systems </td> Low footfall at launch <td> Target delivery fleets, autos, or captive users first </td> Approval delays <td> Use the Single Window Portal or escalate to state agency </td> High CapEx <td> Apply for central + state subsidies </td> Future Roadmap Under MoP Guidelines Unified app ecosystem for charger discovery and payments Battery-integrated charging stations for grid load balancing Solar + EV chargers in parking lots Integration with smart cities for EV zoning and demand forecasting EV charging mandatory in all new commercial buildings Final Thoughts The Ministry of Power‚Äôs EV Charging Infrastructure Guidelines have unlocked a powerful opportunity for India to scale its EV infrastructure quickly and efficiently. With the right mix of policy, private investment, and digital services, India could soon have one of the most inclusive and scalable charging networks in the world.
If you‚Äôre a business owner, startup, investor, fleet operator, or housing society ‚Äî the time to get involved is now.
Understand your local DISCOM‚Äôs process, apply through the right channels, and build your charging ecosystem brick by brick ‚Äî or charger by charger.
title: EV Charging Infrastructure Guidelines by Ministry of Power (2025): Full Guide to Setting Up Chargers, Getting Benefits, and Applying for Connections

In the fast-growing world of electric vehicles (EVs), India is making waves. But as this green shift accelerates, many people still have basic questions: ‚ÄúWhich EV should I buy?‚Äù, ‚ÄúWhere can I charge it?‚Äù, or ‚ÄúHow do I start an EV business in India?‚Äù
Enter E-Amrit, India‚Äôs most comprehensive government-backed platform dedicated to EV adoption.
Whether you‚Äôre a consumer considering your first electric scooter, a startup building an EV product, or a business setting up a charging station ‚Äî the E-Amrit Portal by NITI Aayog is designed to help you take action with clarity and confidence.
In this guide, we‚Äôll break down exactly how it works, what you can do with it, and how you can benefit from the portal ‚Äî with real links, step-by-step actions, and plenty of practical tips.
What Is the E-Amrit Portal? E-Amrit stands for Accelerated e-Mobility Revolution for India‚Äôs Transportation.
Developed by NITI Aayog in collaboration with the UK Government, the portal was launched to offer a single-window platform for everything EV ‚Äî from buying guides and subsidy updates to charger locators and business resources.
Its goal? To simplify the EV transition for every stakeholder in the ecosystem ‚Äî including individuals, entrepreneurs, investors, and government agencies.
Official Link: https://e-amrit.niti.gov.in{.}
Why Was E-Amrit Created? Until recently, India‚Äôs EV ecosystem was a web of disconnected departments and outdated PDFs. People had to visit different websites for FAME subsidies, startup registrations, state EV policies, and charging infra guidelines. There was no central place to compare EV models or understand business opportunities.
NITI Aayog stepped in with E-Amrit to:
Simplify decision-making for EV users and startups Encourage private sector participation by removing info gaps Centralize access to government support like PLI, FAME, and state schemes Empower small businesses, OEMs, and investors with verified data E-Amrit is not just a website ‚Äî it‚Äôs a digital backbone for India‚Äôs electric mobility future.
Who Should Use the E-Amrit Portal? This portal isn‚Äôt just for policymakers or government bodies. It‚Äôs designed to serve:
Individuals looking to buy electric two-wheelers, cars, or autos Fleet operators switching to electric delivery or taxi services Startups working on battery tech, motors, leasing, or mobility platforms Charging station companies seeking land, permissions, or policy support Academics and researchers tracking India‚Äôs EV adoption story Policy advisors and urban planners integrating EVs into cities If you‚Äôre connected to the EV industry in any form, E-Amrit is for you.
Core Sections of the E-Amrit Portal (Explained in Detail) Let‚Äôs explore what you‚Äôll find on the E-Amrit website and how to make the most of each feature.
1. EV Buying Guide This is the most popular section for individuals. It lets you:
Compare EV models across 2-wheelers, 3-wheelers, 4-wheelers, and buses See detailed specs such as battery capacity, driving range, top speed, charging time View prices after subsidy deductions under FAME II or state schemes Access links to manufacturer websites or dealerships For example, you can compare an Ola S1 Pro vs TVS iQube vs Ather 450X in one place, check who offers the best value, and estimate your monthly savings on fuel.
It removes guesswork from the EV buying decision.
2. Charger Locator Tool Many people worry about range or whether they‚Äôll find chargers on the go. The Charger Locator Tool solves this.
It maps nearby public EV charging stations Shows charger types: AC, DC, fast charging, slow charging Displays live status (in some cases), number of sockets, plug type Integrated with real-time data from Bharat Charge Alliance, NTPC, Tata Power, and private providers Before your next intercity trip, you can map out charging stops along the route ‚Äî all from the same page.
3. Subsidy & Policy Dashboard India has EV schemes at both central and state levels. But they‚Äôre scattered across dozens of government sites. The E-Amrit dashboard brings everything together.
It includes:
Details of FAME II subsidy, eligibility for 2W, 3W, 4W, and buses Production Linked Incentive (PLI) details for manufacturers and component makers A state-wise interactive map showing each state‚Äôs EV policy, benefits, and industry clusters Want to know how much subsidy Maharashtra offers on an electric car? It‚Äôs right there. Want to compare Karnataka‚Äôs battery park incentives with Gujarat‚Äôs stamp duty waiver? This tool does that too.
4. Total Cost of Ownership Calculator Electric vehicles cost more upfront, but they save you money over time. The TCO calculator helps you:
Compare your fuel vehicle with an EV over a 5‚Äì7 year period Include factors like EMI, electricity rates, insurance, servicing See your breakeven point and long-term savings It‚Äôs a practical tool that can turn a hesitant buyer into a confident EV user.
5. EV Investment Opportunities This section is pure gold for startups, investors, and B2B entrepreneurs.
You‚Äôll find:
Information on land allotment for EV parks (like those in Tamil Nadu, Gujarat, and Telangana) Updates on FAME II tenders for buses, chargers, or battery tech Guidelines to apply for PLI Auto and ACC schemes Resources on Battery-as-a-Service (BaaS) and battery swapping pilots State-led programs for manufacturing or component support If you‚Äôre planning to raise funds, apply for grants, or pitch to investors, this section provides essential background and credibility.
6. Knowledge & Learning Center This section hosts:
Policy whitepapers by NITI Aayog, MoHUA, and MoP Research by think tanks like TERI and CEEW Investor presentations Consumer awareness booklets City EV readiness plans Perfect for building proposals, writing articles, or training your team.
Step-by-Step: How to Apply or Use E-Amrit Resources For Consumers (EV Buyers): Visit https://e-amrit.niti.gov.in Use the ‚ÄúCompare EVs‚Äù section to choose your vehicle Check TCO calculator to estimate monthly cost vs fuel Use the Charger Locator to plan your neighborhood usage Visit the showroom or website of your preferred OEM Purchase the vehicle ‚Äî FAME subsidy is applied automatically No separate government application is needed.
For Businesses (Charging, Startups, Investors): Go to ‚ÄúBusiness Resources‚Äù Download relevant policy PDFs (PLI, MoP, FAME, state incentives) For charging station setup: Use MoP guidelines Contact your DISCOM for connection Apply for subsidy if available via the state nodal agency For PLI or FAME registration: Visit fame2.heavyindustries.gov.in Follow instructions for OEM or component supplier onboarding For Startup India benefits: Register at startupindia.gov.in Look under “EV Category” for pitch decks, grants, and visibility Real-Life Use Case Examples Example 1: A Consumer in Delhi Buying an EV Scooter Rajesh lives in Delhi and wants to buy an electric two-wheeler for daily office travel.
He visits E-Amrit Compares Ather, Bajaj, and Ola models Uses the TCO calculator to see that he‚Äôll save ‚Çπ20,000 annually Uses the charger locator to check if charging is available at his society and office Heads to the showroom where FAME II and Delhi State subsidy (‚Çπ5,000 per kWh) are already applied Example 2: Startup Founder Launching EV Leasing in Tamil Nadu Priya wants to start a two-wheeler leasing business for delivery partners in Chennai.
She uses E-Amrit to check Tamil Nadu EV Policy Finds that she‚Äôs eligible for 100% road tax exemption Downloads FAME II and MoP documents Applies for Startup India recognition Reaches out to SIDCO to rent land in an EV cluster She‚Äôs live in 3 months with FAME-eligible vehicles and a state-approved business plan.
Common Questions About E-Amrit Portal Is the portal free to use?
Yes. It is 100% free for all users ‚Äî consumers, businesses, or researchers.
Does it cover all states?
Yes. State-wise policy links, incentives, and manufacturing updates are regularly added.
Can I apply for EV subsidies through this portal?
No. It connects you to the official portals like FAME II, Startup India, and MoP, where you complete your application.
Is the content updated regularly?
Yes. NITI Aayog updates the portal with the latest guidelines, documents, and dashboards.
What‚Äôs Next for E-Amrit? E-Amrit is evolving. Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs coming soon:
Integration with VAHAN portal to track new EV registrations Tie-ups with banks and NBFCs for instant EV loan approvals API for real-time charger data from private CPOs Franchise tools for EV dealerships Marketplace for EV services like maintenance, leasing, insurance Key Government Links for Action {.wp-block-heading} Purpose <th> Link </th> E-Amrit Portal <td> <a class="" href="https://e-amrit.niti.gov.in">https://e-amrit.niti.gov.in</a> </td> FAME II Registration <td> <a class="" href="https://fame2.heavyindustries.gov.in">https://fame2.heavyindustries.gov.in</a> </td> Startup India Portal <td> <a class="" href="https://startupindia.gov.in">https://startupindia.gov.in</a> </td> PLI Auto Scheme <td> <a>https://pliauto.investindia.gov.in</a> </td> Ministry of Power Charging Infra <td> <a class="" href="https://powermin.gov.in">https://powermin.gov.in</a> </td> Final Thoughts The E-Amrit portal is one of the most user-friendly government platforms ever launched in India. It brings together clarity, actionability, and future-readiness ‚Äî all in one place.
If you‚Äôve been sitting on the fence about switching to electric or starting an EV business, this is your sign to get started.
Explore. Compare. Apply. Accelerate ‚Äî with E-Amrit
title: E-Amrit Portal by NITI Aayog: Full Guide for EV Buyers, Businesses, Startups & Charging Infra in India (2025)
